review: Just purchased the 2gb model. I primarily have a desktop that I use for everything, but needed a portable device to work on programming. I was going to dual boot ubuntu, but I didn't want to have to set up my environment again. Its still a possibility, but using nitrous.io there's really no need to at this point. I was a little sceptical about the 2gb model, but I've had no problem multitasking on it, even while using a secondary monitor. Speaking of, this has been the easiest OS I've come across setting up dual monitors. All you have to do is plug it in and it auto detects and expands the display.  $200 is a steal for this.

I have C720 with 4 gigs of Ram.  It is a nice upgrade from the c710.  The Intel Haswell process is faster than the chip in the C710, and the battery life is much much longer, which I find useful.  The 8.5 hour estimate for the battery seems reasonably accurate.  Really an amazing value at the price.  The offline capacity is improving, and I find myself using the Chromebook to create slides for presentations, and write, off line.  I'm not sure who will want the 4 gig model, which is somewhat more expensive.  For me, the added memory was worth it, but for many, the 2 gig model will be fine, and I would not hesitate to buy or recomend the 2 gig model for a child, parent, or co-worker.  While somewhat more clunky in appearance, the Acer Chromebooks have more zip than the Samsung ARM Chromebook, and are probably faster than the new HP ARM Chromebook.  The keyboard is not the best I have seen on any laptop, but I liked it, and find it quite useable, probably above average for machines close to this price.

As a former macbook pro and windows laptop user, I was initially very skeptical about making the switch.  26+ months later and I absolutely love this little chromebook. I have a spreadsheet to track the sales and expenses of my small business, also in the cloud, and it all works without a hitch.  All for less than $200 over 2 years ago. In my opinion, not just mine, Intel Celeron CPU, especially Haswell group is the best insurance against weirdness, for best compatibility, speed and platform stability.   Enabling Cloud Print may take a little extra "fiddling" for some. Depends a lot on your printer and Modem/Internet setup. Preferred setup is to a newer Printer printing wirelessly through your modem/router via the Embedded Wireless Setup app enabled through the Printer Control Panel. Cloud Print can't find access to a printer connected directly to a ChromeBook through a USB cable. Can't hook up an external USB CD Rom Drive either. It won't connect to a printer hard-wired to a router via Ethernet or USB.  Non-wireless printers must be direct-connected to Mac or PC via USB cable while logged-on to the Network acting as a Print server.  A common example might be a printer USB cabled to a PC conected to your router through a USB Port. Newer printers use the Embedded Wireless Setup via the Control Panel to print via wireless network to Cloud Print. Will not work while that printer is also simultaneously connected to Internet by Ethernet and/or USB cable.  Wireless printer must be wireless only to access Cloud Print.  (Not really as complicated as it sounds). Worst case scenario, Google Docs saves document as an rtf, doc or pdf, download to flash drive, SD Card, or email attachment. to Print on Desktop printer.  Some report is a no-brainer, just set up in Chrome Settings for Cloud Print. I have two printers; a newer, wireless HP Inkjet and a 1997 HP Laserjet.  No problem with the wireless Inkjet; old Laserjet only accessible via Cloud Print if LaserJet is hard-wired, USB only, to my Desktop connected to the Internet.  Wouldn't work using my old Hardwired Manual IP address setup. When I followed Google directions carefully, It worked the way Google said it would.  It is possible that your old non-wireless printer might have problems with Cloud Print. Most any newer printer utilizing Embedded Wireless Server will work OK.  Only way to be sure about your printer is to try before you buy.  Google support can be contacted to help with setup.

This product is ideal for students that want the versatility and portability of a tablet with the practicality of a laptop.  The Acer C720 Chromebook has a slightly larger screen than the iPad Air while not being significantly much heavier or bulky, still fitting easily into any backpack.  Most students are going to need a product that has a battery that can last through the day; this device has this ability and more.  I have gone several days with this product before needing a charge.  This product can meet any needs of a college student working on campus.

The battery life of the device is one of the key reasons that I chose the Chromebook over a tablet.  Normally you would see a device lose battery capacity over time, but I have not seen that in my ownership of the Chromebook.  In the year and a half of owning the Chromebook, on a near daily basis, it still provides me with around 10 hours of use on one full charge. With the long battery life you don't have to worry about bringing the charger with you to class.

Its tablet like simplicity is ideal for students that are looking for a note-taking and web browsing type of device.  While it doesn't provide much in terms of computing power for more heavy loaded software, that's not what the product is designed for.  The product is almost entirely internet based for device storage. While it may be an issue for some, college students are going to have internet access while on campus anyways. Its differences from a tablet however make it more ideal for me as a sports fan.  The Chromebook has a full HDMI port allowing you to display onto a TV or Projector, which you won't find on a tablet.

A college student is going to need a product that provides access to internet based classwork.  The Chromebook is the ideal product with a great combination of portability, price, and battery life.  All the things considered I have been very pleased in my experience of owning the Acer C720 and would I would certainly recommend it to current and incoming college students.

My old Acer chromebook was a sturdy workhorse, and when it started to lag after several years, I started looking for another chromebook.  I bought this as a replacement for the first replacement: a Toshiba chromebook CB35-B334 I had to return as junk.

It's small, sturdy, good battery life, a completely smooth transition.  Faster than its earlier incarnation, and beautiful bright screen.

This little machine has been my constant companion for over a year now. Not once has it restarted by itself, frozen, or crashed. Something that is lacking as technology has advanced is reliability. Fancier processors, more ram, but somehow PCs still manage to mess up. Not this little chromebook! I can honestly say that this is the most pleasant computing experience I've ever had, and I've used everything from an Alienware laptop to a macbook pro.

First, it's small. Not too small, but portable and sturdy enough to carry around with minimal effort. It slides into my backpack easily, and doesn't flex under pressure. I had an HP 14 chromebook before this, and it felt much flimsier than the Acer. The screen is matte, which means there won't be any glare. Ever. Sure, it doesn't have the "pop" that a glossy screen has, but it's never bothered me. It can get very bright, and is crisp and clear to read. If you so choose, you can hook it up to a TV or external monitor and it will output 1080p instantly and with no lag. I regularly hook it up to my TV for netflix binges. Speaking of which, if you have a wireless mouse and keyboard, you can hook it up to the TV and close it to save battery. It will enter 'docked mode', where the screen is off, but it still outputs to the external monitor. Pretty damn nifty.

Speaking of battery, this thing reminds me of the old energizer bunny commercials. I've gotten 10 hours on one charge with the screen dimmed before. Average is probably about 8 and a half, although personally I never use it for that long consecutively. I usually charge it once every 2 or 3 days, and it goes from 0-100 in about an hour. That's impressive. This is by far one of the most killer features of chromebooks, they just last much longer than their Windows counterparts. I'd say you could easily make it through an entire work or school day without needing a charge.

The keyboard really shines; it's the best I've ever used on a laptop. It's nearly full sized, the keys depress just enough, and there's a satisfying *click* with every press. Writing this review has been a seamless and enjoyable experience, thanks to the superb keyboard and trackpad. Another surprise was how loud and clear the speakers are. They can fill an entire room and not distort. I find myself playing music on the chromeboo more often than I expected because of this.

Other less enjoyable features are the average webcam, the fan that is quiet but persistently on, and the fingerprint magnet around the screen. The screen itself is matte, but the surrounding bezel is a glossy black, which gets dirty and stays dirty. The computer can get a little warm under load, but it's never gotten "hot", the fan seems to take care of that. I hear it buzzing more often than I'd like (I'm just on facebook, chill out, fan), but it;s never annoyed me. I also would have liked to see full size arrow keys (the left and right are full, but the up and down are one key size split into 2). Other than these few qualms, this is a great laptop and even greater value.

Combined with the stellar battery, low price, zippy performance, and ultra portability, this is the little chromebook that could. Over a year old and it's still as fast as the day I opened it. I use it every day, and I will continue to use it until I see it fit for a replacement. And I don't see that happening for a long time.

Screen, battery life, keyboard --everything is perfect. I'm not sure why there are some negative reviews on the screen. Maybe because people today are saturated with Ultra HD super screens that they can't look at a simple screen anymore. The colors are great. The computer is just fine. What do you need colors to "pop" for? Anywho, I bought this for writing and surfing the web. It does everything that I want very well. The keyboard is not too small (I have large hands). Highly recommend this little machine!

Acer Chromebook C720 Review

If you're looking for a high-speed portable computer, in a lightweight device, at a great price, then the Acer C720 Chromebook is for you. The chromebook weighs only 2.8 lbs, has a screen size of 11.6, and is only priced at $216.

Details:
The Acer C720 competes with the best of them. The criteria that I was looking for in a laptop, being a college student, included, in order: overall performance speed, price, size, video playback/quality, battery life, design quality, and memory capacity. You won't find a better laptop for a cheaper price.

Performance:
The chromebook runs all of my common apps flawlessly like google drive, google docs, gmail, and streams video seamlessly on netflix and youtube. The chromebook has a great battery life at around eight hours and two years of free 100GB on google drive.

External:
When I bought the Chromebook it was only $199, a little pricier now at $216, but still a great deal.
Its compact size, at 11.6 and 2.8 lbs, is nice for the small college desks that im accustomed to and its low weight makes it easy to carry around campus. Its design quality is nothing too fancy, its got a sleek black and grey look with acer on the front and back as well as a good quality touch pad and solid keyboard.

Downside:
Most people are used to a Windows system, this runs a chrome OS system, but it will still perform most of the functions that are used in Windows.

Upside:
High speed performance:
  Quick boot up, 5-10 seconds until you're logged on
  Seamless Video Streaming
  Intel Celeron 2955U Haswell Processor
Lightweight, only 2.8 lbs
Great Price, $216
8-hour battery life
Google Apps allows you to use Windows-like programs
Anti-glare screen
16 GB Drive
Intel HD Graphics
HD webcam

Overall the Acer C720 Chromebook is a great portable computer at a great price.

I bought a 2GB Acer C720-2802 in June 2014 to use for study during my senior year of high school I was getting tired of my incredibly slow and outdated eight-year-old iMac, and I wanted a portable device I could take between classes. I've had it for more than 13 months now, and my experience has been overwhelmingly positive (I've had one broken screen, but more on that later). It quickly eclipsed the iMac in almost every respect (I now only turn on the other computer for about ten minutes every two weeks, to scan documents or work with CDs) and impressed me with its sheer simplicity and versatility. Like other reviewers, I started wondering why anyone really needed anything more powerful. The most important thing to keep in mind when buying a Chromebook is that you aren't really buying a conventional computer. Its Chrome OS operating system is mostly designed to be used online, has limited offline capabilities, and will only support apps from the Chrome Web Store. Consequently, you don't have quite as much freedom with it as you would most other laptops. On the other hand, you'd be surprised at the amount of things that you can do with just Google Chrome, Google Drive with offline capabilities, and the Web Store apps. It can open and edit Microsoft Office documents (although using an app that doesn't offer Office's full functionality), print via Google Cloud Print (which pretty much all modern printers have), stream music via Spotify and Google Play (or play music from an offline library), and edit emails offline via a Gmail app. I managed a year's worth of schoolwork, Web surfing, Netflix, and music streaming without any trouble at all, although I did come to miss things like games and Skype. In the same vein, the Chromebook isn't especially powerful with 2GB of RAM and a 1.4GHz Intel processor, and its 16GB of storage isn't exactly huge, but Google's great OS means you don't really notice either. You don't need a lot of RAM or processing power for web browsing I experience a little slowdown when I have 10-15 tabs open, or when I'm loading a web page full of .gif files, but it's really not that noticeable. In fact, Web browsing is usually very fast. Similarly, since the OS encourages storing almost everything in the cloud anyway and I can choose whether or not to sync an offline copy, I've never run into storage issues (I still have more than 2/3rds left). Plus, you get 100GB of Google Drive space for two years, which is a fantastic deal and more than you could possibly know what to do with (the other "goodies", like the GoGo Inflight passes and the 2-month Google Play free trial, are really good value as well). If you really do need more storage, it's easy enough to plug in a flash drive or external hard drive. I think that the best quality of the C720, however, is how incredibly user-friendly it is. It requires zero setup beyond creating a user account. Thanks to its solid-state drive and pared-down operating system, it really does boot up in less than the advertised 7 seconds (and hasn't slowed down at all!) It comes preinstalled with security features that Google says make antivirus programs unnecessary, and it updates quietly and automatically when you restart it. Its battery life is incredible: it gets the advertised 8.5 hours easily with normal use; during the school year, when I would keep the screen at 50% brightness and do little more than edit documents, I could easily have continued using it for 13 or 14 hours before the battery died. Even when streaming music or videos at full screen brightness, I usually get at least 4 or 5 hours out of it. The operating system is intuitive, well-designed, and easy to navigate. So far as the physical construction goes, it's satisfactory. The device is extremely portable and lightweight, making it easy to carry around all day in a backpack/messenger bag/handbag/etc, and its small size is nice if you're working on a cluttered surface with papers or textbooks. The screen is nothing special, but seems clear and fairly bright, and gets the job done. Its webcam is actually pretty good, and delivers clear video at high frame rates, while the microphone is similarly decent. The keyboard and touchpad are both really quite high-quality and are excellent for long periods of typing; if you don't like using a touchpad, you can connect a mouse in less than a minute. Nevertheless, the C270's plastic casing does feel a little cheap, and isn't the sturdiest it's more or less what you'd expect from a $199 device. I've never dropped the laptop, but my screen cracked after about eight months of use and needed replacing (the replacement screen, which I bought as Acer Chromebook C720 New 11.6-Inch WXGA HD LED LCD Replacement Screen 30PIN Matte Fits: C720-2848, C720-2103, C720-2420, C720-2800, C720-2802, C720-2844, was pretty cheap and easy to install). Also, I've had a few minor dents or cracks in the casing around the USB ports nothing that impairs functionality, but still something you might want to watch for. If you do a lot of typing, the areas of plastic where you rest your hands may start to wear after a couple months. Finally, at least on mine, the lid and lower panel don't seem to fit particularly well when the laptop is shut there seems to be some areas where they rub together, wearing away plastic and slightly marking the screen. Fortunately, most of these issues can be fixed pretty easily if you clean it every few months and buy some protective accessories. I'd recommend a screen protector, one of those snap-on hard cases, and a sleeve, which in total will probably set you back about $25-30. It's not a bad investment for everything you get. Overall, the Chromebook can't do everything a more expensive PC or Mac laptop can, but I didn't feel like I was missing much. 95% of the time, especially in a work or school context, its surprisingly extensive combination of offline and online functions are more than enough. You get a very well-put-together operating system and an incredibly portable, lightweight laptop for a really impressively low price (For context, this entire computer cost me less than the graphics card in my gaming PC. There are headphones that cost more. You could buy five brand-new C720s for the same price as a 13" Macbook Air). The construction might feel a bit flimsy at times, but it's a case of getting what you paid for as opposed to every other area of the C720, where you get quite a bit more. The Chromebook is great as a second computer to carry around with you while your larger, more expensive one stays safely at home, and even if you don't have another computer, it's a fantastic option if you're on a budget.

This was the first Chromebook computer I have ever purchased.  I was intrigued by Google's concept behind it: make a lightweight operating system based around Chrome with high quality parts for a very small amount of money, so I ordered the 11 inch, 2gb RAM version.  It arrived without any problems.

Setup is very easy.  Simply plug in the laptop the first time you use it, open the lid, and follow the instructions.  All you need to do is sign into a Google account, log into a WIFI network, and all of your Google settings, history, and apps will be downloaded to the device.  It does not take more than a few minutes to get started.

It only takes a few seconds for this device to boot up.  Once you have logged in, you can get to work immediately, unlike many laptops running Windows or other operating systems.  The device renders webpages and apps almost immediately.  Even though this computer only has 2gb of RAM, the operating system is light and efficient enough to work perfectly with that small amount.

The battery capacity is impressive.  I have found that the battery lasts at least as long as advertised: 8.5 hours.  This, combined with the speed and efficiency of the device, makes it very practical for on-the-go productivity.  If needed, this device can go from off to spreadsheet in a matter of seconds, which can be useful in business meetings, university classes, and the like.

This device works well, but it only has a screen resolution of 1366*768.  That is understandable since it is only 11 inches, but most newer laptops ship with at least 1080p by default.  If this product were a few years older than it is, this screen resolution would be understandable, but it is a new product shipping with an inferior screen resolution.  This may have been deemed "necessary" to make the product cheaper, however.

Overall, I would recommend this product to anyone looking for an affordable laptop of high quality that can get the job done.

This is my travel laptop, now almost two years old.

The Acer and Amazon descriptions of this little computer are accurate. It does everything that is promised. And in the course of two years, banging around across two continents, I've seen almost no reduction in performance. The one exception to this is the right-mouse-click function on the touchpad. It's disappeared, making right-button menu functions unavailable via the touchpad. Since I prefer a separate mouse anyway, this doesn't affect me much.

Other notes:

PRO
- as many have noted, booting up is amazingly fast
- this laptop has lots of ports ... 3 USB ports, VGA and HDMI, an Ethernet port, audio out, SD card slot
- if you love keyboard shortcuts, there are lots available (search online for a full list)
- basic e-mail review and writing functions, and Google documents, can be set to work offline for syncing later when you have Internet access. Note that you have to choose and authorize these offline functions; they're not automatic out of the box.
- PDF, photos, and multimedia files that you've stored locally can also be viewed/played while offline.

CON
- playing videos: some file formats are not supported (or audio is not supported and video plays silently). Search online for "Why some videos won't play on Chromebook." This is one reason I added Ubuntu to the laptop (see below), so I could use VLC media player for those few video files I couldn't play on the Chromebook.
- connecting to an external monitor wasn't very satisfactory; resolution seemed poor. However, the laptop works fine with digital projectors, more than good enough for classroom purposes.
- can't transfer files to my 3rd generation Kindle Fire.

ABOUT ADDING LINUX
- this is not supported by Google or Acer, but if you really feel the absence of some feature that only a locally installed program can provide, it's possible to add Linux ... Some online research will give you several ways to do this; I used the Crouton tool and chose the Ubuntu option, because I'm familiar with it from my desktop. I can switch back and forth between Chrome and Ubuntu with keyboard shortcuts. For most general purposes, this modification won't be necessary.

The only times I've noticed it getting hot is when I'm looking at a lot of pictures and sometimes if I've been watching videos for more than a few hours. I've had the Chromebook for half a year now and haven't experienced any problems with it. No random restarts or slowing down. It's still as fast as the first day I got it. The battery still holds an awesome charge, unlike traditional laptops. I can't tell you what the battery life is exactly since I only have to charge it every few days, depending on how heavy my usage is. If I'm having an unusually heavy day of usage, I can drain the battery in maybe 6 hours. On my normal days of light web browsing and Youtube watching, it'll be 3-4 days before I have to charge it. This is perfect if all you do is surf the web and watch Netflix. If you need more than that, you might not be happy with this and a regular laptop or desktop computer would probably suit your needs better. I can see this Chromebook lasting for at least a few more years, which would get me beyond my money's worth. Even if it doesn't last that long, you can't beat the price and quality or find anything else like it.

This is not a fully functional computer - you can't connect to network shares, you're restricted to a limited number of apps, and you won't be playing the newest games on here. I highly recommend anyone looking at this to do three things:

1) Buy used. You can normally pick up a C720 for $100-$200 used.
2) Install SeaBIOS and Linux to unlock the full potential of the machine.
3) Upgrade SSD to 128gb, and buy an external 1TB drive.

Those three simple steps aren't necessary for the enjoyment of this machine, but if I was informed of those steps before I purchased one new, I would have given my computer 6 stars. Otherwise, the ChromeOS is decent for daily needs, but lacking for me since there is a wonderful amount of power in the computer. At first, I was slightly disappointed in the computer's keyboard, but now that I've become accustomed, I must say the key travel isn't lacking though it's nothing to brag about. Last, the battery and weight are were it shines above most computers at this price point. This is my first ever review on Amazon, I was compelled to write one.

Got this as a gift from my wife. I knew the machine would be good, but I wasn't expecting it to be _this_ good! This $200 machine has same snappy performance as my work Macbook. And it manages to do this with a entry level Celeron processor, that's just insane. Boots up in 2-3s and shuts down instantly. The keyboard is good, though the keys aren't very deep. Trackpad is very accurate and smooth, I haven't seen a trackpad this good outside of a Macbook. Even though it has just 2GB ram, I haven't had even a slightest hiccup with multiple tabs/apps running with music streaming at the same time. I think Google has done an excellent job optimizing the OS, so much so that you get the same performance from entry level processors as an i3/i5.

I initially thought that the small size could be a problem, but it hasn't been in my last few weeks of use. The resolution of the display is same as the other machines with 13in displays. I was so enamored by this small wonder that I decided to ditch my work Macbook and tried working on this for two full weeks. And I haven't missed a thing. Attach it to a external monitor and it handles a higher resolution equally well - no hiccups there too.

My only little gripe is that the Cisco VPN doesn't work out of the box (for certain types of authentication, for some others it works). I'm hoping Google or Cisco will fix that soon. But if you're a little handy, you can install crouton and vpnc to get it to work even now.

All in all, things don't get better than this. I haven't been more satisfied with any tech product as this. Tip of hat to Google and Acer.

PS: The battery life is outstanding, I consistently get 8-9 hrs.

I have been very pleased with the Acer C720!  The device is very light and portable while still powerful enough to perform the functions that I expect a Chromebook to be able to.  There aren't many well-known native ChromeOS applications in my experience so far, but luckily they aren't really needed.  I have had a great experience with Google Docs - I use it daily to collaborate with my wife on spreadsheets, grocery lists, and basic documents, and it is perfect for these things while I'm watching the kids in the living room.

The device can open multiple tabs in Chrome and play videos without any hint of lag, and that is about all that should be expected for this type of computer.  I chose this device in large part because of the Intel Celeron 2955U it is equipped with.  I was correct in my prediction that it would perform far better than the ARM processors at multitasking and maintain a respectable 7-8 hours of battery life.  While the newer Intel Celeron N2830 provides better battery life and the i3 processors are far more powerful, I have been very pleased with the 2955U's balanced performance/power ratio that compliments the mainstream computing that I wanted the Chromebook for in the first place.

As long as you look for a Chromebook with the realization that it will only be able to perform basic web-based functions, you will be very satisfied with this device.  The Acer C720 provides enough power for word processing, some video watching, and web surfing without wasting time with an underpowered processor or money with an overpowered computer.

I've had my Acer C720/2GB/16GB for 10 months now.  I bought a refurb for $149.  For that pittance, I have a wonderful little machine running 3 operating systems: Chrome OS, Linux via crouton, and Win 7 via Google Remote Desktop.  There's almost nothing I can't do.  Here's what I love about it:
1. I love the form factor.  It's ultra-light and easy to carry from room to room.  Or from continent to continent, as I discovered on a recent trip to South America.
2. The battery lasts forever.  I use the unit all day long, then plug it in to recharge when I go to bed.
3. I'm very happy with the trackpad and the keyboard.  And I say that as a 60 WPM touch typist.
4. I only recently discovered Remote Desktop.  The display died on my Win7 laptop, forcing me to relegate it to the bedroom, where, now connected to an external monitor, it has become a desktop.  No worries, though.  I have a pinned tab on my Chromebook giving me constant access to my Windows machine, whether I'm at home or on the road.  So now with my C720 I can run Word, Excel, Outlook, Photoshop Elements--you get the idea.  Of particular value personally is the ability to run Thunderbird, since I detest Gmail's web interface.  And I have the choice of cloud printing or routing output through my Windows machine to an attached printer.

All this for 149 bucks.  Unbelievable.  Some may ask, "Dude, you're so enamored of your ability to access Windows; why not just get yourself a new Windows laptop?"  Because the C720 is a far better solution for web surfing--which is what I spend 85 percent of my time doing.  To get a WIndows machine that a) wakes up in ~2 seconds when you open the lid and b) lets you surf with outstanding speed (see below for limitations on this), I'd have to spend several hundred bucks.  Then there's the bloatware, the updates, the anti-virus and malware overhead.  With the C720, I can enter the Windows world when I want to, while preserving the beauty and simplicity of the Chrome OS experience.

I've just today figured out how to use the C720 and Remote Desktop to route music stored on my Win machine to my Yamaha receiver.

But I don't want to be too gushy.  The C720 has a couple of shortcomings:
1. The display is just average.  You don't really notice this unless you're comparing it side-by-side with another display, but there's a bluish cast and the colors lack punch.
2. If you're a tab slut like me, you will bump up against the machine's hardware limitations if you get over maybe 15.  The same thing will happen with fewer tabs if you hit a bunch of resource-hog web pages.  I had four different Facebook pages open in tabs today, each of which, according to Chrome OS's task manager, was using up several hundred megabytes of memory.  Things got slow fast.
These, of course, are shortcomings of the C720, but not of the Chromebook concept, on which I'm obviously sold.  Give me a unit with, say, an i3 processor, 4GB of memory, and an HD display, and I'll jump on it.  Meanwhile, I'm enjoying the hell out of my C720.

First of all, I didn't get to buy mine at Amazon, because they refuse to ship it to Guam, despite being a US Territory. For its price, I find the device well built and solid.  At this price you can expect a lot of plastic, not the most expensive looking but given what Acer has to work with, the device looks surprisingly good for its price and better than many cheap notebooks.  It is also quite thin and light, despite not being a mobile processor inside its guts, feels easy and convenient to carry around, in fact, better than most small notebooks I have tried.

The screen lacks saturation and brilliance, I think its precessor, the C710, looks better on that plus the C710 has a glossy screen.  Despite this, I find the matt screen on the C720 looking better than that of the Samsung 303 in my opinion, and will get the work done, plus video consumption without straining the eyes.  Not the best small screen, but still a pleasant experience.
Battery life is exceedingly good, it feels more like a tablet at times for battery life, despite not having a mobile processor.
Performance is snappy, in the typical Chromebook fashion.  Expect those with Haswell processors like this one, to exceed those using current ARM and Bay Trail processors.
I probably won't be exaggerating to see this is one of the best, if not the best, small notebook in the market.  I think this is a breakthrough product for Acer, a home run, despite having two early previous models of Chromebooks, this Chromebook model placed them on top of the Chromebook market, and helped led Acer's recovery this year.
I would look forward to see Acer's successive models of Chromebooks, and see if they can topple this one.

If they do, the power wash function will clean up the computer and Chrome will restore your settings as soon as you log back in.

Keep in mind, this is not a computer for the program obsessed. The Chromebook is an internet machine at heart and has no disc drive, no printer port, and cannot run PC or Mac programs. Internal storage is limited, but the direct connection to Google Drive has made that a nonexistent problem for me. The non-tech savvy among us who are still perplexed by the Cloud might struggle to adjust to an entirely online existence.

I received some advice when I was thinking of getting a Chromebook and I will pass it on. Try running nothing but the Chrome browser on your computer for 1-3 months. Don't use Word. Don't use Paint. Livemail and Outlook Express do not exist to you. You cannot run games from Steam or play music on iTunes. If this isn't a problem for you, you're good to go. Buy yourself that shiny new Chromebook and enjoy quick internetting. If you can't do it, the Chromebook isn't for you or should only be used as a secondary portable computer to supplement the heavy one you keep at home.

Bought this for my daughter for Christmas.  As of today, it has a cracked screen.  Screen on the C710 and C720 series apparently have a stress point that will eventually cause the screen to crack just by opening and closing the lid.  And... when you have a daughter that carries it around like a personal buddy, it's going to happen sooner rather than later.  I have researched this and there are hundreds of cases of the 'spontaneous' cracking screen.  Of course, it's your fault as no manufacturer (including Acer) will acknowledge that they may have under-engineered the portable device for 'portable' use, but that aside, it is what it is.  I'm contacting Amazon today to see about returning the product.  Funny thing is, I bought a protective case for this since it was so light and thin.  Guess that's a wasted purchase as well considering that there's not a scratch on this thing.  Perfect... flawless, no dings, no drops, no scratches... just a cracked screen with no apparent damage other than if you open and shut the lid with your LEFT hand from the upper left corner of the screen, it will eventually snap internally and crack the screen.

Short of the screen crack, loved the unit itself.  Performs as expected and runs as it should.  Good battery life... just a horribly designed screen that will eventually crack spontaneously.

Bought this for the family as a secondary laptop for the kids to do schoolwork on and it's great!  Very lightweight, fast, and perfect for using the web, email, streaming video or music, and getting schoolwork done.  It has multiple user accounts, so that's definitely a positive change from previous Chromebooks.  Performance has been great, no trouble getting work done and using on any websites.  You can't beat this computer at this price point for its price-point, performance, and portability.

I was a bit concerned with the smaller screen size, but it's not an issue when you're just using the device for web browsing and video streaming, and the built in full screen mode is great.  The screen isn't the greatest out there, others have pointed out that it's the same size and resolution as the MacBook Air screen, but the color is definitely not as great, and I don't think it's the screen itself, but rather the protective cover over it that has a rather odd graininess to it you won't notice it unless you look for it though.  The speakers are quite astounding for a device of this size, easily beating out our MacBook Pro's speakers in volume and quality.  Trackpad feels small coming from the giant and smooth glass one on a MacBook, but its the best I've used on a non-Apple computer, and is more than adequate.  Keyboard does feel a bit cramped, but is very usable even for someone with very large hands like myself.  I haven't heard the fan turn on once, even with 20+ tabs open and HD video streaming, which is awesome.  Overall construction is great, feels solid, although the lid does collect fingerprints quite easily.

I've noticed that it sometimes has a bit of a stutter when opening new tabs (only if twenty plus tabs are already open, and this is a very minor visual issue, something most people probably wouldn't notice).  It does slow down noticeably if you have HD video streaming and try to work between several other tabs at once, but this isn't usually an issue since I don't normally use the computer much when I'm watching something on the screen already.

The only things I might change would be to add a backlit keyboard (spoiled by the MacBook, and that's crazy to ask for at this price point) and also allowing the user to remap the keyboard as they like.  The built in keyboard forces you to use alt-caps lock to use the caps lock as normally, otherwise it's a search button, which is pretty redundant because you can search just by opening a new tab in Chrome (there could be a way to remap that I just haven't found in settings yet.  Also, the ability to declare/change the device to have multiple 'owners' would be great.  There are some more advanced settings that seem to only be able to be changed by the 'owner' of the device, which as far as I can tell is just the first user to have logged in to the device.  As others have pointed out there isn't a Skype app either, which forces you to use Google Hangouts.  Not sure if this is intentional on Google's part or if Skype just hasn't made a chrome app yet.

Overall, a great computer in general, and an absolutely killer deal at this price.  This is the perfect computer for you if you don't need to anything beyond surfing the web and streaming video, which is probably about 90% of users these days.

I LOVE my Chromebook... however.. there are a few things you should be aware of:

I am typing this on the 3rd Chromebook Ive purchased.  They are very easy to break.. the other two went to the electronics graveyard as one fell of my table and the screen ceased to work.. the other I tripped and fell on (too many Martini's..) But I keep coming back for more.. as again I'm typing this on my 3rd Chromebook.. so obviously I'm hooked on them.

The keyboard is very easy to use.. it has the chiclet style of keyboard and it is very easy to type on.

Most of the changes you make to your computer will be made online.. there is a row of command buttons at the top of the keyboard (like F1 keys on a standard keyboard).. but everything that can be changed via these keys.. can also easily be changed onscreen as well. (Sound, brightness, etc.)

This is NOT a PC.  So if you buy this expecting run the same programs that you are running on your Windows PC or MAC, unless there is an equivalent to that in the Chrome Store (e.g. Microsoft Office - Google Docs would be the equivalent) .  BUT, keep in mind there are thousands of applications available in the Chrome Store that will more than likely fit your need. (It's like an app store for the chromebook) Honestly though - I rarely find myself using any of the apps from the chromestore.. I've downloaded a bunch (Spotify, YouTube and a few others..) but I find it's much easier to just use the online version.

BUT - since the browser is the Chrome Browser.. nothing beats the awesome plugins you can add to your Chrome Browser.

This is NOT an ideal piece of equipment for gaming.  I feel silly saying this as I feel this is common knowledge.. but still some people don't know this.  YES, there are games that can be downloaded from the Chrome Store, but they are the equivalent to downloading an APP and playing them on your smartphone.  Casual Games mostly.  Online flash games are hit and miss.  So if your intention is to use this to play lots of games - this may not be for you.

This device is perfect for:
Surfing the internet
Watching your streaming entertainment online: Netflix, Hulu, Amazon Prime shows.. etc. (install the Hola plugin.. it will change your life)
Online shopping (seriously install the "PriceBlink" plugin.. it will really change your life.)
Sending emails
Social Media stuff
Word processing (Google Docs)
Online video chatting (Google Hangouts works pretty great)

All the basics.  The other fabulous thing about this Chromebook is how long it holds a charge.. battery life is great!  I could get several days out of mine.. UNTIL.  My battery stopped charging.

Apparently this is a know issue with the C720.. that they will just stop holding a charge.  I've had my Chromebook for about a year and it is no longer under warranty. I haven't started looking into what I need to do to fix this issue.. it's either a dead battery or some other issue.  I don't like dealing with tech support.. so I may just say forget it and buy a real PC.. there are so many great deals out right now.  Just be advised of this known issue.  I can no longer take my Chromebook anywhere with me.. which stinks as it is so small and light it easily fit into my tote bag.  I feel I've lost a very valuable feature and it makes me sad face all day every day.

Having been a Windows user ever since Computer Cave Man days I was intrigued by the Chromebook platform after my trusty Dell laptop passed on and needed to buy a new portable machine. I use a desktop as my main "work" computer as it has all the tools I need for every conceivable task, yet the truth is that 98% of my time is spent writing or else engaged with the web. Of course, when I really need those Windows only tools, it is a huge boon to have them so I could not conceive of a Chromebook as my main working unit. But since my dell laptop was used exclusively for casual tasks and web access, the Chromebook seemed promising as it could do pretty much everything I needed.

After considerable research I decided that a C720 was the right choice. I did have a few reservations due to the inevitable quibles and negative reviews, but the positive were so overwhelming and the price so irresistible I decided to take the plunge and like so many people I am simply blown away not only by the Chromebook experience, but also by the incredible quality of the C720.

Let me start with the Chromebook ecosystem: If Windows can be compared to a Tractor-Trailer, Chromebook is like a finely tuned Harley Davidson. Everything that people praise is absolutely true - the fast boot up time is a delight, not having to constantly monitor and update all my programs is a huge relief, but something not a lot of people express is the excellent design and simplicity of the graphic interface - it's simply a pleasure to use and engage.

The C720 also completely surpassed my expectation. All my notebooks have been top of the line corporate machine costing over $1,000, so I didn't expect much for under $200, especially when many reviews labeled it as being dull and somewhat pedestrian. On the contrary, it feels solid and well built and the colors elegantly understated. People complain about the screen - I really don't understand why - I suppose they are comparing it to the latest retina, but compared to my older dell it is spectacular. The keyboard as well - I am a keyboard fanatic and am completely delighted with it. The touch pad also is excellent - again I don't understand why some people complain - again after the rudimentary Dell touchpad, this one is a dream.

I do miss not being able to connect simply to a printer - I suppose this is due to a drivers issue so a necessary sacrifice - not a big deal considering everything in favor, so not a big deal. There is also a slight blurring when you scroll text - I have seen that the C720 has a lower refresh rate than other computers - but again something I can live with.

So like so many people, the C720 and the Chromebook interface both get 5 stars. I make it clear again that the chromebook is not a substitue for Windows, it's a refreshing and delightful complement. Hopefully the machine will last - I do see that some people have issues crop up after a few months of use but type any computer manufactures followed by the words "problems" or "issue" and you will get billions of hits - it comes with the program!

I'm another user with the Wi-Fi problems. My first one had it, so I sent it back. My second one was even worse. I'm sending it back too for a refund this time. I really wanted this to work for me, but it's useless without a stable and fast Wi-Fi connection.

Google search for "C720 wireless issues" and you'll see plenty of other people have had these issues or similar issues.

Mine first one, wireless would connect (eventually) and would be really slow (1Mbps) but at least it wouldn't drop. Loading a basic webpage was fine most of the time, but anytime you needed something more... it would just stop responding and the webpage timeout until you hit the refresh button.

The 2nd one wouldn't even stay connected. It would connect much faster than the first one, but then quickly die. Nothing but disabling and re-enabling the Wi-Fi would get it working again. Once it was working, it was fast(er) but it typically died so fast that it just wasn't worth keeping.

FWIW, all my other devices (Apple iPhones/iPads, Nexus 4, Laptops, Desktop PCs, etc) all work just fine and hit their peak throughput or my ISP max downstream (~50Mbps or approx 5-6MB/s). None of them disconnect randomly, or just stop working. I have tried two different wireless routers (netgear nighthawk and my ISP provided device). I tried DD-WRT on the Netgear as well as stock. I tried every channel that it let me choose. Each time it was exactly the same.

It's the poor quality Wi-Fi chip Acer used, plain and simple.

Chromebooks are amazing. At first, when I opened the box, I was skeptical since the display looked horrible and the overall build quality seems feeble. But in using it for a few days - I have started liking and almost loving this little cute machine. Display is the only negative on this C720 - but for the price you can't get anything better. You can read Office files easy and creating/editing Office files (via Google apps) is limited in functionality of course. It's really light and small and makes this a very portable machine. Remember, don't think you are purchasing a computer that can run programs, iTunes, Excel, etc. This is just like a tablet with a physical keyboard and a much more practical work machine than a tablet is.

This should be bought for:
1. Browsing web, social media, YouTube videos, etc.
2. For those who like keyboards vs. touch screen.
3. For taking notes, heavy browsing (comparison shopping, booking vacations, etc.) is where this wins over a tablet.
4. Frequent flyers and Google power users.
5. As a couch computer.

This should NOT be bought for:
1. Being a primary machine on which you can run programs and do tons of work.

Some tips to make this machine even better:
1. Set the zoom level from settings to 125% and set the default font size to large.
2. When reading articles or websites - press the 5th button from the left on the top. That will make the view full screen. Really nice.
3. Baby this product, it is feeble and gets scratches easily.
4. Set brightness up to a higher level - will making reading easy.
5. Try the two finger down/up gesture for scrolling - really nice.
6. Try the two finger left and right gesture for moving back/forward on web pages when browsing.
7. Try a three finger swipe down - to switch tabs.

The one thing I am worried about is how long will this machine last. I will update this post in 3, 6, 12 months with status on how well this machine has held up over time.

I have had my c720 for a little over 4 months now and it is holding up fine. The c720 pros for me include: very compact, semi-light, great battery life, nice multi-touch mousepad, and great battery life. There are caveats however such as a rather shallow keyboard (I like a longer and deeper keystroke), non-backlit keys, uninspiring display (limited viewing angle and so-so colors but still usable), and an SD card reader that leaves your card mostly sticking out. Also structurally I feel it is not very robust so I definitely try to baby it. I have a purple hard cover that protects the lid and base plus I also have a sleeve for it when I put it in my bookbag. Between jaunts to campus and errands it is still working fine!

My overall feeling is that trade-offs should be considered. The biggest one is the price. It would be very hard to find a compact, nimble, and low-priced laptop like the c720 if it had a backlit keyboard and an IPS wide-viewing angle screen. With those features I am quite sure the price would easily increase accordingly. During the last 4 months I have found I can live with the drawbacks.

For those who say it is limited. I have recently installed linux to run alongside chromeOS. The linux distribution I am running is 14.04 Ubuntu XFCE. Since XFCE is a full-fledged operating system I am able to install actual programs. So far I have installed:

-WPS Office (great looking MS Suite type of program; incl. word processor, excel, powerpoint)
-Steam
-qpdfview (nice lightweight PDF program; can annotate PDFs)
-Chrome browser
-Firefox browser
-VLC
-Clementine (music, radio program)
-XBOXdrv (lets me use the XBOX360 controller for steam games)
-Spotify
-Cheese (web cam program)
-Gimp (Photoshop alternative)
-Transmission (torrent utility)

The significance of running linux is that I can use the word processor in a more full-featured way offline. I am even able to hook my printer directly to the c720 and print due to available linux drivers for my Brother HL-2240 laser printer. Another nifty feature is that since chromeOS is still present I am able to log-out of linux and jump right back into chromeOS without rebooting. Getting linux set up to my liking so far has taken some time (~one day). I am still working on getting the chromeOS gestures to work similarly on the linux side. If you are interested you can search engine Crouton and find resources that will detail the procedures to install linux and associated tradeoffs.

In conclusion this makes the c720 very versatile while doubling as a pretty great learning device as well!  Next step is to install a 128gb M.2. SSD to replace the 16gb one. All in all I do not regret my purchase!

Every child at our school gets one of these, which I love; however, I wish Microsoft had gotten on the ball sooner with the lower priced laptops for education. I also received the HP 14 Chromebook so between fixing students' laptops and mine, I am pretty familiar with them. If you only ever use a laptop to browse the internet, or you don't collaborate with others using Microsoft office products, and mostly do 1 or 2 things simultaneously, they are fine. They start up fast, weigh nothing, and since my students and I use Google Drive, the sharing of folders is seamless, but it would be the same on a fully stocked Windows or Mac computer.  I find I am sometimes making apologies for Chromebooks' ability level when speaking with students or parents. "You want to write/edit a PDF? You can't use Foxfi like in Windows, but there are some really awful apps in the Chromestore." "You want to print? Yes you can, but only if your home printer is Cloud-ready or there is a dedicated printer attached to a Classic Printer." I love Google Cloud Print, but some of my students and parents have a tough time setting it up.

As long as you are aware that you can't download software to this machine, like Skype, Word, Excel, Foxit, etc, you will like it. You can use Office through OneDrive, which is Microsoft's answer to Google Drive. If you can find Cloud/online/app versions of your favorite software, even better. Now that Microsoft has lowered the cost of it's licensing fees, and Intel is making a cheaper chip, there are some price competitive Windows laptops coming out. It will be interesting to see how/if Google reacts when price isn't a huge deciding factor for Chromebooks anymore. Google is coming out with some wonderful apps for education, and they maybe they will make those more integrated into the Chromebook experience.

I use a heavy desktop replacement laptop to run engineering software and play games, but wanted something light that I could stick in my bag so that I could be productive on the go. I considered buying a tablet, but the lack of keyboard was a definite deal breaker and I didn't want to experiment with the pricey tablet / laptop hybrids.

To be honest, I bought the Acer C720 Chromebook because the $200 price tag was attractive enough to give Chrome OS a try. My expectations were not high, but after a month of usage I am here to say that this product is awesome! The Chromebook is very light, feels durable and awakens/sleeps (when you open/close the lid) almost instantaneously. Between working on documents, writing emails and watching videos, the battery lasts at least 6 hours on a single charge and doesn't seem to ever overheat or make fan noises. It's very quiet and cool.

Lately I've been using this just to marathon through my favorite TV shows and will make just one comment on actual performance speed. For the price of $200, it's understandable that the hardware won't be able to handle my bad habit of using "open in new tab" for each new video on my YouTube subscriptions list. Initially the load is slow and the flash plugin may even crash, but for all you normal people who open and watch one video at a time (and avoids having a 100 tabs), then this Chromebook will always run smoothly! The screen and picture quality is satisfactory, there are 2 USB ports available for my mouse (never liked using just the touch-pad), and there's an HDMI port to connect to my HDTV. I'm used to having DropBox take care of my cloud files, but duplicating it into Google Drive was simple and clean. Also glad that there is still hard-drive space for me to download school and work files to. I myself did not see the need to pay an additional $50 for the extra 16 GBs but that is more of a personal preference, as is the $100 extra for touch screen capability.

Conclusion: This product is great for casual use (videos, social media) or light work (email, google docs, blogging) and is even good enough to use as a main computer as long as you don't need specific software for work or play. With Black Friday around the corner, I'm planning to buy this again for my mother. Her only requirement is access to Facebook so that she can stalk me, but that's alright mom, I got you covered.

I love the little Chromebook. It's not my main computer, never will be, but gosh it is convenient for on-the-go usage.

What I like best is how quickly it's ready for work. I open it up from being suspended and by the time I've finished positioning the screen, it's ready for my password--no "Windows is preparing your computer to suspend" delays. By the time I've typed my password (which is easy because there's a real keyboard), it's re-connected to the right WiFi (assuming it's somewhere I've been before). Another blink, and I'm back looking at GMail in a browser window and that's already updated with new messages. And when I'm done, I just close it, and don't have to worry about playing Windows Hibernate Roulette. Nor do I have to worry about running out of battery--the 8-hour lifetime is real, holding up even after months of use--I simply haven't run out yet, partly because I can close it up and be confident of getting back exactly where I was in mere seconds.

I use it for things like email, note-taking, simple spreadsheets, browsing, PDF viewing, Google Hangouts, delivering presentations, Youtube. It does all those things quickly and well. I wouldn't attempt big documents or software development or various other things I do with my office machine, but what it does, it does seamlessly.

I wish it had PageUp/PageDown. I wish it had Delete. And I wish it had three real mouse buttons (especially since it's happy with those on an external mouse). And yes, you do need a WiFi network for most things (although you can take notes without one). But those are minor cavils about a complete modern computer that costs only $200.

I received my Acer C720 Chromebook yesterday. I have never owned a Chromebook before and spent quite a bit of time comparing different models (and being overwhelmed by the variety of options out there). I settled on this particular Chromebook because it really is an amazingly good deal. For $200 you might expect the quality to suffer, but I have been so impressed with how the C720 is built and performs. Yes, it's made of plastic. But the full-sized keyboard has a very solid feel. I type over 90 words per minute and I'm not getting any missing keystrokes at all. This is one of the most important aspects for me because I am a writer. The hinge is tight and solid-feeling, there is no flimsiness to the screen or awkward loosening of the hinge that I've noticed even in pricier electronics. The touch pad is highly responsive, zero complaints there. The Wi-Fi range is stunning. I can't get either of my tablets to hold a Wi-Fi signal in my bedroom. The C720 on the other hand keeps the signal and loads pages and games very quickly. The speakers are also surprisingly good for this price point. Watching Netflix movies and listening to music are fantastic experiences on the C720. The screen resolution is considered "alright" by today's standards, but the matte finish makes everything very crisp and readable. Colors are vibrant and washout is minimal. The screen is readable from multiple angles. The battery life is as good as advertised! I am always skeptical about claims regarding battery life, but I can and do get a solid 8 hours out of a full charge. The "time left" on a charge indicator is also accurate, thank goodness.

If you haven't owned a Chromebook before and this is your first time shopping for one, I promise you the C720 will not disappoint. It is jaw-dropping how much this little machine can do for just $200. That's cheap enough to use this as a trial run for a more expensive purchase. Or not. You might find you have everything you need in the C720. It's that great.

If you're on the fence, just go ahead and buy it. You'll be happy you did.

Update 1/14/2016: I still use this Chromebook on a daily basis and it's running as well as it did when I bought it. It just keeps trucking along. I spent over $1,000 on laptops that didn't last this long. Truly the best computer purchase I've ever made!

I received a working model two days later and i have been in love ever since. I only need my windows desktop for virtual machines and the adobe suite. I can get by without MS Office and i'm a heavy user of Google products/services so it was a natural transition for me in terms of the app selection, marketplace and browsing environment.

As for a computing device, this little machine is a beast. I have never used a computer in recent years that didn't require 4-8GB of ram and a quad core cpu to deliver a smooth, high performance experience. The chrome browser in this system is equivalent to the experience i receive on my custom build desktop with 4GB of ram, an 8 core 4ghz amd cpu and ssd. I haven't tried resource intensive websites but it has handled everything i've thrown at it over the past two days of use without issue. I multitask a lot and always have an abundance of tabs open at one time. It hasn't been a problem, even while watching a 1080p video on YouTube. Granted the resolution is low at 1360x768 so it may slow down when i plug it into a 1080p display but it's still a surprise considering netbooks in 2010 were terrible at rendering 720p videos.

 Using google docs and being in the cloud is an awesome workflow. One of the reasons behind my decision to order this Chromebook was to have a good reason to use cloud services. On windows everything is stored locally so if you still haven't adopted to cloud storage or g docs; you won't be able to easily access your files across all of the different devices in your home unless you use Dropbox, Box or OneDrive. With G Drive built into the machine, i installed the app to my two desktops and phone to transfer some important files to the Chromebook and it has helped me immensely. I no longer need to worry about my ability to locate and retrieve what i need when i need it which gives me peace of mind along with the fact that i don't need to worry about optimization issues, driver conflicts, viruses, misconfigured bios settings, incompatible hardware or anything else that comes with traditional windows machines.

That leads me to another factor in my decision making process. I needed something that would allow me to maintain my online business without distractions. Managing the IT that you use to make money can really cut into productivity and efficiency which becomes incredibly frustrating when you're a one man show. It takes time away from time more important things that need to be completed. I've been using Windows from Win '95 to 8.1 Update 1 and have spent countless hours diagnosing and resolving unexpected technical issues. A mac is out of the question for me, so i'm very grateful for an alternative to be be in the form of a Chromebook. Cheap, fast, light, portable, and with a battery that last from morning till night during constant use. It only takes an hour and half to charge. This thing is incredible.

If your workflow will allow it or if your just curious; i highly recommend you order one of these and give them a try.

I purchased one of these recently, and overall I've been quite pleased. It does almost everything I need a laptop to do, it's compact, has a nice keyboard, and has a battery life so long that I've yet to encounter a situation where I've had to discontinue use due to lack of power. When considering purchasing one of these, you need to be aware of what it is and what it isn't. It is not a Windows computer, it will not run Windows programs or executables of any kind. You can not download anything intended for a Windows machine and expect it to work. Call that point one. It is not a Linux or Android machine. You cannot install apps from the Market, HOWEVER, there are a lot of Android apps that have been ported to ChromeOS, and more are being done every day. If you are a Linux hacker, you probably won't like the Chromebook, there is no shell by default, and a lot of the functionality that a Linux user would expect is hidden or absent. Call that point two. So what is this thing? Well, pretty much what the descriptions all say, a heavily network dependent netbook that eliminates most of the fluff in favor of a simple browser-based environment. Is this a bad thing? No, if you are primarily looking for a web browsing and e-mail machine (90% of what I use a laptop for, admittedly) that can handle some basic document-based tasks. The upside: it can do almost everything a high-end Android tablet can do for less money and (for me) greater convenience. It's mostly idiot-proof. It's largely free from any security concerns. It's fast, simple, and there are no licensing issues. The downside: What it can't do...connect to Windows workgroups or domains easily (use Cloud for this), print easily (Cloud again), navigate (no GPS enabled), not very upgradeable (RAM is not upgradeable on this model, however larger SSDs can be installed if you are technically competent and follow the procedure correctly, (it is not trivial).

In short, I give it 4 stars for doing what it was designed to well. If it had a GPS capability (most tablets have this), I'd give it 5. Overall, I'm satisfied with it for the price I paid, and it's the first new laptop/netbook I've bought in a while. I was originally considering installing Linux, but the Chrome OS works so well for what I use this for, that I don't really see the point. If people paid more careful attention to what they need when they're considering buying a Chromebook, there would be less complaints. It will not replace a full-featured Windows or Mac laptop for every role that they might fill, but for a lot of people, it would be close enough.

-The Intel Celeron processor is actually very impressive in running tasks, and much more capable of multitasking than the old netbooks from several years ago.  Web browse, write a document, and watch a video on youtube at the same time with ease.
-Lower chances of being infected by a virus with a new, minimal OS with virus protection built in.  However, always know, NO computer is 100% safe from viruses.  Be a smart internet surfer, and be careful of the Apps you install.
-Seamlessly work with Google's program ecosystem, equivalent  of Microsoft Office are available as Google Docs.  Similar Apps are available on Google Play, with new and rising applications released all the time.
-Matte screen means less glare when working outside.  Screen brightness is adequate for outdoor use.
-Considerable battery life, about 6 hours with steady use. 8.5 Hours seems to be the maximum with limited use (using one program, or just web browsing with minimal brightness)
-Chrome OS is easy to learn, easy to use for all ages.

CONS:
-Limited Hard Drive storage.  You are relining on internet-based storage, and should have a backup of your work with you.  Consider an external drive.
-Keyboard feels unsatisfying to use, it isn't the worst, but lacks quality and feels cheap.
-A new ecosystem of applications that take time to get used to, but most of the basic applications, such as Google Docs, are straightforward and handy to use.
-Not upgrade-able.
-Not usable for graphic design, gaming, or intensive 4K video viewing (but really, did you expect it to be capable of these things?)

The C720 is a device that lets me do everything I need for work and play. I am an IT administrator and I was looking for a device that is portable enough for me to move back and forth between multiple locations. At first I considered a tablet, but without a physical keyboard, it is very difficult to type fast and be productive. Let's face it, typing with your thumbs or using one finger at a time is not ideal. All of the servers I setup at my place of employment can be administered through a web browser. I tried using the web browser on a smartphone and tablet, but the experience was horrible. Even with "Desktop Site" enabled, the scaling was just off and was difficult to navigate. The advantage of a chromebook is that you will always have the desktop version of a website instead of a mobile version. I can also remotely control my own computers or my co-workers computers if they need me to troubleshoot something for them.

I am also a graduate student and the chromebook fulfills all of my needs for school. The chromebook will not be perfect for all students. Since I am a business student, I do not use specialized software that is only found on Windows or Mac. Using Google Docs, Sheets, and Slides have replaced Microsoft Office for me. If you try using the android or IOS apps for Docs, Sheets, and Slide, you will most likely have very crippled office applications. However, since you are getting full websites on a chromebook, the transition from Microsoft Office to Google Docs was seamless. Because my professors always request APA format for my papers, I am very happy that I can still format my papers correctly on the chromebook.

It is great that Netflix, Hulu, YouTube, and CrunchyRoll work well on the C720. If you install an ad blocker onto the C720, almost all ads from YouTube and Hulu are blocked. Because of this feature, I find myself watching more video content from the C720 instead of my phablet or tablet.

I have heard some people say that chromebooks are bricks without the internet. I would like to say that this is not true. Without internet connection, I can still access my documents from Drive. I can even edit my documents offline as well. The second my chromebook has internet access again, all of the changes I made in Google Drive or Google Docs are synced. I was also able to play movies and music that are stored on an SD card. Even without an internet connection, it is possible to still be productive. I will admit that you can't do everything on a chromebook without internet connection. When you think about it, what will you use your Windows or Mac PC for if you do not have an internet connection? I remember when my home internet connection was down for maintenance, my wife never touched her Windows PC or tablet. When the internet connection was up and running again, she was using her devices again.

Because of how chromebooks are setup, you are getting a very personalized device. When you sign-in to your chromebook, you see your bookmarks, apps, and search history. If you are a fan of Google Now, you will also see the same notifications on the chromebook.

So far, I have commented a lot about the positive side of the C720. Now it is time to talk about some things that I think can be improved. The screen is a common issue that people have with the C720. For the price, it is acceptable, but you are not getting a screen that is ideal for photo editing. There are some great photo editing apps for chromebooks, but because of the quality of the screen, your adjustments to the brightness and contrast of a picture will be off. How you adjust pictures on the C720 may look good, but when you look at the picture on another device, it may look slightly different. The lack of an ethernet port is also an issue that I have. It is great that this is a wifi device. The problem is that many public wifi spots such as your local library or coffee shop may have poor quality wifi access points. In these cases, an ethernet connection will be much more reliable. That is about it for the cons that I have with the C720.

Remember that when you are purchasing the C720 or any chromebook, understand that the operating system is different. I notice that many people get this and think it is a cheap laptop with Windows and are disappointed. Before buying a chromebook, you can test out its functionality by downloading the Chrome web browser on your current computer. Checkout the Chrome app store and start testing out different applications. Anything you can do in the Chrome web browser, you can do in a Chromebook.

Even though the C720 has its cons, I am still happy with my purchase overall. Because of the C720, I feel more productive whether I am at my desk or offsite. I thought that phablets will help me get more work done because of the larger screen. I now believe that the C720 allows me to do more work than my Note 3.

It's hard for me to describe the appeal of a Chromebook to those who have never used it. First thing I ask to prospective buyers, have you ever used the Chrome browser before? If yes, it's a little easier to describe and even so very difficult and if no, then it's damn near impossible. Chrome, as a browser, is pretty much the ultimate tool for navigating the internet. Google has reigned supreme over search engines since launching and has remained the cream of the crop, and while there have been competitors over the years and people have questioned many of their changes they have kept prevalent for a reason. Same thing applies to their browser, it's fast, efficient, easy to use, and has constantly endured a number of changes with the user in mind.

Chrome OS is the Chrome browser on steroids and nothing more. This might be disappointing to some who are used to the traditional environment of a computer, but rest assured that most if not all of your needs will be satisfied by this device. You can create documents, you can edit photos and video, there are IDEs for programming, remote desktop functions, chat features, and a whole lot more. Sure, a lot of these features are not going to be as in-depth as their Windows or Mac counterparts but these computers weren't built for everything. Chromebooks are built to satisfy the needs of most computer users and other users still have other options if they need it. But if you're looking for a cheap and effective computing device, then look no further.

The downsides are that most people need to get used to cloud computing and that almost nothing on the device can be stored natively unless you use an external hard drive, flash drive, or SD card, and to be quite honest that can be a pain. And like I said, they have their limits on certain functions such as the media editing and gaming. Additionally some people are turned off by the fact that you're also locked into Google's own software, which while very good, isn't as widely used. For example, there is no Skype so you'll have to turn some buddies onto using Google Hangouts as a substitute.

Moving on, the Acer C720 is a great device with a nice and sturdy build. The matte screen isn't overly reflective and has a decently nice display that can get plenty bright and the colors and resolution are perfectly adequate. Unfortunately, the keyboard and trackpad while also of solid build are loud and clacky while in use which can be pretty obnoxious. The fan is dead silent and the laptop itself never gets too hot and only gets mildly warm while performing a lot of functions at once. All in all, it's built well and works fantastic with the operating system.

The chromebook is perfect for those parents who want to know what sites their kids are visiting and whether or not they are really just doing homework.

PRO: It's like an Android phone with 1. more processing power 2. more storage. 3. more battery 5. more screen 6. w/ keyboard.
CON: Everything you do on this computer is out there accessible to those who are willing and capable. Like an Android phone, you cannot install programs such as Microsoft Office Suite, Photopshop, etc.  You are restricted to apps that are available in Google.  You should make sure that the files that you want to use can be opened and/or edited in an Android operating system. If you cannot open/edit a file on Android phone then you cannot open/edit it in a Chrome book.

This is a poor choice if you ever need to use your laptop for business software.  You cannot install programs on any Chromebook, ALL of your software must be hosted in the cloud AND you better have an internet connection at all times.  Your internet goes down, you're out of luck.

Want to install a games like World of Warcraft or Dota2 or Call of Duty?  You're out of luck.

For only $30 more you could have fixed the first problem with a Windows laptop.  For only ~$200 more you could have fixed the second problem and have mobile games.

So what benefit does the chromebook offer?  It has good batter life if all you want to do is surf the web and use Google docs.  Personally, I'd rather just spend the extra $30 and get a real computer.
