Original Post on 10/10/14:

I just purchased this at a BestBuy store a few days back. I have been out of town on business and left my iPad at home, so I decided to see what cheap options they had for my personal use in lieu of the MIA iPad. Low and behold, I found this model as the former display model being sold with the open box specials for $98. I have to admit, I figured that it wouldn't be worth it, and I couldn't get any answers out of the staff at Bestbuy about the hardware, and sadly my smartphone was dead. I left and didn't buy it. Once I got back to the hotel I researched the hardware for this little machine and decided to go back the next day and grab it....and boy am I glad I did. I think this has been the best bargain of anything I have purchased in this category, ever! I am actually typing on this machine right now on a flight using in-flight wifi.

The computer is pretty slick for what you get, I have to laugh because it has way more computing power than my first computers in the early 90's. I also was only interested in picking up one of these with Intel hardware, which ruled out the Samsung models (this is because I wanted something to dual boot linux with). Great machine for the money, very light weight, very snappy, amazing battery life, and even the screen impresses me for the price I paid.

Now onto the OS. Chrome really is not that bad, probably decent for most of your web browsing / casual internet needs. I don't care for the way they have incorporated office documents, which requires an internet connection. This thing boots up really fast too.

Extra bonus: I successfully installed Ubuntu Linux to dual boot on this machine. In most cases I will probably be using Ubuntu, but Chrome deff has its place. Right now I am using chrome since I just want to use the web browser, and that is actually snappier. The Ubuntu OS actually runs way better than I expected on this machine also, which is to say pretty darn quick too. With my install / experience, everything was seamless too.

Overall I can't believe how much you get for your $98. I am just ecstatic. I am definitely done with the iPad 3 that I have at home. This is way more versatile, and doesn't lock you into all the Apple nonsense. I really can't list any serious cons. If the price tag were higher I might say well its too bad that the chasis is all plastic, or that the screen isn't a little nicer....but even though it is plastic it is built very well. Even at the $199 list price this machine is a steal, especially once you factor in the fact that the hardware is linux supported.

Update on 10/16/14:

After using the machine for about a week, I am still glad I made the purchase, I still believe that this little machine is an amazing bargain. Although, my attitude towards Chrome OS has definitely changed a bit. I decided that Chrome is not worth wasting disk space on to have as a dual boot option. Also, the ChruBuntu dual boot script install has a flaw, that being WiFi seems to only want to work for whatever connection used to download / install it. I have now gone the other route of flashing the firmware and making legacy and USB boot and seabios the default, and have only Ubuntu installed. There were only a couple things that didn't work out of the box, and the fixes are well documented. Instead of installing all the fixes, I reinstalled "HugeGreenBug's Ubuntu 14.0.4 64bit for Acer C720 - Version 1.0.3" which can be found here: https://www.distroshare.com/distros/get/12/#comment-1634877963

HUGE TIME SAVER, WAY EASY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

The install methods for both the dual boot and more 'permanent' install option are below:
http://www.linux.com/learn/tutorials/764181-how-to-install-linux-on-an-acer-c720-chromebook
http://www.circuidipity.com/c720-sidbook.html (I recommend the version from distroshare.com referenced earlier than regular ubuntu, same install procedure though)

Overall the only thing I can add to my complaints is the lack of a delete key on the keyboard, as well as the function keys being in lieu of the F keys. That is still a minor complaint at this price point. If I were to buy one of the flashier versions of this computer, you start getting into the price point $350+ that you will find lots of other options with better hardware. Best $98 I have ever spent on computer stuff.

Let me just say that I've had this baby only a day, and it has surpassed my initial fears!

I ended up getting this because my main laptop is in the shop (new screen needed), and I needed to have something cheap, but sturdy and workable as a backup.  This baby did NOT disappoint one bit!

Please keep in mind that this is NOT what one would consider a laptop in terms of working with productivity-type of programs (Microsoft Office), or heavy gaming-- but is basically meant for surfing the net, watching netflix and movies-- which quite frankly, is what I do with my laptop 98% of the time...  Now for the pros & cons:

PROS
Is Superfast - It boots up immediately
Is Lightweight, but not cheesy...
Does not get "hot" or overheated
Silent fan.  Cannot hear it at all
Cannot beat the cost at $200
If you're already on Google Chrome-  nothing you have to do but to log in...
Battery Life is Superb!  I'm already at the 7 hour mark, and still have half battery power left

CONS
If you are not already signed up with Google Chrome (I wasn't until I got this), you may have a problem in having this computer sync to the internet.  I'm gonna be honest--  at first, when I opened up this computer and tried to log into it by signing up for Google Chrome--  it kept saying I couldn't get an internet connection--  when it was clear I could as all the bars were lit up...  and everything else in my home on wifi was just fine...  I ended up going to my Kindle Fire and signed up for Google Chrome and voila!  When I went back to this computer to sign in, no problemo!  I strongly suggest that if you are not signed up with Google Chrome when you purchase this computer, that you do so prior to receiving it, IJS...

No printer hookup is a problem...  but apparently you can do so from the "Cloud", with a printer that has bluetooth...  Haven't tried it yet so I don't know how efficient that is.

No backlit keyboard.  If I'm up late at night, and in my bed using this, I want to be able to use it without lights on, IJS...

No delete or CAPS Lock Keys - These are the two things about this computer that I miss the most, but not a biggie, just an inconvenience.

10/14/14 UPDATE - Discovered that you can substitute the "search" key for the CAPS LOCK key. All you have to do is to click your profile photo on the bottom right of the screen and select "settings".  When the "settings" page appears, go to the "Device" section, and click on the "Keyboard Settings" button.  When the "Keyboard Settings" box appears, pull down the search list and select "CAPS LOCK".  Click the ok button and you're done!

So far, so good!  I'm even considering getting one for my daughter for Xmas...  Also, this would make a great starter computer for young children who don't need an expensive laptop or ipad...  And for senior citizens who just basically surf the net and watch movies and listen to music like my mom...

I am an IT Technician for a smaller school district and felt I had to review this product... We needed about 400 chromebooks for our district, and chose the Acer over the Samsung because we felt this one seemed sturdier (while the Samsung XE303 seemed a little flimsy). While that is true, the quality control seems to be terrible. After about a month of use, we have sent at least 15 almost-new chromebooks in for repair already. We ordered a large batch of Samsungs last year and only had 1 or 2 that were defective. Issues with the Acers center mostly on the screen backlight, with several other issues as well.

In addition, we have found that Acer's customer support is frustrating to deal with as well (which seems to be located overseas!) They rarely offer to pay the shipping for the defective chromebook repair, and are just a pain to deal with in general. In contrast, Samsung has excellent customer service with clear-speaking representatives and will pay the shipping both ways without question.

In summary, while the Acers seem sturdier, the Samsungs seem to be more reliable overall, and have much better warranty support.

We got this Chromebook because my wife and I got tired of our sons asking to use our laptops, I didn't want to buy them their own and worry about viruses, and I wanted control over what they view so we went this low cost solution and we are both pleased with it.

Our sons play simple games from the school's website and the 2GB or RAM is sufficient to handle these without freezing. The 11.6" screen is great for them as they like to sit close to screens anyway so I don't need to worry about a large screen in front of their face, plus it's nice and small for them to carry around.

It's very lightweight and feels as though it's made fairly well, I don't feel as though it's made as well as some other Chromebooks we've looked at, but it's what I expected with purchasing a lower cost device.

We've hooked it up to our TV via an HDMI cable and were pleasantly surprised that not only can we mirror the Chromebook's screen, but we can extend the display as well, giving us two screens. This would come in handy if they wanted to watch a video and do some web-browsing/homework on the chromebook at the same time. I'm sure this is a feature found on all Chromebooks but thought it was worth mentioning.

The battery life is good, which comes in handy when you have kids that don't always remember to plug it in to charge or we can plug it in to the TV for several movies before having to worry about the battery dying.

Control (This is for all Chromebooks, not just Acer) - as mentioned above, my wife and I wanted control over what our sons did and with the Chromebooks, we were able to set up supervised accounts with myself as the main account. This allowed me to turn mature content results off so that mature content wouldn't accidentally pop up when searching for school articles or going through Google Images (you'd be surprised how easy it is to find things you weren't even looking for). They can still go to a website if they type in the URL but it won't show up in Google's search results, or it at least has a lesser chance of showing up. In addition to filtering search results, it will let me view their web history with no option for them to delete it or browse in In Cognito mode.

They are able to use a mouse with it, the screen is good, it's made decently, and has plenty of power for our purposes. All in all, it's a great Chromebook that I would recommend, especially for the low cost.

I chose the Acer C720 for mom after her big Compaq laptop died based on practicality, price, and some light research. Here are the basics, from a Chromebook novice.

Pros: compact, light, and simple to use for mom -- who's easily intimidated by computers -- for light internet, email, and Facebook. Her laptop had serious overheating issues, and the C720 has stellar performance in that area; mom rests it on her bed and it nonetheless runs cool and quiet (but it's still inadvisable to rest it on a soft surface, and mom's experience might not prove universal when doing so!). Cooling was one of my primary concerns in selecting her replacement computer, and I thought I was making a concession there by choosing the C720 over one of the pricier models with a fanless processor, but not so!

Cons: the proprietary Google Chrome operating system (standard on any Chromebook, not just the C720) means a few software concessions. So far that means no Skype (only the Google-branded alternative, Google Hangouts), and an apparent inability to load at least some Facebook apps -- targeted research turned up this problem after mom was unable to load the Facebook game "Doctor Who: Legacy," so interested parties would be wise to look into potential compatibility issues with any Facebook apps they expect to use. And it's important to be circumspect when researching; while checking out Skype compatibility I found a user or two online who mistakenly said there was a simple workaround that made it possible to use Skype on a Chromebook, so there's some misinformation floating around out there. (If there is a workaround, it requires some relatively sophisticated software jiggery-pokery and may very well run afoul of your user warranty.)

So I think that just about covers the things I wish I could have read beforehand while shopping around. All-in-all, it serves nearly all of mom's needs well, and she's happy.

If you've spent the past 3+ hours comparing chromebooks, fretting over Bay Trail vs. Haswell, considering whether you should use more money on a better notebook... just stop. Stop that right now. Click the buy button. And walk away.

Because this sh#t is amazing.

If you have less than 7ish tabs open, even though this thing only has 2gb RAM, it will handle it as good or unnoticeable-y worse than a laptop with a i7 4700MQ. You might view having a certain amount of tabs open as a limitation or brake on your productivity, but, in fact, it forces you to focus on the task at hand, with nothing else open that would clutter your digital workspace. This is one of the greatest virtues of working on a computer, and this little guy will help you achieve it.

 Want to watch HD videos? This will do it. It will even play 720p videos at 2x speed using the YouTube HTML5 player, which was pretty awesome. I love watching my Khanacademy videos and certain audio-information-heavy videos at higher speeds to get through videos faster.

Additionally, ChromeOS is more than "just Chrome web browser and thats it". Yes, almost everything "runs through" the browser, but once downloaded, a lot of applications run in separate windows with their own little pin in the task bar, just like in Windows 7. It's pretty brilliant.

In terms of input, the trackpad is pretty great. It, combined with the wizards who made chromeOS, allows for a multitude of amazing gestures that increase productivity, and make this chromebook a blast to use. For instance, holding three fingers on the touchpad and dragging them left and right allows you to SWITCH TABS. Yes, you can do that with ctrl+tab, but I just thought that this was so cool. WHats even cooler is that, in the default theme, you can even see a light move across your tabs as you do this gesture. I like little touches like that; it adds life to the user experience and makes it feel more responsive, and serves functionally because it tells you how much more you have left to drag your fingers until you reach the next tab. This is just one example of many of amazingly cool things that ChromeOS lets you do. From the first time I clicked the trackpad though, I didn't like it. It's unnecessarily loud and does not "feel" good.

The keyboard does require a little getting used to, however. It has very shallow travel; when typing on a table, it almost feels like you're typing on a super-flat keyboard on the surface of that table. It's a strange feeling, and doesn't provide optimum feedback as to whether you've made a keypress or not. Despite this uncomfortable typing experience, it strangely doesn't slow my typing speed down too much once I spent a day or two getting used to it.

Some people have also complained that there isn't a 'double click to hold and drag' feature, but it's been added in one of the updates; whenever you get your chromebook, just quickly update/restart, and it should be available in the accessibility options.

As a last note, this laptop doesn't provide a right click; however, a tap with two fingers is so intuitive to me, that I started doing it on my other more powerful laptop and being momentarily frustrated that it wasn't doing anything, and forgetting that normal laptops don't do that. This allows for absolutely silent touchpad operation, something that, in some situations, is very convenient. Additionally, anything that functions with middle-click is mapped to a three-finger tap; so closing tabs is doable by three-finger tapping it. Very convenient.

If something isn't working correctly, like certain websites used by your favorite university that don't work well *cough cough University of Houston Casa online textbooks* you can use Chrome Remote Desktop to access your Windows machine, and comfortably work or read from there. Usually remote desktop services are kind of cruddy, but this one is pretty impressive. I was able to acceptably watch Netflix and Youtube in HD over it; roughly 12-17fps. Not like I needed to, but it was just fun to see how well it handled it. You can easily watch Netflix and Youtube on this processor in HD, don't worry. I tried to play a game from my i7 laptop on this one and... well lets just say it was like 2-5 fps. I'm not sure why this is the case, but it probably has to do with the chromebook having to manage a larger amount of information forward and backward. It would lag especially when I would provide input, so that probably has something to do with it.

Of course, this laptop has standard inputs, just look at the pictures/specs. They all work fine, and sometimes the USB ports recognize peripherals faster than my i7 Windows 7 laptop.

This is one of the few things I have ever bought which I can solidly give a 5 star review, especially for the value it gives me.

In summary, convenience, intuitiveness, innovation, and ease of use is worked into the many facets of ChromeOS. This provides for a user experience that is unlike any other currently easily available. Even if you don't want a chromebook, it's worth just trying this out for such a low price and seeing what its like and returning it if you don't like it.

I've had my c720 for more than half a year now. I'm a business student who spends most of her days at school, and fighting for a computer at the computer lab wasn't cutting it :p.

I needed something with Microsoft Office, long battery life, and easy portability. The C720 offers Google's version of Microsoft Office (which isn't too great, see below), a very long battery life, and great portability. The Chromebook has also been quite durable. I've dropped it a few times and although there is a small crack, it's held up better than I thought.

The C720 has a phenomenal battery life. It was about 8 hours when I first got it, and lasted 8 hours consistently for the first few months. Now, it lasts around 6 hours on a fully charged battery, which is great. I can always count on my Chromebook to last me the whole day when I'm stuck in jury duty or at school and need to binge on Netflix :P.

Google's version of Microsoft Office, or what you would call Microsoft Office Lite, was frustrating. It was okay for easy and simple assignments, but for assignments such as for my Business Analytics class which required more advanced use of Excel features, Google Sheets didn't have that functionality. Google Sheets, as you probably guessed, doesn't offer the same ease of use as Microsoft Excel. It's OK, but it's definitely not as easy to use. Google Docs was clunky. Some docs could not be opened either. If you're a university student, chances are, your college offers Microsoft Office for free... I suggest splurging a little more and grabbing a full functionality laptop hybrid instead.

If there is no internet connection, there's not much you can do on a Chromebook. Google docs and Google sheets won't work.

The Chromebook is OK for what it is, and if you are sure that you'll be receiving internet access wherever you're using a Chromebook. But in cases where there may not be a reliable internet connection, or actually, in any case, you have MUCH better options.

When I was purchasing my C720, it was only about $170. Some lucky people even got the C720 for $42 with a Kindle Fire promotion. It's $200 now, and I highly suggest you look elsewhere. What a chromebook is is a computer built using minimal hardware. Well what good is that? you ask? Well, it doesnt NEED better hardware. The OS is designed to run like melted butter because it does away with background processes. All your protection is based on the web browser because that is where youll do about 90% of your work. Sot a dual core with 1 or 2gb of RAM is actually Plenty. I would however, had liked a larger hard drive

Things to know before you buy.

This computer has a small SD card slot, which means it will stick out halfway (I bought one before I had the computer with intentions of leaving it in there as more memory, but I scrapped that idea and bought a low profile Flashdrive
The computer runs EVERYTHING through Chrome Internet Browser. EVERYTHING. Which means it is virtually crippled without an internet connection
The computer has FANTABULOUS battery life. Sometimes listed as being 11+ hours remaining.
You will indeed notice some keyboard differences, but that's okay, youll get used to it.
Once you are online, it's just like every other computer (however I did notice that saving pictures is tricky)

Anyway, If you're looking for something cheap, quick, reliable and new go, for it man.

Chromebooks are meant to fill the gap between tablets and full-function laptops, and at $200 this is a decent value. However, being that you can by cheap regular laptops starting from $300, I feel to deserve a full 5 stars, the ideal sweet spot is $150. Since most upper-class tablets start from $200, I feel Chromebooks need to undercut them to really be successful, because ultimately size and weight are the biggest trade-offs Chromebooks compromise, and from laptops is the ability to install and run full programs. So what you are left with is a very small niche, and niches can only survive and thrive at the right price.

If you've never used a Chromebook, it won't take you long to figure out. Powered by Googles incredibly user friendly Chrome OS, the Chromebook acts as a web tool that integrates everything Google. The user interface is clean and easy to understand, and any questions you have will be answered on Googles Chromebook Help forums. There is a long list of add-ons that can be downloaded from the Chrome Store, which has everything from themes for your browser to games and Microsofts OneDrive. You can stream video from Youtube, Netflix, and Amazon Instant Video (to name a few), even though the display isn't the best resolution (Apple Retina display, this is not) and is quite small for most peoples standards, though on the side is an HDMI port which allows you to use an external monitor or TV instead. With the built-in camera and microphone, you can make Google Hangout sessions and work on a project with classmates or send documents to one another (similar to Skype). Depending on what you're doing, the battery lasts between 8-9 hours of constant use. Google also throws in a bunch of extra goodies, such as 2 free months of the All Access Google Play service and almost unlimited storage in the Google Drive cloud for two years.

While the Chromebook is very versatile and will probably be enough for most people, it quickly shows that it isn't a real laptop and is limited to just Google things. While the store has lots to offer, it is missing tools (like Microsoft Office) that you might want with a traditional laptop.

In general the hardware is good but not great. The trackpad on the keyboard isn't quite as responsive as Apples or Logitechs (sometimes it has a mind of its own), and I have accidentally hit the power key instead of the delete key twice. You can hear the fan on the bottom of the computer, which might bother you (like a hum in the distance). The speakers are located on the bottom of the laptop and sound tinny at best.

Happily the hardware weaknesses can be easily solved. You can connect an external keyboard and mouse via bluetooth or use one of two USB ports located on each side of the computer and you can use standard mini-jack headphones.

Overall, if you are in need of a cheap laptop and you don't do much on your computer other than use the internet, for 200 dollars the Acer C720 is a great choice with no major flaws.

This is coming from a MacBook Pro (2.9 ghz, Intel i7, 8 gb RAM) power user--this Chromebook is simply amazing, and loads pages just as fast (or even faster) than my MacBook. And it can take a hit (or three), too.

I'll just highlight a few things:

Build quality: It felt like cheap plastic out of the box, but for a $199 machine, you can't expect silver and gold. But looks are deceiving. One day, while I was typing up a paper on Open Office (don't ever use this...it doesn't automatically save. Always use Google Docs or Word Online!), and an "error" occurred, so I lost three hours worth of work. I was so mad that I threw the Chromebook HARD on my hardwood floor. I did it again. And I picked it up and did it again. I wanted the Chromebook to die. Well, it now has a crack at the bottom (that is replaceable for about $20), and some scratches on the lid, but to my surprise, the darn thing still worked 100%! The hinges were not broken whatsoever. Everything was still in one piece, just scratched and cracked. I was completely sold, and I bought two more for friends and family. Buy it for your kids, buy it for your dog, buy it just to have a laptop to throw around the living room...this thing is as durable as a tank, but as light as a notebook.

The touchpad: So MacBooks are known to have superior touchpads in the laptop industry, but the Acer's touchpad comes pretty darn close. I usually have to adjust the way I swipe a touchpad on a PC, but I found the Acer's touchpad to not be all that different from the MacBook Pro's, aside from the Acer's plastic touchpad, of course.

The keyboard: Very comfortable. I have medium sized hands, and I have no problem transitioning from a full-sized keyboard to the Acer's keyboard. No backlit keyboard though, but again, it's a $199 machine.

Performance: This is where the Acer C720 Chromebook shines. Remember those clunky, snail speed netbooks back in the day? Or how about that cheap, sluggish Windows laptop you saw on sale for $249? This is not one of those slugs. It is a speed demon. Pages load instantly and consistently. In fact, my patience has gotten much worse ever since I've had this Chromebook. The new Intel Haswell-micro architecture (Celeron 2955U) is a must on any Chromebook as of now (unless you're willing to pay more for an Intel i3 version). There really is a big difference in processing power compared to the older generation of Intel processors.

I probably use my Chromebook 80% of the time to take notes, do research, shop online, check email, pay my bills, etc. It's just so much more convenient to take in and out, and I never really have to worry about it dying on me because 7+ hours on one charge is a really long time. The other 20% I use my MacBook to do extensive projects and when I need a bigger screen to do research and type up a paper at the same time.

Case in point: if you aren't sure which Chromebook you want, buy this one now. Upgrade to a fancier looking (but similar performing) one if you decide that you are a Chromebook fan, but for now, this model shows the best value that Chromebook has to offer at an affordable price.

This is a great machine for internet access, email, and document creation through the Google apps.  If this is all you're doing, this may be a great option for you.  I believe this is all the machine over half the population needs, but there are limitations. Here is my list of Pros and Cons.

Cons:

1.  You can't run Microsoft office or other PC based software.  This is the key hang up for the Chromebook.  If you need specific, PC based software for your work, you need a PC.
2.  You can't hook up directly to any printer
3.  Its of little use offline (no internet connection).  This means you will not be able to work without the internet.  The Chromebook relies on online applications.
4.  You must have a Google account, and all your work will be stored through an app called Google drive.  I put this on the Cons list because some people are not comfortable with this.  Personally, I think you're just as secure as with any machine with internet access.

Pros:

1.  You can perform virtually the same functions of Microsoft office and other programs through Google apps (Google Docs, Sheets, ect.), which are free by the way.  In fact, before I purchased mine, I made sure I could open Word and Excel documents through the respective Google apps.  The translation works both ways.
2.  If you plan to print, you must have access to a cloud capable, wireless printer.  I purchased a Canon printer for this for under $70 and it works great.  This will be easy to identify in the specifications when printer shopping.  You'll enjoy the wireless printer if you've never had one.
3.  As long as you have internet access, you can do just about everything you can with a PC laptop.  In today's world we are always online, so I don't see this as a barrier.
4.  You can store all your work in cloud storage, but you can also us internal and external storage.  This is done through your free Google account, and you can access your work from any machine by logging in.
5.  Great battery life - up to eight continuous hours.
6.  Extremely light
7.  Great value.
8.  It is very easy.  Just about everything is simple on this machine.
9.  Always starts up, ready to use in seconds.
10.  Same internet access as any PC.

So, is a Chromebook right for you?  If you're like most people, probably.

This is an excellent everyday machine for common office tasks and daily browsing. I ordered this as part of the kindle deal several weeks ago so I have had some time to play with it and become accustomed to the Chrome OS. The following are several points that I have observed with the hardware and software:
1) For the cost, it is an inexpensive machine that will accomplish most daily tasks that many people have.

2) Document handling: Specifically, the Google Docs, Sheets, Slides, and Draw apps may be used in place of Microsoft Word, Excel, and PowerPoint, respectively. Google Draw can be thought of as Adobe Illustrator "Light". I use Google Docs the most and you can save a copy of the document in a variety of formats with the Word format being my most used. Therefore, you can still interface with Microsoft Office users. The only catch is that when someone sends you a Microsoft Office document to edit, you cannot comment on it (the chromebook uses the QuickOffice app to open these Microsoft formatted documents). To circumvent this, I have used the Microsoft Office online suite of productivity apps which works admirably. I already have an xbox log-in so I didn't need to create a new user. Also, it is important to note that you can work on documents off line.

3) The battery life is outstanding. I can do a good days work on this machine no problem. On top of that, charging the battery is very quick. Generally, it takes less than 2 hours.

4) For video calls to my friends and family, I typically use Google Hangouts, but if you have Skype you will have no luck as currently, there is no support for Skype on the Chromebook.

5) The keyboard is acceptable. The spacing of the keys is very good and I have no trouble typing. Although, I do find that the keys have a mushy feel to them, which if I am in a mood, can be grating. The track pad is good as it is smooth, and gives a satisfying "click" when pressed.

6) There is no "Caps Lock" key, the shortcut is "Alt+search" and the "Delete" key is replaced by the shortcut "Alt+backspace". There are other shortcuts as well, all of which are easily accessed in case one forgets through using "Ctrl+Alt+?". I have no trouble with this whatsoever.

7) The display, while not exceptional, can be extremely bright and is plenty sharp for a $200 laptop. I mostly keep it at 50% because I don't like extremely bright displays.

8) There is no trouble having multiple tabs open, I have experienced no slow down in performance after having 12 tabs open (this has been my max). Of course, those tabs were mainly text. I have not tested having multiple video-graphic-intensive tabs open.

9) Having 16 GB available is fine by me, I am a heavy user of Google Drive and the extra 100 GB for 2 years is even better. I have not passed using more than 2 GB at any given moment. There is an SD card for expansion, but when put in, it is not flush with the computer as it juts out a bit. So having an SD card permanently in the slot is not an option.

10) A very big plus is the fact that you don't have to worry about security as google constantly updates the OS with the lastest and greatest so no need for an anti-virus suite. (All that is required is a restart when indicated.)

Overall, I was concerned about having a laptop where functionality is anchored to having a WiFi hotspot, but this was unfounded as I have yet to encounter a location where I work that lacks such capability. I would recommend this to anyone who needs an inexpensive machine to work on or as a secondary computer. Integrating into the Google ecosystem for new users may take some getting used to, but it is worth it in my opinion. I for one am very happy that I chose to make this purchase.

I bought the C720 for school (I was unwilling to continue dragging my 15" Macbook to my university for a multitude of reasons) and I am so happy I did. It's such a great choice for students or business people that need something lightweight and compact for commuting purposes and for simple tasks such as typing up reports. Although the Chrome Store is a little barren at the moment, there are quite a few treasures if you dig around long enough. A Chromebook is a wonderful choice for someone that is looking for a distraction-free sort of computer (I say distraction-free as in there are no huge games that can be installed, negating the temptation to shirk off work and just play for hours). Sure, you can download a few games off of the Chrome Store, but they're like any other mobile game: easy to pick up and put back down.
My only - and seriously, my only - complaint is that the Acer model doesn't have a backlit keyboard. A small feature, but it is something I would have loved to see. Still, this one lacking feature isn't enough for me to box is back up and return it.

I briefly owned the Pixel. While it was an amazing computer, I couldn't nearly justify the price. When this refurb went on sale for $150, I ditched the Pixel and ventured into what I thought would be a far lesser ChromeOS experience. I was wrong. Now, clearly the Pixel screen was better and was just faster overall. But really, for 1/6th the (craigslist) price this is /at worst/ 90% of the experience. I think I touched the Pixel's touchscreen twice. Once when I bought it, and once to show it off to the guy I sold it to.

As far as features, they're pretty straight forward, meaning they work when I need them to and I don't miss any from past computers. Battery is outstanding: 6-8 hours of normal use. Connecting via HDMI to external screens is flawless. Video playback is smooth. Speakers are too loud for my desk. Keyboard and touchpad have a great response. The finger-tapping rather than full clicking is better than on my wife's Mac.

A few downsides, but not deal breakers: It sometimes doesn't register three-finger clicks (open link in new tab). I find I have to spread my fingers farther than I think to register the click. Actually, I lied. That's the only downside I've found in 4 or 5 months of use.

You've won another convert. -- and haven't switched to the Linux side for a long while.

My current work occasionally requires Office docs to be edited. Fortunately they've switched us to O365 and I can now use the online versions of Office apps on ChromeOS on those rare occasions it's needed. I was already used to not having access to Office from my Linux time.

Printing is fine a long as /some/ computer is constantly connected. I probably print four times a year anyway.

If you want a laptop to use ONLY for internet browsing and maybe some word processing then this is a great machine at an amazing price. If that is all you want to use it for then I think you will be very satisfied with this laptop. It has enough CPU speed and RAM to be quick and responsive, and the whole interface in general is user friendly. For $200 this little guy is just phenomenal.

HOWEVER, you must understand that none of your Windows software - not one single program - is compatible with a Chromebook. Yes, you can open and edit your Word and Excel documents via Chromebook compatible software. But that's about it.

The thing about the Chromebook operating system is that it is 99% web-based. What that means is that it can only run programs that operate on a web browser. So if there is some program that you access on the web and it runs solely through your web browser you will not have any problem. But if there is a program installed on your current computer's hard drive and you want to be able to use it on your new Chromebook, the answer is no. Unless the program can be run through a web browser or there is some Chromebook compatible "app" (and for Word and Excel there is) you will not be able to run the program on your Chromebook. Even if it is a very simple game or other program that is installed on your current PC you cannot install it/run it on Chromebook. You cannot install programs on the hard drive and run them off of the hard drive. At all. That is not how the Chromebook operating system works. Everything goes through the internet. If it cannot be accessed and operated entirely via the web then it cannot be operated on your Chromebook.

So, folks, give it some real thought before you make the purchase. Is there a program or two on your current computer's hard drive that you expect to be able to operate on your new laptop? If the answer is "yes" then you may be very disappointed if you make this purchase. If you want a laptop solely for surfing the web, using Word and Excel, and performing other functions that can be done entirely via the web then I think you will love this laptop. I encourage you to do some research on your own into what Chromebook applications are available that could serve as substitutes for a program that you currently use on Windows. Just understand that Chromebook cannot run your Windows software - no matter how small and simple the program - unless: (1) the same program can be operated entirely through a web browser; or (2) there is a Chromebook application specifically designed to be compatible with the software.

Don't expect to play big games, edit video (well, you can do video editing, it's just subpar), or do any crazy photoshop tricks (although photoediting is more than do-able on this device).

When all is said and done, this machine is amazing for what it does. It's a glorified web browser for an OS, but that doesn't have to be a bad thing. In fact, the C720 is unapologetically a web only machine. Where offline apps exist however, I never really find my MacBook or my PC useful when there's no internet anyway.

If you're looking for a great secondary machine that is light, fast, and reliable, go for a Chromebook. Go for THIS Chromebook. For $200 it is a bargain nobody should skip out on.

I purchased this with specific plans of loading Xubuntu 14.04 using Chrubuntu. After a little tweaking (there are some wonderful guides on the web), this thing runs beautifully. Makes an outstanding Xubuntu performer. By far the fastest-running personal laptop I've personally used. Can't ask for a better computer at this price.

A few comments, which can either be construed as negatives, or at least something for a buyer to be aware of:

1) The touchpad is very poor, in my opinion. It is very responsive when moving the cursor about the screen, but since the buttons are integrated into the touchpad itself, whenever I go to left-click something small, my cursor inevitably moves just a hair and I end up missing. Frustrating. But still, it's usable, and you have to remember you get what you pay for.

2) When lid is closed, and laptop is packed in a bag for transport, it takes very little pressure to "push" the screen against the keyboard/touchpad area. I continue to experience little lines of grey "paint" from the sharp edge between the keyboard and touchbad getting rubbed onto the screen during transport. I actually went as far as putting a thin strip of masking tape along that edge to help prevent this. It wipes off easily enough with a slightly damp cloth, but again, frustrating. Again, it's good to keep in mind that you get what you pay for. This laptop does not utilize the highest quality materials or hardware.

3) The keyboard feels cheap. This may be more preference than anything, but it's a comment shared by many. There is not much of a tactile response to the keys, and as I type on it, I can't help but wonder if the keys will break one day. I'm a typist who happens to hit the keys with a bit of authority, so maybe this is more of a concern for individuals like me than for most users. I find myself making a deliberate effort to "go easy" on the keys. Again, you get what you pay for.

4) The RAM is soldered in. This is an important point for those who had any aspirations of upgrading this from 2GB of RAM to 4GB. I can understand soldered parts as a manufacturing expedient to keep costs down, but this is frustrating to me only because the 4GB version of this laptop is sold for so much more, which tells me the limitation is more marketing driven than it is manufacturing cost.

5) The SSD is *very* easy to swap out. This was a huge plus for me, as I found 16GB to be far too small to house both Chrome OS and Ubuntu partitions. I went ahead and upgraded to 64GB SSD for about $50. There are great video guides for swapping out the SSD on the web. Very simple, but obviously voids the warranty. Still, I imagine most users will find the 16GB sufficient.

Conclusion:
I couldn't be more pleased with this laptop for the price. If you're computer savvy and want a solid, affordable system to run Linux on, then look no further. This should make a solid daily use laptop for me for several years, provided I remain cognizant of its limitations and take care of it.

For instance, my Chromebook will stream Netflix, whereas my Linux desktop would not. Much smaller footprint than my previous tower desktop configuration. You can eliminate some of your traditional rats nest of desktop computer wires, and desktop clutter, if you make do with the built-in Wi-Fi and the Chromebook's built-in speakers.

Someone just recently pointed this out to me: if you're looking for a better VoIP experience than the built-in microphone will offer, the jack on the left side of the computer is a combination headphone/microphone jack to accommodate a wired mic, and there is also bluetooth capability. This, in conjunction with your Google Voice supplies you with free VoIP telephony.

And, obviously, it's portable. For coffee houses and the couch or armchair, vacation and anywhere there's WiFi available.

I should mention that, while it's possible to install a Linux OS on this machine, I can't recommend that. I've attempted it. It's complex, compared to what it was like installing an operating system on my previous netbook, unless you just have a lot more patience than I do. Following are some excerpts I found on howstuffworks.com. Hopefully this will be helpful:

"Google embraced the concept of an ultra-simple, Web-centric OS in large part due to the huge recent success of netbooks. Netbooks are small laptop computers that are designed to let users access the Web, and not much more; they're inexpensive and feature-limited hardware, and they aren't built for high-powered applications like Photoshop, for example.

Unlike Windows, Chrome won't be available as a download. It'll be pre-installed by netbook manufacturers who adhere to Google's hardware specifications. Chrome is designed to run best on solid-state storage systems as opposed to traditional spinning hard drives, in part because solid-state drives are less prone to failure, but also because they're less spacious -- remember, Google wants you to store your data online. And because the OS uses Web-based applications, you don't need local storage for software, either.

It's no accident that Google stresses the online aspects of Chrome. The entire Chrome project revolves around the cloud computing model. That fancy term simply means that all of your data and applications are stored online, in the "cloud," so that you can access them from any computer, anywhere."

"It's important to remember that Google doesn't intend for Chrome OS to be your primary computer's operating system. Instead, the company sees a Chrome OS netbook as a secondary computer that you use once you're done with the heavy-duty applications you use on a more powerful office computer."

Now don't get me wrong, I do love MacBooks, I only HATE (yeah, spelled in capital letters!) the cost price. Yes people talk about the security, the this, the that, but why why why on earth will I spend over $1000 on a laptop? Why I ask again? Maybe if I wasn't a student I wouldn't be asking.

Anyway, I got this chromebook for $59 (and no it wasn't stolen!, lol). I got it during a kindle fire special deal. Which brings me to another topic: if you don't have a kindle fire get one ASAP, even if you don't need it! I assure you, you will get your money's worth in a few months from the special offers alone. Back to the chromebook: as already explained by multiple reviewers, the chromebook is a web-based operating system that does EVERYTHING through the browser....even games. Now, just like windows 8 you have apps you can install from the chrome webstore (e.g dropbox, pandora, netflix, youtube, bible, evernote, google drive, and even instagram). You also get a free 2-year 100GB google drive storage. The chromebook comes with a flash player so you can watch web videos if you want to. The device battery gets charged in less than two hours and lasts approx. 7-8 hours with heavy use. The device itself is very light, small and very fast. I opened up more than 10 tabs, was streaming music to my wireless headphone from youtube via bluetooth and was drawing chemical structures on reaxys all at the same time and the chromebook didn't even notice. I read somewhere that you cannot draw chemical structures on reaxys and scifinder on a chromebook, well that's a big lie. You can choose the GGA Ketcher structure editor on reaxys and it draws just fine, and scifinder works excellent too. Furthermore, for programs you can't install on the chromebook you can remotely access a windows computer that already has the programs installed using the chrome remote desktop app and it works fine. I have heard people complain that the remote desktop works slowly but that wouldn't be the case if they remembered to change the windows computer theme to the basic windows theme. I remotely accessed topspin and chemdraw on my windows desktop at home from school and it works fine and fast. Oh and yes, it comes with google sheets and slides etc, the whole thing you need to type and make presentations. The google apps are basically the microsoft office equivalent because they look just like microsoft word and excel and powerpoint and even work like them for the most part.

So in conclusion what am I trying to say? If my windows 8 laptop was very fast, very light, very small and didn't interrupt me with updates every now and then because of security issues, maybe I would always carry it around. But even if a MacBook had all of these and much more, I wouldn't buy it because all Apple stuff, though are good, are always too pricey. Oh and get a Kindle fire! Amazon gives awesome deals every once in a while. Good luck!

First, I purchased the Acer Chromebook fully understanding what I was getting. A Chromebook is not a laptop killer or desktop replacement.

It is a better execution of the old netbooks that went out of style a few years ago. Chromebooks are not for loading 3rd party software, playing hard core games, or even using native Microsoft products. A Chromebook is what you use when youy just want to play around on the web, push out a few Google Sheets, and talk to family using Google Hangouts. Did I mention that Chromebooks don't play well with native Microsoft apps like Skype?

But what it does do is give me a fast machine that allows me to do 90% of what I used my full function laptop to do. I still have a desktop that i use for photo editing, managing my music and video files, and playing the occassional game. But for surfing the web, sending email, and other things that I can do on a phone or tablet but would rather have a larger screen and keyboard - the Acer Chromebook does for me.

At 2.75 lbs and .75" thick, the Acer is an affordable beast for quick work on the web. It does everything for me that I need. The keyboard is rock solid. Mouse pad is sensitive and works as well as a full function laptop.

It took me less than five minutes to set up including adding a Google Cloud Printer. The toolbar icons make it simple to do everything I want.

I highly recommend the the Acrer C720 as any Chromebook over $250 should make the buyer think twice about if they should just get a full function laptop instead.

Before giving my review I want to introduce myself.. my name is Justin and I am a newly enrolled student at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and this laptop has literally been a tremendous asset in my summer school classes at UNC.

Going into the latter part of my senior year I knew I wanted my next computer to be a gaming laptop, and for people who don't know much about gaming laptops.. those things aren't portable... I had been so used to carrying my huge HP pavilion though that I believed the task to be manageable. Now fast forward to summer school I have my new gaming laptop the MSI Dominator in a beautiful 17 in screen display and weighing over 10 lbs. my plan was to leave the MSI in my dorm and use my old HP for classes. I wasn't used to carrying my HP around with me and walking around all day with a 8 pound laptop on your back is not fun!! After a week I knew I needed something else because this was not going to work for my remaining 5 weeks in summer school or in the fall. I began my search by looking at the Windows Surface computers and long story short after numerous YouTube videos and amazon reviews and budget concerns I decided to go with the Acer.

I could not be happier with this laptop. This bad boy is so light, and it last all day and some allowing me to pull it out in classes without worrying about the charge. I can go a whole day of work, and watch about an hour of netflix/youtube and work some more and only charge this thing before bed everyday. My only gripe with the computer is the keyboard. Another gripe I have is that there is no caps lock button! To conclude this device is a great secondary computer.. I couldn't imagine this being my primary machine, but for taking notes in class and doing work on the go this machine is magnificent, and the reliance on the internet it has doesn't bother me at all because everywhere I go on campus I'm covered. So if you're someone who enjoys the portability of a tablet, but wants the features of a computer then I highly recommend the laptop. I bought this laptop for my wife so she can use for work. She does work for the business we own. Her job is managing social media marketing campaigns for our clients. She was using a desktop computer that just was not very efficient for what she needs to do and wants to do. We have 2 girls that she also spends most of her day taking care of so she needs to be able to move around and setup and work anywhere. Because of this she also needs a machine that doesn't need to be charged all the time.

I purchased this laptop intent on installing Linux on it. My initial thought was to purchase a decent laptop that is 4 or 5 years old because she isn't going to use it for much more than the internet, email and light office work. After doing a research on a bunch of older laptops I realized that none of them will be able to hold a charge that long and they just aren't going to be very efficient. I went to Fry's and asked the sales people if they have any display models or clearance laptops but all they had were Chromebooks and at the time I was dead set against getting one. I didn't want to have to buy something that I had to spend a lot of time tweaking to get just right. Unfortunately all they had were Chromebooks and the cheapest one they had was the Acer C710 for $199. So, I decided I would keep looking online. I researched installing Linux on a Chromebook and realized that with the newer models this was a lot easier to do. So I went to Amazon and found that the newest Acer model the C720 was only $199 (the same price as the older C710 on clearance at Fry's) plus I had a $50 Amazon card that I got for Christmas. So I purchased the Acer C720 with 2GB of RAM and a 16GB hard drive for $149 +tax. It was the best decision I have ever made.

After it arrived at my house I turned it on and logged into Chrome OS for 5 minutes before I started to install Linux. She was not able to do what she needed to very efficiently with Chrome OS either. You can only be logged into one Google user session at a time and she regularly logs into 3 or more to do what she needs to. If she were to do that using Chrome OS, she would need to logout and login to each one, each time, which is a huge time suck.

I initially installed it using the ChrUbuntu dual boot method but this was just not what I was looking for. So, I read some more tutorials and figured out how to get it to single boot straight into a custom OS and I installed Xubuntu 14.04 on it. After a bit of configuration and tweaking, I got the trackpad working (better than it did in Chrome OS), I got standby operational, I configured the function buttons at the top of the keyboard and configured the machine to connect to her old desktop for extra storage space as well as daily backups. My wife is a photographer as well and this computer just doesn't have the space for storing the tens of thousands of photos she has generated over the last 12 years. The hard drive space is not an issue as long as it is configured to use a remote drive for storage. I also installed Remote Desktop software and configured it so she could open a remote session to her windows computer for running programs that only run on windows.

I was a little concerned at first because of the 2GB of RAM and the 1.4 GHz CPU even though I had heard really good things about the Haswell processors. Naturally, the machine flies in Chrome OS but I thought I would compromise speed and energy efficiency by installing Linux but I was completely wrong. She has not had any issues with speed. She regularly has at least 3 or more chrome sessions open at the same time, each with 5+ tabs and she has not once complained about lag or the battery dying fast. She also does photo editing and uses Skype on a regular basis without any issues.

I recommend this machine to anyone looking for a new affordable lightweight laptop. No matter if your looking for something streamlined for internet/email only or a fully functional laptop, this will work. Chrome OS is great for the average user who doesn't need more that a portal to the internet but if you are looking to do more, such as Skyping, photo editing/managing, graphic design and/or any sort development than I recommend installing Xubuntu or your favorite flavor of Linux. Linux has hundreds of open source desktop applications available, free of charge, for completing almost any task.

Oh yah, she also can work on this thing continually for at least 5 hours before needing a charge. That's when she is running multiple chrome sessions as well as photo management tools and Skype.

I was going back and forth on if I should rate this to be 2 stars or 3.  Ultimately I decided on two, because the standard price is $199.  For that price, it completely is not worth it. PROS:
* Super fast start up
* Easy set up
* Easy web browsing
* Portable

CONS:
* Keyboard layout with the spaced out keys causes a lot of typos. The backspace button is just a bit off, so I can't correct the typos quickly

* No Yahoo Instant Messenging.  I knew I wouldn't be able to run traditional Windows or programs, but I definitely thought that I would be able to download YIM since this computer touts itself to be a web-based system.

*  No video Skype.  While it does have Google Hangouts, no one I know has Google Hangouts to call.

* Difficult to right click.  You have to press the touchpad with two fingers exactly right to get it to right click.

* Apps are always opened in a browser.  I finally did find an app (IM+) that ran YIM and Skype.  However, it has to be opened up in a browser window.  I can't move the chat windows around the whole screen like I normally do, nor chat from the desktop.

*  Printer set up is confusing.  I won't even bother trying to print directly from the Chromebook.

*  Chromebook's Google Documents aren't as user friendly as Microsoft, Wordperfect, or similar word document programs.

All in all, for $59, I'm glad I got it.  It is easier than the Kindle Fire to browse the net when I go to a hotel.  However, I would never pay $199 for this device.  I'd rather get a second hand laptop for that price, or better yet, pay the extra $100 and find an actual laptop on sale. Quick update: I was typing a document and went to hit the Caps Lock key only to find it's been replaced by the google search key - which is a great shortcut but I do need caps lock for documents. However, I found the way to activate caps lock is by pressing the alt and search keys at the same time or you can go into "settings" and assign CAPS lock to the search key.

For right and left clicking, press Alt and the right or left bottom corner of the touch pad until you hear the "click".

Edited again: A week later and I'm continually impressed. I just installed the remote desktop feature and now I can access my desktop, use the software that I don't have access to with the chromebook and work without compromising the speed of the chromebook while editing sound files, video, pictures and scripts while saving them all to the cloud. No more moving files around on flash drives or making clients wait until I get home to retrieve files. The productivity of this chromebook is endless.

Update 8/16/14

I use this every day and have not been let down yet. I was concerned about being able to play quicktime videos for transcribing and was relieved to find a a free app for transcribing that embeds the video in the word processor that works better than any paid software I've used!

I still haven't found a decent audio editor, but with the remote desktop connection I can still access my main computer from anywhere and use the editor in that (as long as I remember to leave it on.)

On top of all of the functionality of this chromebook is the added bonus of not having to worry about viruses. Yesterday an ad on a webpage automatically redirected to "java update" which I normally just close out of, however this time it automatically downloaded before I could shut it down. On a windows machine I would be in a mad panic to get to the file before it installed itself and held my system hostage. With the chromebook, no worries. I just deleted it from the download folder and that was that.

Still no overheating and it stays cool to the touch on my lap even while typing in 90 degree heat. I can't hear a fan at all so I don't know how it does this. I spent 12 hours working on a screenplay with no freezing, no overheating, no computer related distractions at all. Since it's done in the cloud, every word is automatically saved as soon as it's typed. Writers will get how important this is. There's nothing like spending hours writing only to have your software freeze or glitch to elicit a string of curse words you've never heard before and frenzy to try to recover your lost work. Even if this chromebook were to crash and burn, I can still access all of my work just by logging into Google and opening the Chrome browser from any computer and it's right there.

If you're worried about security and having everything in the cloud, Google has a wonderful security feature that you can get through changing your security settings where every device has to be verified through a code that is sent via text to your cell phone. So, if someone gets your password and tries to login from their own device - unless they have your cell too, they're not getting in.

Bought this for using at work/home because I was sick of using my phone to browse the internet, and wow! This is a 200 dollar netbook pretending to be an ultrabook.  The remote desktop is amazingly fast, and usually gets ~10fps on local wifi and ~3-4 fps over the internet.  It works with proxies and vpns, the solid state memory is user upgrade-able, the battery lasts around 7 hours as long as you aren't watching videos, the screen is perfect for watching a movie by yourself or with another person, and everything just works.  There was a hiccup where the firmware on my television was causing problems with the HDMI outputting 720p instead of 1080p, but it seems to have been patched out.  The touchpad is very responsive, and scrolling with 2 fingers is an entirely different experience than side-of-the-touchpad scrolling with a laptop, I'm still not sure why they make laptops with that anymore.

I've also used the linux dual-boot / crouton-shared-kernel boots and while I much prefer the legacy-bios dual-boot option, they were both functional and extremely easy to install.  You put it into developer mode, type about a line of code, and wait for it to do its thing (around 30 minutes).

Would I rather have an ultrabook? Of course, but I'd much rather have 800 bucks and this than an ultrabook.  Plus the price helps mitigate any fears I have leaving it in a car or in a backpack while I'm at the gym or something.

The 2gb of ram haven't been an issue, and if it becomes one, just close a couple tabs.

10/10, would buy again.

My wife was struggling with an old Vista laptop we purchased years ago.  It was very slow and when typing an email sometimes written work would completely disappear. My first encounter with this device started badly. As I was learning to use it,  the display suddenly became very dull and washed out. Strangely colored bars would sometimes cross the screen. Very distracting. I posted a question on the "ask a question list" (above the reviews on the product description page) asking if others had the same problem. The answer was a resounding NO. So I asked Amazon to replace it. They rapidly complied, and two days later I had a new model. Very painless exchange. Thank you Amazon.

Now, on with the review. First of all this is not a windows PC, and that is clearly stated in the product description. It may take a windows PC user a little while to come to terms with this operating system. At first it may seem restrictive, but as you get to know this thing you may come to admire it, as I have done. It is pretty much an Internet based device. Without an internet connection it is barely functional, although it can still do some useful things.

As a web surfing device it really shines. It brings up web sites much faster than my $600.00 Acer laptop. In this computer I was mainly looking for very portable web surfer to take on trips. With this guy I really hit the jackpot. Battery life is excellent. I got nearly 10 hours out of it one day. It's very light and the keyboard is great. But what's really amazing is the touch pad. It is very responsive.  you can move the cursor around the screen with one finger, and scroll the screen up or down, left or right with two fingers. I bought an HP blue ray mouse at Walmart, which works fine, but I rarely use it now because the touch pad is so good.

It doesn't have a lot of internal storage, but unlike many tablets, it works well with flash drives. That gives you an almost unlimited amount of storage (you can stuff a lot of them in your pockets). You do get some free storage on Google drive and that's helpful, but I have found that Google drive makes for a very convenient file transfer device, linking my PCs, and iPhone to the Chromebook. So that's what I mainly use it for. Very handy.

I have no trouble playing my MP3 music on the Chromebook (I have about 40GB worth on a flash drive), As far as videos, I can get it play both MP4s and Quicktime videos from my iPhone, but it can't handle the AVCHD format that my Panasonic Camera produces. However, I use a free video converter (Win FX) to convert them to MP4s and those work very well.

There is much about the Chromebook that I have yet to discover, but the more I learn, the more I like this thing. It is a refreshing change from a Windows PC with its constant nagging and neediness. The best testimonial is that my computer challenged wife took to this thing right away. I'm impressed.

My only real complaint is the display quality. It's pretty good but not nearly as good as my more expensive Acer laptop. Maybe my expensive Acer spoiled me. That's the only reason for the 4 stars. If you haven't seen a really good display you would probably think this one is just fine.

All together there is much to like about the Chromebook, especially for the price. I would buy this product again and, actually, I may just buy another for no apparent reason. Pretty darn good job Google.

Finally, thanks to everybody who answered my question about the display, and a special thanks to Amazon for providing that capability and for getting me a replacement so quickly.

So let's talk about the Acer c720 chromebook. This is a small 11.6 inch netbook style laptop which runs chrome OS on a intel based haswell processor with 2 GB of ram and a 16 GB internall ssd for storage. It boots in the promised 7 seconds and I've yet to see it slow down during heavy use. The chrome app market is still young but there are already a lot of applications which make this more than "just a browser". The keyboard is shallow for my taste but the layout and overall tactile feel is good. I was concerned about the hinges having seen this design with larger laptops and it more often than not is the first hardware piece to fail. I was pleased to find that the hinge was tight and sturdy, this and the lightweight design of the laptop lead me to believe this hinge will last the lifetime of the device. Battery life under use has been the best part, 9-10 hours easily. Screen brightness has a nice range and is acceptable for anything from indirect sunlight to full dark rooms. For those concerned with getting bored of the operating system on this device it's worth noting that this device is well supported by several popular Linux distributions. For the price it is a no brainer even if you only buy it as a travel or spare laptop. Portability of a tablet with the stability of an integrated keyboard and google cloud at your fingertips.

The Haswell architecture Celeron CPU is both capable and power-efficient. The basic configuration Chromebook C720 with 2Gb RAM and 16 GB SSD can run fast-action 720p HD video (example: Youtube video of squash or badminton sports), even in full-screen mode, without any performance issue. Scrolling through complex web pages (example: arstechnica.com, theverge.com) is also never a problem. These observations are made in the presence of 20 browser tabs.

The C720 cold boots to the login screen in 8 seconds.

It has a HDMI port for easy connection to a larger monitor or flat-screen TV. Other ports included are USB 2.0X1, USB 3.0X1, 3.5mm audio/microphone combo, SD card reader, and Kensington lock.

The screen, although bright and good resolution, has problems when viewed at angles and not straight on. Surely it is like this so that a latent user profile doesn't eat system resources, but fast user switching would be a nice option.

Now everything else about this machine is everything you could hope for @$199.  I have many documents and pictures already with Google and once I signed in with my account they were all there.  It copied my chrome extensions from my desktop to the Chromebook once I signed in so configuration was almost non-existent.

It can play every type of web content I've tried; even streaming with the Plex app works wonderfully.  I was surprised at how loud the speakers get, if you have it at max you have to be deaf.  The wifi reception works well.  I can access 5 GHz networks with better signal strength then my phone.

I got this for light weight option to use the internet around the house and while traveling. I bought the Acer C720 to have something lighter to carry around. I have a Dell Windows laptop that's has incredible specs; however, I don't find myself ever using it to its maximum capabilities. So why should I drag around 6.5 lbs with me all day? The Acer C720 is incredibly light and it's much thinner than it appears in the pictures. The build is very nice for a $199 laptop. It uses a sturdy matte colored plastic which I actually find rather attractive. It doesn't look toy-like.

The screen is something that many people have complained about but I find it perfectly satisfactory. The resolution is good enough for the size of the screen and it's plenty bright to be used in sunlight especially since it's a matte display. The keyboard is nicely spaced and the keys feel okay at best. The keys are very shallow which I don't particularly like but I can understand why they had to do that. It takes a little bit of time to get used to but after a day's use, the keyboard should feel fine. My WPM fell about 10 from my average 85-90 WPM on a desktop keyboard but after several days, I'm starting to get back up to that range. The trackpad is really nice. It has a nice smooth texture and it's responsive. I don't know what some of the other review have been saying about it being loose. Mine is definitely sturdy. It does make a loud click but if you turn on "tap to click" you'll only actually have to make a loud click when you have to grab and drag something.

I bought this laptop to primarily use out and about for work so it was very important for me to have it open my PDFs. I put my PDF files on the 16gb hard drive and they open right up with the Chrome PDF viewer. Perfect! All of my documents, music, and photos were already in the Google cloud so as soon as I turned the laptop on, everything was ready to be viewed.

The battery is rather amazing as well considering how light this laptop is. The machine came with no power. Once I plugged it in, it took just over an hour to charge. On my first charge, I've managed to get just under 9 hours! Wow! My usage was pretty light though. Primarily opening up books, reading news, typing two emails, and watching a couple of youtube videos. Still, that's an awesome battery life.

In terms of Chrome OS, I think it has a perfect balance between simplicity and functionality. Sure, it can't run Photoshop or autoCAD, but I think the majority of people don't use those programs. I, personally, don't need anything more than what Chrome OS offers. If you really need some kind of editing tool, the Chrome Store has replacement apps that can get the job done. You just have to look for those apps or just Google search for them.

Speed on this little guy is incredible! I can't believe that a $199 machine can work this quickly. Pages load up almost instantly and that includes videos. In terms of browser performance, the Acer beats my Windows laptop (which has a Core i7, 8gb ram, and a SSD). I don't know how Google accomplished this but it's truly incredible. I think the 4gb model is overkill. This 2gb model has not slowed on me. I use a max of about 10 tabs. The laptop never lags or skips a beat with that many open. I personally don't use more than that at any one time; however, I've heard that this thing can handle up to 20 tabs without slowing down. I can't imagine how many you'd need to open for the 4gb model to slow down.

In general, this is a 5 star machine. If you're looking for a productivity machine that can entertain you during breaks, then look no further. This is the one!

I needed a small, portable laptop with great battery life for writing my next book.  However, I didn't have the budget to plunk down on a MacBook Air as I just bought an iMac a few months back.

So, I took a chance on this guy and I am glad I did...this is a great secondary computer for heavy users and a great primary computer for light users.

This thing is cheap and super fast...assuming you have access to Wifi or a mobile connection (I tethered this to my iPhone when I was out and it worked great) this is a no-brainer if you want an inexpensive machine for checking email, surfing, and web-based activities.  It can do some offline work but its functionality is limited when not connected to the net.

If you are a power user and need to do hardcore editing of audio, video or use Windows or Macs programs...do not get this thinking it will meet that need.  However, it can be a great secondary computer to accomplish other web based tasks...most people do not edit videos at Starbucks.

Also, you have to be comfortable with Google's ecosystem but for the average person who wants to check Facebook, watch YouTube videos, email and access websites that should be no problem.

As a user familiar with Windows, Mac & Linux, I think this computer portends a cloud-based future where we are all essentially walking around with "dumb" terminals connected to the cloud.

In fact, I haven't found anything that doesn't quite work with it yet....Well, I guess Microsoft office, but there are programs out there that are practically the same...for instance, Openoffice.
