Before I bought this, I bought a Toshiba Satellite 15634 because I needed a cheap laptop to complement my Kindle Fire HDX (You know, Flash, keyboard, MS Office, etc., plus the capability to cast to Chromecast.) I returned that since it lagged terribly streaming videos, and was just too flimsy. Then I thought I'd try a chromebook, being apprehensive about the OS. I have since come to love this notebook. In fact, I was sold on the set up, before I even got to the desktop. I opened the lid and it immediately asked for the password to my WIFI, and within seconds, I was up and running. It's light and fast and at $200, it beats all expectations. The web based word processor and spreadsheet are plenty sufficient for my needs. It still lags when streaming HBOGO, but I can cast it to my TV via the Chromecast with no issues (well, other than the fact that if you navigate away from the page you're on, you lose the controls, or I haven't figured out how to get them back yet.) All in all, I find this a delightful little tool on the coffee table, not the least for the fact that I don't have to give up my Tablet everytime someone wants to "check something real quick." I just toss them chromebook.

I really like this new Chromebook.  It has a beautiful display, it loads quickly and easy to navigate.
My two issues with it are the Bluetooth didn't connect as expected and the drag and drop is a little heavy-handed.

I chose this rating because I have had my Chromebook for about a month and it keeps flashing like a bad neon light then, the entire screen goes black and I have to close down the lid and lift back up.  After a few minutes, I have to repeat the process over again.  When it started happening, I tried to click on "get a replacement" and was informed my time had expired!  I haven't even finished paying for it yet so YES, I am disappointed.  Other than that, I like the Acer.
Great product. I absolutely enjoying this product. I still have a lot to learn. I am trying to figure out how to download movies onto it. But I love it. I take it everywhere with me.

My personal Chromebook is the C720P touchscreen. I have purchase 2 more C720 no touch screens for others. All three have worked flawlessly. I don't think I will ever need to use Windows again. I personally do not think the touch screen portion is worth the extra money. If the keyboard was removable the touch screen would be great. I also have had several friends that have purchase one and they also tell me they will probably never go back to Windows either.

When my last laptop wouldn't power up anymore, I started looking for a new one. The only thing my laptop has been used for in the past couple years is letting my daughter watch youtube videos or play games on PBS's web site. I also occasionally surf the web and maybe once in a while do a video chat/Skype.

With those requirements in mind, I wanted to get the cheapest laptop I could find. I am not a big Windows 8 fan (my now-dead laptop was running Linux) and of course Macs are too expensive, so I started looking at Chromebooks. To be honest this was the cheapest one I could find with decent reviews, and at only $199 I thought I'd give it a try.

I'm pretty impressed with ChromeOS as a whole. It boots very quickly, and this C720 has a good battery life (4 or 5 hours with youtube watching). The screen quality isn't the best but the resolution is acceptable. As you would expect, pretty much everything is based around Chrome and it all works pretty well.

One thing that is a downside of ChromeOS and not this particular product is that since everything revolves around Chrome, any Chrome extensions you install have the opportunity to mess the system up pretty good. After a couple weeks of really poor performance after installing (and uninstalling) some extensions, I did a system restore (which was very easy/fast from the menu). After that, I just didn't install any extensions and it has been working great ever since.

The device is really light and easy to carry around. It doesn't feel exceptionally sturdy.. I'm not sure how many drops it will survive.

Sure I'd like it to be a little bit faster, have a higher resolution, more RAM, etc. But for the price point, this really is an amazing product.

After six months, I like my Chromebook even more than when I first bought it.  I'm getting 7-8 hours of battery life on a charge, and the system remains very fast.  Scrolling is excellent -- on a par with a MacBook Air.  The form factor is good -- very light, yet solid.  The screen could be brighter, but it's bright enough that I can use it outdoors without any trouble.  It will sit in standby for a week or two before dropping below 20%.

My only knock against it is that you have to log back into your Google account after every shut down. (At least I haven't found a way around this.)  That's annoying for those of us who use long, random, secure passwords.
What else to you need? A laptop with just one thing: chrome. And god, does it work well. Like, really well. If you're a student, this is the device for you

Pros: Better performance than ARM Chromebooks; Matte display reduces glare; Runs cool; Affordable price; Good battery life;

Cons: Dim display; Bland design; Limited app selection

For what it is, it has worked fine for me. I wold have liked to know how limited chromebooks were before I purchased, I would have bought a cheap laptop for a little more, like this one http://amzn.to/1lRTt26

Still thats no reason to reduce the rating, for what it does, its an excellent performer
I does all it is supposed to do at a fair price. It sits on the end table next to the couch.

I replaced the ChromeOS with Linux, and voila, I have a long battery life, lightweight, portable development machine.
2GB is quite sufficient for ...
- running all browser based apps (such as Google spreadsheets, gmail etc.)
- browsing in dozens of tabs
- running LEMP/LAMP stack based web development environment (includes Apache/Nginx, MySQL, PHP etc.)
- running the Java-based Netbeans IDE
- running several local terminal sessions
- running several remote SSH sessions
ALL of the above AT THE SAME TIME!

CONS:
The reason for only 4 stars are couple things that hobble an otherwise great machine:
- the manufacturer originally came up with a 4GB RAM version (which would have been even better) for $50 more, but now it is nowhere to be found (for found only at unreasonable marked up prices)
- the ChromeOS keyboard is horrible. It doesn't have several commonly used keys such as ... DELETE, F11, F12, PgUp, PgDn etc. Not sure what they were thinking.
No problems to report and easy to use. If you need a laptop for Netflix, small tasks  and simple everyday stuff this is for you...It boots up quick too...

I am not very impressed with this product. Pros: good price, relatively light weight, 100 GB free cloud drive for two years, fast starting, good battery life. Cons: difficult for those used to the Windows platform. I understand from other reviewers that there is a tutorial for using it, and external mouse connectivity and external hard disk connectivity are possible.

I like this product, is good for internet connection, is fast to start up, l like chrome os, but i would like that in the future it will come with support for some hardware, but is perfect for taking with you to every place.

Who is in a personal care facility.  He wanted to stay in touch with his children and visa versa.  A PC was a bit difficult for him so I thought that an Android computer wouild be easier.  Once he learned that he how to sign in he was good to go.  Now he is branching out and using it to search.

I did not want to upgrade my old computer after XP stopped being supported.  This Chromebook is a big browser.  It's always up to date and easy to navigate.  I like it a lot and it fits my needs perfectly.
Excellent Notebook: starts immediately; had it over a month with no problems; I love how long the battery last without recharging.

Used this at a friend's place for about a week when I was staying with them before I decided to buy it. I was undecided whether to go for the C720 or the C720P- the touchscreen option but eventually opted to go with what I had tried and tested. Got it less than 24 hours ago.

We already have a Macbook Air, Macbook Pro and an iMac at home. I got the Chromebook for myself- passing on the Air to the kids.

Very happy with my choice. Can do everything I do with the Air except one (coming to it soon). I browse the net, open and save all MS Office files- Word, Excel, Powerpoint. Just downloaded the 3 Office applications from the Chrome Store- haven't tried them out as yet. Even if that doesn't work out the Google options are pretty good.

I can browse any website, save files locally and print (via Google Cloud Print). I am an Android user (Nexus 5) and most of the features available on the Chromebook either supplement or complement what I already had on the phone. Some of them are given below:

Google+ Photos: My photos from my phone are already automatically backed up to Google+. Photos from our iMac (main repository of photographs) are also automatically to Google+. The Google+ Photo app in the Chromebook just enhances the experience of browsing those photographs though one could also look at it in the Chrome browser in Google+

Google Cloud Print: I can easily print from the phone and the Chromebook does the same. I have a HP 3510 and it connects to the printer via HP ePrint.

Evernote: I use the Evernote for web. Works very well, in fact is faster than the desktop application in the Mac. Doesn't work offline though. I also use the Chrome browser extension for Evernote to add notes and clip web pages very well. Another alternative could be Keep (from Google).

Google Drive: works just like the phone. Accessible even offline. And with the 100GB of storage for 2 years it is a great plus. If you do end up using the 100 GB, even after 2 years if you don't want to pay for it- it should still work- you just won't be able to save more files above the free (15GB) limit but be able to access all the existing files in the Drive.

Hangouts: works with the Chrome browser extension or within Google+.

Speed is excellent. The battery life is just out of the world. It is like a camel in the desert without water- it can go on and on and on.

What's my biggest gripe? Skype. I use it pretty often and it is the choice of most when it comes to video calling, across the world. The alternative offered is Hangout video calling. But as a medium of communication this is still to catch on and this is the most restrictive feature of the Chromebook. Akin to Skype Out, Hangouts also provides the facility to call phones and mobiles by buying credit- works across the world and not only specific countries (the purchasing of the credit).

Of course the requirement of being on line for most of the tasks is also restrictive but then that is a given and known when you buy the Chromebook.

Two other products which I have figured out are not available but might be high use apps are Spotify and Picasa. The latter is surprising considering it is from Google, but I think the objective is to push everyone onto Google+ Photos.

Sound is excellent. Has a small bass and is more than adequate.

Overall- this (and any Chromebook) can not be your primary PC/laptop. But is a must get for easy access, browsing and great battery life. Would be a great gift and also great entry level notebook for kids.

First off, let's get this out of the way...IT IS NOT A LAPTOP! But let's get to what it does do! It is an amazing web browser. It is very fast. I have had mine a little over 6 months and I have never had an issue with it. It boasts a 10 second start up to internet speed and that's accurate. You do have to be connected to the internet to use it. It is a paperweight without it. It is really nice being able to access all of your files, pix, ect on any internet accessible computer with the Google Drive. Google Docs is really nice too. It's free and you don't have a trial period like Mic Office. I really like it. I highly recommend for the basic computer user. It's not for the super high tech people, but for the basic student or web browser, it's great. If you use your Google Drive space (similar to cloud), then you can buy more.

This was my first experience with a Chrome Book as my wife wanted a secondary laptop just to browse. For the money your paying, you can't ask for more. Boots up fast, great battery life, light & compact just throw it in the bag and take it the park or beach it feels sturdy enough. This Chromebook can definitely survive high-school or college life, parents take note.

I had the problem of two computers running Windows XP and I took a chance on purchasing this Acer for one of my homes. So very happy with speed of bootup, battery life, portability, supplying and supporting all my computing needs in the location I chose it for. Screen resolution fine but sound is a tad bit tinny. Doesn't trouble me because I loved the price for what this little puppy can do. Glad I ordered this vs all the laptops I researched with Windows 8.1. Yup, another satisfied customer.
*Added Tip - I am one to ignore direction sheets. I got a notice from Google to update my payment info for the $5 legacy storage plan I have been paying for a number of years to ensure my photos in picasa were maintained. Lightbulb! I don't need to pay for the storage for two years with the purchase of the Chromebook as you get 100 GB free for two years, but you have to redeem the offer by visiting chromebook.com/goodies.
Perfect size and it does everything I need it to.  Shipped great and packaging was excellent.  Have had it for a few weeks now with no issues at all.  Very happy with this purchase.
Does everything I need, nice to have a keyboard not a touch screen. Very fast and easy to use. Light, holds a charge a long time. Easy accurate touch pad.

I use this for schooling since I am taking all of my classes online. Startup is fast, works smooth. Google drive took some time for me to get used to, but the printer I have can print off of Google drive, which is very nice. The battery last a very long time, so when research papers are being typed up, I don't have to worry about the battery dying on me in a few hours. I don't need it for games, I built my own PC for that. It's very lightweight and easy to carry in a backpack. I coupled it with a 64 GB flashdrive to hold all of my documents and no problems. I have had it freeze up on me a couple of times since I bought it, and holding the power button for an extended amount of time (~20 seconds) resets it, and it works fine again. Nice budget friendly for those looking for something to type papers, check Facebook, surf YouTube, and check e-mail.
i love this computer only problem is that it doesnt  have DVD. i wouldnt get it for school, i just use it for social networking and shopping.

I bought this computer for one purpose, to have a small machine to carry on trips to check email, get on the internet and offload photos from my camera.  It does all of these.  First....it is NOT a laptop replacement for most people however it does perform the previously mentioned functions.  I fully understand my iphone will do these same tasks but I still prefer to use a larger screen and as my old eyes aren't as good as they once were.  If you dislike google and can't stand the CHROME browser stop reading now as this is not the machine for you.  As far as functionality, it connected quickly to my wireless network (this is wireless only!!) connected to my gmail and google drive account seamlessly and allowed me access to any website I desired.  The screen seems bright enough and with fairly sharp resolution.  Bottom line this is a functional device that performs limited functions but does them pretty well and for $199 that ain't too shabby.

EDIT....had this thing a few weeks and my original opinion holds.
Works great and also fast price is also very good for the quality of this product no complaints at all

I purchased this to surf and watch video.  It's quick, even with multiple windows open running video.  It's lightweight and very portable and the battery lasts and lasts.  My son uses Google docs for school work, which I thought we wouldn't even use and he likes the accessability to his documents from anywhere.

I never realized how limited my use of computers was until I got the chromebook.
But this may very well be the only computer I use from now on.
It has google docs, internet and a webcam.
And if I run out of space I can just use google drive.
I don't even need to download videos or music, since I get it streamed online anyways.
And all for the low price of 199.
Also, no viruses.
I was hesitant at first because the acer netbooks I got in the past were of low quality,
but it seems that acer has stepped up its game.

This Acer C720 Chromebook (11.6-Inch, 2GB) is the best computer I have ever owned. It is faster than my Windows based laptop. I was so impressed with this Chromebook that I bought two. One I just use to stream movies on line hooked up to my 65" TV via the HDMI plug. The other to do banking & email + just internet browsing. I will never buy a Windows based computer again. Google got this one right & I love the Chrome operating system, It is very easy to use. A big plus is the battery life is over 8 hours on one charge.

I didn't think I would like it as much as I have. Just download the extensions you wish to use and you're in business. I use it for email, internet, and just recently light picture editing. The only thing keeping it from 5 stars is the plastic screen cover feels flimsy. I open it carefully and it works just fine.

I am not a tech guy and my expectations for this machine were out of line. I ended up getting a laptop when I realized all the things a chromebook won't do that I wanted done.

Yes it's cheap but it doesn't really do anything a phone won't do.

I purchased this laptop with the intention that it be a compact, low-maintenance option for mobile computing when a keyboard is needed.  It has more than met my expectations.  The screen is adequate, the keyboard reasonably comfortable and the operation trouble-free.  The keyboard half of the clamshell is slightly convex and the space bar deposits a light, easily-removed mark on the screen if I carry the laptop in a backpack and it's compressed a bit while traveling.  I'll be getting a small microfiber cloth to cover the keyboard when the laptop's closed, which should remedy that issue.  If you go in with your eyes open, realizing that there will be some applications that you can't run on Chrome OS and being willing to find substitutes, I believe you'll be pleased with this machine.  The price is great, especially as a refurb!

I have been looking for years for a thin, light laptop computer that does not have Windows on it.  I object to paying the Gates tax only to immediately trash Windows and load Ubuntu.  This, finally, is that machine.  It took me all of an hour to find, download, and install Ubuntu 14.04 , which worked flawlessly out of the box.  Wireless, touchpad, networking, power management, the lot just work.  I currently have it set up to dual boot with ChromeOS, but I was so disappointed with the limitations of that operating system that I can't foresee using it again.  The machine is zippy and I feel no need for more than the 2GB of on-board memory.  However, now that I have a real operating system on it, 16GB is not nearly enough room, so I've ordered the MyDigitalSSD M.2 NGFF M2 64 GB SSD.

So now I have what I wanted: a thin, light, capable laptop running my OS of choice, and I didn't have to pay for Windows in order to do it.  My thanks to Acer for building the machine, to Google for making open source ChromeOS free, and to Ubuntu and Canonical for making their OS so much better than Windows.
nice device for what it's being used for, new to chrome and we were a bit anxious. but for the price and the performance, we are very pleased.

The Chromebook is actually for my son.  He is enjoying it and has only good things to say about it.  The delivery was later than expected, but Amazon where very kind in compensating for that particular issue.

Before placing my order, I was deeply concerned that I would be wasting 200 bucks on a piece of crap. I could not have been more wrong. The Acer C720 Chromebook gives you a fully functioning computer, a solid hardware, fast internet, and thousands of free Google apps and games, all for the price of a couple tanks of gasoline. What more could you ask for? It's exceptionally lightweight, which makes it easy to travel with. The battery lasts an astonishing 9 hours without requiring a recharge. The internet is lighting fast, the user face is simple. The Chromebook gives you every important function for a remarkably low price. I couldn't recommend it more highly!
Worth every penny, this chrome book is as good as it gets in this price range. It's ideal for Web surfing and email and even handles basic business requirements with Google Docs.
This is a nice small, lightweight computer.  It is great for email and general browsing.  My husband loves his Chromebook!

For the minimum price, you can't really go wrong here. My Chromebook does everything I need it to, without fault. I can have multiple tabs open without any lag or noticeable slowdown. The build quality is also nice; even though it's plastic, it still has a sturdy feel. The speakers can perform, and the brightness is good as well. If only we had more windows programs available! That's my only complaint!

MyChromebbok is a very comfortable device that I enjoy using.  I appreciate it's simplicity!  I admit that I keep a magnifying glass handy as the print size in some instances is a challenge.  Other than that, it's a handy and helpful device.!

Yes, yes, yes. $200 well spent, no regrets. This basically fits all my needs. When I announced I had bought a chromebook a few of my friends were disgusted. One said that "all it does is run the internet" and another said "they break in no time". To the second guy, I'm assuming he was talking about earlier chromebooks which I heard broke very easily. Everything I heard about this one before buying it said that it was much sturdier and did not break easily. To the first guy, I said well, that's all I really need.

I really needed a new laptop and as a high school student my priority was speed, lightweight, thinness, efficiency, and for it to look nice. So I started looking into chromebooks and decided that this pretty much met those needs. I'm not really a hardcore gamer, and if I really need to play computer games there's always other laptops in my home to use. I love google chrome and chrome applications for their simplicity and ease. This gave me all that without other distractions. No need to worry about antivirus, no constant update reminders, no snail-pace start up, no overheating. Just so convenient. Obviously there are drawbacks of not being able to do all that you might be able to do with a traditional laptop but I'm willing to look past that. With my high school/artist's budget I don't really expect to make much and so don't really expect to be getting some high tech piece of machinery that works to perfection.

The only problem I personally face is that my WiFi connection can be pretty s***ty, but that's not the chromebook's fault. Really, if my WiFi was out while I was on my old laptop I would pretty much have nothing to do except wait for it to come back. So why waste 300 extra bucks on something over priced and over large that I won't even use when I could have this for a much better price? Another thing I had to get accustomed to was the small size. I was expecting something a bit larger and I felt a little disappointed initially when I saw it, but I got over it pretty fast. Now when I use my old laptop or another "regular" laptop, it feels ridiculously large and awkward. This computer takes everything I need and gets rid of everything unnecessary and makes my life so much simpler. DEFINITELY recommend it to anyone who's primary concern with a laptop is the internet. 5/5 for me, thank you so much Google.

I purchased this Chromebook specifically to surf the web, read and answer emails, and watch streaming videos (netflix, HBOgo, you tube, etc.).  It works really well for everything.  One feature I really like is that when you open the lid, it is immediately connected to wifi and you don't have to wait for it to connect as you often have to do with PCs.  It really fits the bill for my needs.  It's small and thin and light and very portable.  Excellent battery life too.  Overall very pleased and happy with this purchase.

I bought this Chrome Book as a cheap laptop that I could connect all the time to my main TV through an HDMI cable to watch internet movies and videos.  Then I found out that it makes a fast wireless connection to the Chrome Cast on my TV from any website.  That wasn't the case with my Windows laptops that only made a fast connection with the Chrome Cast from websites that were already set up for Chrome Cast. The Google Drive is also very useful since it includes Word, Excel, Power Point, etc.  Now I am buying a second Chrome Book because my son took over the first one.  He actually likes it better than his iPad.
This purchase was perfect for everything that I need.  It is light and portable, cost effective, and easy to use. I don't need to run Word so it met all my expectations.

I like almost everything about this machine: the size, the speed at which it starts up, the style (especially for this price point), and the weight.

What's bad about it is its inability to connect to internet consistently which for a machine that needs to be connected to the internet to work properly and efficiently, this is a big problem. It just can't connect are a regular basis, especially when the battery is under 80%. I have laptops, cell phones, consoles, and PCs that all do fine on this network  but the Acer C720 just can't compete with those. While the other devices are connected and surfing properly, this machine will drop the connection a lot. Occasionally it will have a nice little run and not drop connection for a day, but that is a rarity.

BTW: I've dealt with Customer Service (both ACER CS and a internet forums for Chrome, google, and general hardware) and haven't had much luck getting it fixed. I like the machine in every other aspect but this.

The Acer 720 arrived in a couple of days. It was neat and clean. Start up was almost instant. It took me a few minutes to navigate my way around. A few days to get things how I like them. Since then everything has been wonderful. This machine is super fast and light weight. From dead battery to full charge is only 60 to 90 minutes. I would recommend this laptop to anyone as a second machine and a first machine to many. Do a little research. Make sure to get the Celeron processor. It flies. Enjoy surfing.

Yes, there are a few tasks I need a different operating system to complete, but overall I can do pretty much all common computer tasks fine with this Chromebook. With vim and ShiftEdit, I even do a good chunk of Web development with this computer. I still take video editing and rom tinkering elsewhere, but this little guy is great for just about everything else I've thrown at it. The built-in terminal works fine, and there's enough storage space for transferring materials around. Certain tasks are still a little rough around the edges (working with zip files could be smoother, for example), but overall, I'm more surprised by what I CAN do on the Chromebook, rather than the other way around. If you are the "tech support" family member and need to suggest a consumer laptop for a less technical family member, the Chromebook could be a godsend for you and for them. You'll need to convert Microsoft Office use to Google Drive use (works fine for me, but I don't really created sophisticated layouts. Chrome's Excel replacement is really quite good now, with much better formula options), but other than that, I think most computer users would be foolish not to consider Chromebooks. The price alone makes them worth a look and with Haswell in them the battery life is great. A few things to keep in mind: wifi must be reliable, new users need to be patient and develop easy (but possibly different) workflows, you may need to search a bit for extensions in the Chrome store to replace a few Windows/OSX functionality, and it may be easier to buy a newer printer for use with Google print if you need to print a lot. I'm quite pleased with this machine and I would not be surprised if ChromeOS ends up as a new Windows in terms of widespread use. With its cloud-first leaning and the ease with which users can switch computers (even to other operating systems with the Chrome browser installed), it's really a great choice for mobile workers. It also really lends itself to use in schools, so the next generation will be well-versed in its functionality and well-aware of its budget-friendliness... a great take-to-college machine for students on a budget.

My wife and I travel a good bit and we use this unit with our Verizon hotspot.  Everything works really well and it allows MOM to stay in touch while we're on the road.  It is fast and (so far) not any problems to speak of.  We did have to change the security setting on our hotspot and ACER work with me on the phone and walked me through that.  Great support.
Very happy with this purchase. I can see this easily becoming my main computer. It starts up very fast and is very responsive.

I found this notebook extremely cheap feeling and don't like keeping things in the cloud. I should have know when I bought it but wanted a cheap backup for email and such to replace my gaming desktop in a pinch. Wrong move...if you are used to a system with high-end specs you will be hugely disappointed in this product. It's best use as I can see is straight websurfing...no more no less. I sent mine back and looking for another backup.....ANY IDEAS????

Small, light, functional, reliable, affordable.  I'm not a tablet person, but a laptop person.  Starts up in under 8-9 seconds, offers all the programs I need (more than I need at Google store), and provides connectivity and ease when on the road.  Love it.
This notebook is easy to use and very light. The speakers are great! I love the simplicity. The battery last for a very long time on a full charge.

This Chromebook's software is very fast and smooth. The device is light and quite thin. However, Chromebooks still have a lot of features missing. Printer support is where I encountered a serious lack of functionality. If you have an Android phone, you can send your print jobs to it, as Android has good driver support from printer manufacturers.
Trying to access your printer directly via Google Cloud Print is useless, unless you have a Windows computer running all the time, with a printer attached to it.

Another problem that I encountered was finding a good calculator program. Chrome OS has a very basic calculator, but if you want to calculate anything more than basic math, then you either have to get a full-blown scientific calculator from the Chrome Web Store, or calculators that are really buggy. Very frustrating, as all I needed to do was calculate percentages.

One final issue that I had, was that I had to use my Google account password as the device password. That required me to dumb down my password, so I could remember it. Normally I have a password manager create a complicated password and then sign in to my Google account using the manager. Why Google choose this method when Android allows you to create a device password is a mystery to me. Apparently, Google thinks you will only be accessing their services on a Chromebook!

When it comes to using Google services and accessing the web, this Chromebook really shines. Do not purchase a Chromebook if you need a full desktop system! That being said, I am happy with my purchase. I bought a refurbished model, and I have had no trouble with it at all. Acer designs a great Chromebook.

Great value and great chrome book overall.

However, the low price does come through in the build. The screen feels a bit flimsy and fragile, so handle with care. Keyboard also does not feel as responsive as you'd like. Upside is that it is very light.

Definitely recommended if you're looking for a high value mobile laptop

Item arrived very quickly, great packaging, good looking, but just a little to small screened for me, so I am returning it for a larger screen.  It was great service though, if you are looking for a smaller Chromebook.
I can't be more satisfied. Light weight and long battery life. I haven't noticed I don't have microsoft office because of word online app and similar apps.
I bought this to take to class and keep me entertained. It has done extremely well and the battery life is great. It does take some time to get used to google docs however

This is a nice, inexpensive piece of hardware. I got one used from an Amazon vendor.

After running ChomeOS on it for over a month finally installed Fedora Linux 20 with the stock Gnome desktop. Although my model (C720-2802) only has 2G (of non-upgradable) RAM, Fedora with Gnome 3 fits nicely. Did upgrade the shipping 16G SSD to 64G using a part from another Amazon vendor. That leaves plenty of room for installing additional apps and almost 20G of space for files. Now I can use my Chromebook to makes calls over Skype! But seriously, if you're comfortable experimenting with computer hardware and not afraid of open source you're going to love this model. There are tons of blog posts and technical wiki articles on the Internet explaining how to turn this into a really useful machine. The only wrinkle is that my unit has a hardware issue in common with some of these 2G models: it shuts down without warning. (this review written by Erica's 10 year old son)  This is a great laptop. Before you read this entire review you need to know that this is a Chromebook. If you already know what a Chromebook is then go to the next paragraph. Chromebooks can't run .exe files like a PC or a Mac can. It does most things in the Chrome browser. So if I wanted to play Cut The Rope, I would go on the Chrome Web Store, "download" it, and it's, "installed." Then, when I want to play Cut The Rope, I press the Cut The Rope button and it opens up Google Chrome on a certain webpage where you can play Cut The Rope. So If you wanted to play Minecraft, you shouldn't get a Chromebook because Minecraft and pretty much anything that you need to download (like Microsoft Word or Spotify) is probably a .exe file. But you can still do a lot of stuff on a Chromebook. Google Docs lets you edit documents and you get 100 GB of Google Drive storage on Google's servers, or "The Cloud, " to edit and store your documents. Also, Microsoft has Word Online which lets you, well, use Microsoft Word and store it in "The Cloud," except you store it on Onedrive instead of Google Drive, unless you download it onto the Acer C720's 16 GB solid state drive. (At least, I got the 16 GB version. It also comes in a 32 GB version.)

  So, for the nerds, here are all the technical specs:

OS: Chrome OS

Processor: 1.4 GHZ Intel Celron 2955U

Memory: 16/32 GB storage, SDD (There are two types of hard drives: SDD and HDD. SDD works like a flash drive and a HDD has a disk. SDD's have bettery battery life and speed up the computer a lot.) 2GB RAM, and a free 100 GB on Google Drive. Also has an SD card slot.

Screen:11.6," LCD, 1366 x 768, 135.09 ppi

Connectivity: HDMI, two USB 3.0 ports, Bluetooth 4.0, and Wifi.

Battery: I couldn't Google the MaH in the battery, but it lasts about 7.5 - 8 hours.

Ok, so after I wrote all that I just noticed Amazon has the specs right on it, so you can also look at that if you want.

Now, for the actual laptop on the outside. Even though it only has a pixel density of 135 ppi (pixels per inch, 135 is terrible), it still works and shows me what's on the screen. Unless I'm not looking at it. The speakers work great, and if you plug in headphones it automatically adjusts it so it doesn't scream in my ears. And when I take them out, it makes the speakers loud again, so I can still hear it from about a foot away. It's really thin and light, I can carry it with one hand under it while it's turned on easily. The battery life on this is amazing, it's one of my favorite parts of the C720. Lastly, the processor on the C720 is decent. It's fast enough for a laptop, and great for a $200 laptop.

In conclusion, this is a good laptop. If you like video games, a nice screen, or anything that you need to download, then I'm wondering why you would be reading this review in the first place. But if you like battery life, a good price, and a decent computer, then I think you should click the, "add to cart" button!

Since receiving the Acer Chromebook C720-2848 several days ago, I've come away with a brand new perspective on the Chrome operating system. Here's my take on it and why, if your needs aren't completely dependent on Windows, this may be just the right call for you.

First, what is a Chromebook? It is a laptop with its own system that relies on everything Google, and runs the operating system "Chrome OS".  Chrome OS does not allow for "programs" to be run in the manner that Windows or Mac does. It is almost fully browser-dependent (but not to the extreme that you can't use the computer without an internet connection). You run "programs" in the Chrome browser, and they run quickly and efficiently, with hardly any hesitation. Unlike that of Windows' program launching, Chrome OS is nearly immediate and glorious in its ability to do your bidding.

The first thing you will note about the system is that it boots in under 7 seconds so that you can come from a cold start to having logged-in and ready for work or play. I am used to having my Windows 7 installation tweaked for high performance, but the Chrome OS needs no help there.  A few things before I really get into it should be noted:

There is no firewall to configure; no need for virus protection; system is automatically updated without bother, and has an SSD (solid state drive for virtually noiseless computing), and can run up to 8 to 9 hours on one charge.  The OS requires no license validation and can be re-installed quickly if need be. Sounds intriguing? Stick around and hold on to your wig because this thing will flip it!

This particular model is the C720-2848, at $200, a revamping of the older C710.  The Intel Celeron Haswell architecture brain that runs it is quite faster than the prior model, C710's Celeron brain, and comes with either 2GB of DDR3 ram or, for more handling power, 4GB, for $50 more. It appears for most users that is over-kill, as most won't have more that 10 to 12 windows running at the same time. My model is capable of having several Youtube videos playing, and several other windows open, with no adverse hit in performance. Should you choose to try a Chromebook, don't pick the older model, regardless of sales discount inducement.

When you boot into your Chromebook you are met with a desktop, similar to a Windows PC, but there are no icons on the desktop. Instead, there is a sidebar where you chose which program you wish to use. You want to surf, you click the Chrome icon, and you are quickly sent off to the internet. There is also an apps icon that you click in order to see all of your applications that are available to you. These applications can be downloaded (downloaded here means: the shortcut to the application that will play in the Chrome browser) from the Chrome Store. You can build quite an impressive amount of useful apps for work or play and delete them (getting rid of the shortcut to the application) as you see fit. An example of a utility app is Screencastify, a screen video recorder that can record all you do with or without sound. You can also capture video with the webcam. Snagit, from Techsmith, is another useful app for screen recording or snapping shots of anything that you want on any page you go to.  Another useful application is Clearly, an app that rids pages of all extraneous litter, leaving only text so that you can read or save it.  There is a growing lineup of games that can be played via the browser as well, one of which is still popular, Angry Birds. You won't be able to play more demanding games, but this is not a gaming computer. As more and more users Skype now than ever before, Chromebook users are not as fortunate. But you can use Google Hangout for calls and video chatting. All sorts of utility apps and more are populating the Chrome Store, so this is just the beginning of what may turn out to be a most welcome and fast-growing app market for your Chromebook.

The Chromebook can not accept printers via usb (remember: you can't install programs), but you can wirelessly print via Google Cloud Print to your printer as long as you have a printer that is capable of cloud printing. Nearly all printers for just under $100 have this feature today.

Typing on the keyboard was an unexpected pleasure, as I have never been able to type comfortably with any laptop I've ever used. The touch pad is responsive and utilizes the familiar one finger mouse move, and two and three finger gestures, the latter being for scrolling back and forth through the open windows. You can plug in a usb or wireless mouse and keyboard, but you probably won't need to.

As for music play, the speakers for a low-cost computer as this sound great.  There's appreciable loudness with hardly any noticeable shrill at very 80% volume. The is some slight bass, not heavy and shouldn't be expected on this laptop.  The bluetooth works with newer versions and is backwards compatible with bluetooth 2.0 and up.

For light users of Microsoft Office, Google Docs takes over the job. It will read, write and edit the documents. Just don't expect it to be on par with its very expensive brotheren.

This model comes with 16 GB (there is a 32 GB SSD --Solid State Drive-- version available) of drive storage and can be supplemented with Google Drive cloud storage (free) for additional storage. You can also slip in an SD card up to 64 GB for .PDF files, documents of all extensions, movies, pictures and music.

As for entertainment, Youtube and Netflix is clear and never stutters. Watching movies one SD card on the matte-finish 11.5 " screen is better than expected for such a low priced laptop. No complaints here.

There's an HDMI out port and one USB 3.0 and one USB 2.0 port, headphone/mic input.

At just 2.7 lbs, this laptop is not cumbersome and stays very cool even after hours of play. I am writing this document on it and I feel quite comfortable doing it. I can't say that about any laptop I've used in the past. I've seen the best of laptops come my way for repair, and not once was I enthralled by the keyboard.  I love this keyboard!

When you are not connected to the internet, you can still enjoy your Chromebook to some extent.  You can still write documents, read and write email (for sending later), play one of many free games, read a book or just settle in for a good old movie.  It isn't as crippled as Microsoft's damning commercial makes it out to be, is it?

The question now, is: Is this for you? If you aren't a lover of Google's self-contained system and are really dependent on specialized programs, then you probably won't find much to like about it. But if you are all things Google and have no need for heavy, specialized programs like Photoshop, or intensive music production software, heavy 3-D gaming and the total Microsoft Office experience, welcome to the next thing in computing!

Here's a Top Tip for people who already own a Chromebook or are buying one.  This unit comes with 2GB of RAM which is fine, but if you open a lot of webpages or watch huge videos it might bog a little.  Chrome OS runs on Linux, and in Linux there's something called zRam.  zRam creates a RAM swap file on your hard drive, 1.5 times the size of your physical RAM.  Since the hard drive in the Chromebook is an SSD, data moves between RAM and that swapfile instantly.  Once you enable zRam, it will add a 3GB RAM swap file on your SSD, so now your 2GB RAM Chromebook effectively has 5GB of RAM, instantly and for free.  It is a persistent change- it stays there even after you reboot.

Here's how:

1.  Hit ctrl-alt-T, a browser window opens with a message about Crosh, the Chrome OS developer shell, followed by a command prompt ("crosh>")
2.  Type "swap enable" (no quotes) and hit enter.  Crosh confirms that you've created a swap file that will be active when you re-boot.
3.  Re-boot, and enjoy your free RAM upgrade.  w00t.

-there's no Delete key which I had gotten into the habit of using a lot when my old netbook's backspace key started becoming unreliable, instead there's "alt+backspace" and the power button is where the Delete key used to be on my netbook so I've almost put the computer into sleep mode a couple times

-when the fan does turn on, it tends to turn on for like one second, cool down enough to turn off, and repeat every two seconds for a while, but I'm pretty sure that's not terribly abnormal for a laptop. It's not loud, it's just annoying when it keeps turning on and off.

Things I am ambivalent towards and simply have to get used to:
-I have turned this thing on like once since I got it because it turns itself on/wakes itself up every time you open the lid if it possibly can. That includes the very first time you plug it in which startled me a little.
-there's not much available in terms of customization/options for stuff like when it sleeps/turns off the monitor, but there's not much I've felt the need to change in the first place

It is a shame that a nice machine is so limited by the castrated Chrome OS.

Now, there are plenty of warnings regarding the fact that a chromebook uses online apps.  I understood that.  However, there is 16 GB free on the hard drive, so I figured that there must be offline apps in the chrome store.  I live in a rural area where internet access is spotty in many places, so if I wanted to edit a text or image file, I would be able to do so.  I also thought I would be able to store and listen to some music.  Not a lot, obviously, but some to keep me occupied if I was in an area where there was no wifi.  I was also hoping for some light, offline games.

So I head over to the chrome store... and there isn't much.  The selection, even for online apps, is small.  When you install an online app, chrome simply puts a site-specific launcher in the menu.  The game section if the store is particularly heart-wrenching, because many of the games don't even work on light hardware such as this.  I knew something was suspicious when I saw apps that had complex, 3D graphics.  It's as if Chrome just puts links in the store without bothering to check if they even work.  Many games do not even exist anymore.  If you want games, you're stuck with cartoonish multiplayer games, such as you would find on Facebook.

This would not be a huge problem in and of itself... except, Android is so much more functional.  I have a generic Android device that I spent $30 for on black Friday.  It has many offline apps, a USB keyboard that makes it feel like a netbook, and battery life is even longer.  It is also more customizable as far as appearance goes.  With Chrome OS, all you can really do is change the background.

So, while this chromebook was cheap, I could have spent even less and gotten a much more functional device.  It's pretty sad.  I can't even use Tor on my chromebook, and with the recent scandals surrounding internet anonymity, I view this as a flaw.

Now, all this being said, there are so pro's to the way ChromeOS functions.  Since everything is in the cloud, if the OS is damaged in any way, the Chrome recovery tool will fix everything up in a no time, and all your data will be safe in the cloud.

My biggest feeling with ChromeOS... disappointment.  Google could have created a more traditional OS and swept Microsoft aside.  Linux is incredible and the open source community is vast, and many applications that compete with Microsoft apps already exist.

Instead, all I got was a netbook that runs the Chrome browser.  That is literally all ChromeOS is, a glorified browser.

It is possible to install Linux on a chromebook, but there are problems with the touchpad.  Furthermore, installing another OS entails entering developer mode, where a scary boot screen stating that the OS is damaged appears with every boot.  The screen advises you to press a certain key to repair the OS... which will wipe your entire Linux install.  With a single keystroke.  Not a big deal if you know what you are doing, but if some unsuspecting friend booted your machine and read the message, you can kiss your data goodbye.

If you do most of your stuff online, ChromeOS is fine, if you like paying more for less.  Otherwise, steer clear.

As an Open Source advocate I wanted to try a Chromebook. I liked the specs and feel of the C720. I ordered one for myself and use it often. I also ordered one for my nephew as a gift. I've tried using my smartphone and a couple of Android tablets as devices to surf the web on while watching TV, and none of them ever gave me an enjoyable experience:  while two of them actually had slightly higher resolution screens than this Chromebook, none of them were easy to navigate for me due to links being too small to easily click on and my strong preference for physical versus virtual keyboards.  So I wanted a small, light laptop that would allow me to surf the web while getting the benefits of a laptop vs tablet (touch type and precision pointer/click control).  This Chromebook fits all of my needs easily.  I get over 7 hours on a single charge (though unfortunately my battery level and charge-time indicators are somewhat inaccurate), and web pages load very quickly even on a 802.11-g router that's connected to slowish DSL.  I plugged a USB headset into this and was able to use it to do a Google video call in combination with the built-in 720p webcam with no driver install process or setup issues at all.  I use this at home, work, and the homes of family members, and it seamlessly transitions between wifi access points.  I did encounter one issue that only ever happened on an AT&T DSL connection where images and pages sometimes were timing out or not loading, seemingly due to DNS issues, as though the browser were giving up too quickly to resolve and/or load, but hard-setting DNS to always use Google's servers seems to have fixed that issue.  Which brings up a good point:  for those willing to use Google and do some tinkering, even without installing Linux there are lots of settings and tools you can use to get a bit more functionality and customization than what the standard ChromeOS interface provides.
Two issues worth mentioning:  any SD card will stick about half-way out of the card slot, which is unfortunate.  After extensive searching, it seems that there is no current micro-SD to full-size SD adapter that will fit completely within the slot, either.  The screen is also somewhat low-end:  while the resolution has not yet been a problem at all, the viewing angles and blue-haze common to low-end LCD panels are both very apparent here.  I sometimes find myself tilting the screen to odd angles in an attempt to mitigate the viewing-angle problem, but it's a minor inconvenience overall.  Watching 720p/HD streaming shows/movies is entirely possible thanks to the decent CPU/GPU, but the picture quality, especially in darkish scenes, will suffer on this screen.  Luckily, there is also a full-sized HDMI out port that you can use to connect to a better monitor or TV when available.

Regarding Chrome OS, there are very few things I do with a computer that it will not do:
1) Skype calls (I knew this going in, so it wasn't a surprise)
2) Various file syncing programs (Dropbox, JungleDisk, Box) that I use for different things. Of course, I can access my files online, but for business reasons I cannot move some of these to Google Drive.
3) A few specific, proprietary non-web applications that will run on Chrome OS (or Ubuntu or OSX for that matter). My workaround for this is Chrome Remote Desktop, whereby I can access my Windows machine perfectly from my Chromebook.

It has a battery life that easily lasts over 6 hours, and it also recharges incredibly fast.  Finally, it is much lighter and more portable than a laptop.  While it looks like the old "netbooks", this product is many times superior to those outdated, balky computers.  Amazingly, this product accomplishes all this magic for what I consider to be the best bang for the buck available in computers today ($200). In summary, I have a love/hate relationship with most computers, so far with this machine it's all love.

For the money, the Acer C720 (2GB) isn't just one of the best Chromebook on the market, it's one of the better cheap laptops on the market. For $199 at the time of my purchase, I could not be happier with what I got for my money. This 11.6" laptop is great on battery life, has stellar performance, and houses a sleek and portable form factor. Chrome OS is limited to some, but with a constant internet connection and a computer at home that you can remote desktop to (not entirely necessary), there isn't much you can't do with a Chromebook. The dual-core Intel Celeron (Haswell) CPU inside isn't power hungry, it doesn't put out much heat at all, and it powers Chrome OS like a boss. The C720 also carries 2GBs of RAM, which is plenty for most of what you'll be doing inside of Chrome. You won't have any stuttering or lag with multiple tabs open in Chrome, a video playing or music in the background while blogging on social media. At the time of this review I currently have 6 tabs open, including a livestream on Twitch.tv, and there is no lag whatsoever. Battery life is also fantastic. With social media, email, music, and word processing, you can expect anywhere from 7 - 9 hours with the C720, slightly less if constantly streaming video. I had a day where I unplugged the laptop at 7am, used it for notes and videos through school till around noon, then used it all day at work researching tech and playing videos; I ended the day at 10pm with around 49% battery, I then proceeded to use the laptop most of the next day at home before it finally dying around 3pm. So you can expect to get through a whole day with this Chromebook. Another additional benefit is USB 3.0. There is 1 on this laptop, as well as a single USB 2.0 port on the other side of the laptop. You also have full HDMI out for running an extra HDMI enabled monitor/tv. This greatly improves functionality if you enjoy having multiple displays. It's lightweight, portable, looks great and the build quality is superb for a sub $200 laptop, but there are a couple downsides. The original carried a full-size SD card slot (when inserted, the card would be flush with the laptop, making portable storage easy), the C720 lacks this, and only carries a half-depth SD card slot, minor downside. Also, there are no function keys as well as no caps lock key, like the original. I would like to be able to ALT-F4 out of Chrome, instead I have to CTRL-W to close each tab/window individually. The screen is 11.6" and has a resolution of 1333x768, which is just fine for a 11" laptop. Viewing angles and color reproduction wasn't the best, but you won't have many complaints sitting in front of the laptop for a few hours. Another downfall out of the box was the keyboard, the keys were shallow but well spaced. After a couple days of use I got completely used to this and am now typing this review on the C720 at 60+ WPM.

To conclude, if you're on a budget looking for a laptop, already live inside of Google's ecosystem or are okay with living in the cloud (no classic Windows applications/limited storage), then this laptop will serve you well. The C720 has the best battery life for a Chromebook on the market, other than Dell's Chromebook 11 ($100 more than the C720 at the time of this review),which only carries a couple hours of battery life over the Acer here. Other than that, you won't find better performance, battery life and a simple, utilitarian design in any other sub $200 laptop.

Pros:
Performance
Battery life
Portability
Loud speakers
Good trackpad with easy-to-use gestures

Cons:
Screen viewing angles and colors
Lack of caps lock key and F4 key. (Search key can be swapped with Caps lock in settings)
Keys are a bit shallow and hard to use at first

I have a Roku and Chromecast, I mess around with XBMC, and I try to stretch all my tech dollars.  I wanted a simple, lightweight, mobile device with a keyboard--something handy for surfing on the couch, stashing it away in a backpack and riding the bike to my local coffee shop for some writing.  The other reviews and numerous Youtubes on this unit are consistently very good.  What finally snagged me was the XP laptop trade-in deal offered by a local retailer and suggested by an article on CNET, which enabled me to bring this home at half-price.

Playing with it for a night and a morning (normal Chrome apps, Outlook.com (just to see if I could still use Microsoft stuff), and Chrome Desktop), I'm convinced of a couple of things:
-$200 is totally the sweet spot for Chromebooks.  This thing can do a lot and does it very fast, but it can't do everything.  Everyone should know that by now.  That's not a "con" for me.  I know this going in.  But at this price, what it does is incredible.
-Waiting for the new Samsung Series means saving up another $100-200.  The new hardware looks intriguing (I'm generally a Samsung fan) and I bet it's very nice, but at $349-399 for the new units I'm starting to think Windows (the Asus Transformer Book T100, for example).  By the way, Windows 8's schizo Desktop/Metro is starting to grow on me.
-$1100 for the Macbook Air was a goal until I returned to my profile and use case.  If I want a beautiful piece of hardware that I'll try to use for the next five years without much change, then maybe this is it.  But I'm also not sure I want to stash it in my backpack and crash the bike or bump it around.  I'd baby it too much.

So thanks to the XP trade in, some passion from Puppylinuxworld on youtube, and reflection on my use, I took the plunge.  It's great!
