Oh, and the tiny amount of storage really hasn't been an issue for me. I keep most of my long-term need-to-keep documents on my main laptop. Plus you've got some space on google drive.

Summary: Great as a partner to your main computing device, but don't expect it to replace that. This isn't the most high-tech, fancy piece of machinery you'll ever interact with, but that's not really the point. I love it for what it is and isn't. It treats me well. We are happy together.
I didn't know what to think about Chromebooks at first, but after having one for a while, I have to admit that it's pretty neat!

Recently sold an Asus Transformer with keyboard that was used for a couple of years and took the proceeds to purchase this via the Acer store as a refurb - EXCELLENT purchase!  The whole computing experience is even better than the Android tablet.  Don't get me wrong - Android on my phone is wonderful but when it comes to a larger device, where I tend to do/expect a little more, this Chromebook more than surpasses expectations.

Chromebooks offer a computing experience, in my opinion, that closely mirror what one is already familiar with in a traditional PC environment - operation of the hardware, software functionality and overall familiarity make for a small learning curve.  I really also like that you can work offline with it - to an extent.  I've used it only once offline and that was to continue working on a document - it was a success.

The Acer C720 is overall well designed.  It is thin, lightweight and they keyboard is comfortable to use - especially those of us who are old-school typists :) .  The screen is fine enough - this is at basic hardware and thus you have to expect some areas to be cost cutting.  However, the whole package makes for a great experience.

Google is only going to improve the Chrome OS and these devices are going to continue reaping the benefits of those improvements.  Matched to Acer's hardware design and low-cost, they have a hit.  I can see why Chromebooks are picking up in popularity - lightweight, fast, easy to use and reasonable price now brings computing closer to what people as me want.  (I work in IT and believe me, LOVE, LOVE, LOVE the simplicity of this thing - I get sooooooo tired of babysitting technology, fixing its many issues at times.)

I'm extremely pleased and look forward to using this Chromebook for the next several years.

Honestly I wasn't expecting much when I bought this. But it simply blew my expectations out of the water! It's fast, compact, and does exactly what I need it to. While it does suck to not have Skype and such, all of its apps make it very easy to use. Its battery life is just amazing, too. I highly recommend it to anyone who just needs something more than a phone to access the internet and have fun with on the go!

I'm typing this up on my Chromebook. It is very light weight and compact, so it's perfect for travel or taking to school. It's fast, thought it doesn't have much room for software. Documents can be made through Google docs and stored on cloud, so it's not a huge issue. It's kind of a bare-bones model and if that is all you need, then this is a good computer to use.

To start with this is a way better computer than any laptop including MAC if you are using it for internet purpose( Stream videos or youtube or just browse net)  Literally starts in 5 secs and battery 10 hours ....around 7 with video streaming!

It has all the wonderful google apps for documents etc if i need

Best part is i am using it for more than a month now and not a single time i had to restart... I watch tons of Amazon videos as i am prime member not a single time anything hanged

Another good thing to note is it does not heat up at all! no fan noise ....i have become a non paid salesman of this product!

Excellent OS google!

This is such a neat and cute computer for the price. It is very small! I would only recommend this laptop for children who might be inexperienced with computers and might damage it, or travelers. If you plan on using programs like Microsoft Office this computer can never be a full replacement. For the price though there's no way this computer could receive less than 5 stars.

I needed a high speed portable computer with a HDMI port to be able to watch programs on my television.
This filled that need. I also love being online within seconds of flipping it open. So much better that a tablet I got two years ago.

Simple to use and understand, this machine has converted me to using the cloud. The battery life is awesome. While not perfect, the speakers are adequate for most of my listening needs, although I do use headphones sometimes. Very quick boot-up. A few items I have downloaded to the hard drive have handled well.

Not good as far i can figure out for creating/storing documents or uploading video to youtube or sharing photos via email, you have to try and find then download apps to do the most basic things.
I bought this for my wife she hates it because of the above, she gives it one star rating.
If you want out the box internet surfing and basic email use then this will be ideal for you, but if you want more then i would put your $200 towards a decent laptop and save yourself hours of frustration searching for illusive apps.
Over all as a internet surfing note book its great value i love its size and speed for surfing the net although i was expecting it to be a small laptop as it is listed under computers and it looks like a laptop so i expected a laptop, my mistake i guess but an easy mistake to make if your not bang up to date techno savy.
So my conclusion its a great note book but its not a laptop.

I used to use my Windows XPS laptop which I bought in 2008. Don't get me wrong it worked very good for me however once I started using Chromebook its out of the world. It does most everything I need a laptop to do. When I go home from work I usually am on browser or Netflix. They both work excellent on Chromebook. I like free 100 GB for 2 year option. It acts like my hard drive now. I automatically save everything to cloud which I can access from anywhere. One thing I would recommend to have a windows laptop handy. The reason: Chromebook is great but still it has its limitations like installing third party software. So for now have a windows laptop handy or accessible to you. Let me know if you have any questions. Peace.
Instant start, great apps, charges quickly. Used mainly for web surfing.  . Enjoy it more then my tablet for my needs. Plus do not have to use IE which is much slower.

Was curious about what all the fuss was with chromeOS and the Acer C720 chromebook so I bought one. Unbelievably fast. The C720 is the best notebook I have tried and I have tried several and the battery is fantastic, charge it overnight and use the machine all day. Almost all the apps/programs you will ever need are pre-installed and I added three or four additional programs very, very easily from the playstore. ChromeOS works flawlessly and fast. Did I mention that this is a great system combination?
So why did I give it to my daughter? Because I love to tinker with LinuxOS and different distros and you can't do that with ChromeOS. That is this Systems strength and why it is such a great System but I like to tinker with systems. Unfortunately I break a lot of toys but still I like to tinker.

Very good for just around the house web browsing, some work-related tasks, and basic life activities tasks getting things organized.  Handy to have for quick reference searches and easier to use for such things than, say, a device like an iPhone.  Have yet to use the little machine for everything it can do.  Excellent battery life.  Automatic updates for the system and security are great, too.  Hardly disappointed.  I like it a lot.

I can't believe all the glowing reviews this notebook is getting. Maybe if all you use your machine for is checking your e-mail and the weather you'll be happy, but for anything slightly beyond Internet 101, you're going to be frustrated.

The problem? The damn Operating System...Google Chrome! What's wrong with Google Chrome? It's so bare-boned, so restrictive it what it allows you to do, I might ask "What's right with it?". Try playing a game on it that requires Java.....ain't gonna happen', Cap'n, because Google Chrome doesn't work with Java! Try installing your favorite browser, say, Mozilla Firefox and watch absolutely nothing happen.because you're locked into using the prepackaged browser Google Chrome.

I grabbed this notebook off the shelf of a local Walmart because we've had so much good luck with Acers in the past, it was small enough for travel, and it was cheap. An hour later I was taking it back and exchanging it for an Acer with a real Operating System, not this silly thing called Google Chrome. What exactly is the point of it?
I really love this chromebook.  It is really fast and is perfect for my needs.  I do wish that the screen was a little better, but you get what you pay for.

I gave you guys a couple of hundred bucks. A couple of days later I received my chromebook. Chromebooks are promoted as easypeasy, right? You turn them on and there you go!~ Did you know at least SOME chromebooks, say, this one, come with ZERO instructions? First you charge them, open the screen, choose your wireless server and instantly see, in red letters, "BAD PASSPHRASE". WHAT?!?! Slow forward a month- NO one in the US or Bangladesh can or will tell you what bad passphrase is or has a good passphrase they will share with you, the customer. Though, of course, I will rate the wear and tear on the item as at least a 5+!  L  OL  L  OL!

I picked up one of these refurbished for $150 and I'm amazed. After using it exclusively for a week (in the place of an $1800 Macbook Pro), I have yet to run into a reason I couldn't use this little guy exclusively. Once I found a good online LaTeX editor and got all my code running in SAGE, I was good to go. After a little time tweaking my Chrome settings and extensions, the experience was as smooth as any of my Mac/Linux machines. Sure the hardware isn't high end - the screen is just adequate and the touchpad is clacky and a little small - but none of it gets in the way and it's tremendous for the money. Plus the light weight and fantastic battery life make this machine better than most expensive laptops at their main job - true, leave-the-charger-at-home portability. These days you can do anything in a browser. I'm definitely recommending these to most of my friends.

The computer is perfect for my work purposes. I just wish it was more compatible with my iPod, that I didn't have to buy a printer with google print abilities, and that it had the apps I currently use available.

I love this cheap machine so much that I have bought 2 of these in my family, and have used one for about 6 months now.

Pros:
- lightweight, durable (even though keyboard flexes a bit, its still nice) , battery life is awesome, browsing is fast n snappy
and a lot others which I won't bother posting.

Cons:
- Over Bluetooth , there is a huge audio lag. My Bose soundlink mini works perfectly with my other laptops, tablets,phones with no lag. I don't know if its Acer's issue or chrome OS's
- screen is bit dim and low quality ( well 200$, so not really expecting much)

Overall: It still serves excellently for over 70-90% use cases of most folk, so a great buy for low price.
I prefer this over my tablet or phone any time.

I had an older desktop that was every so slow trying to load web content as the old graphic card struggled so....  Well after much thought I knew I needed to "upgrade" in order to continue to enjoy my Gmail and other internet activities. Well the $199 price point is attractive and the thought of a secure chrome/cloud content was also a nice thought. Well, I bought this chromebook and have been so happy. Easy to use right out of the box, and very fast in loading and navigating the web. I am absolutely satisfied, doing all I desire.

I'm giving this Laptop a 5 star review because the C720 laptop I eventually ended up with is awesome.  The C720 laptop I BOUGHT through Amazon however was not.  I already left a 1 star review for the seller of my original Refurbished C720 laptop, and it didn't seem right giving the laptop itself a bad review when it was the sellers fault.
Long story short, it was defective, the warranty service sent it back to still defective, so I returned it in less than a month after I bought it.  As soon as I received the confirmation from the seller for the return, I went to BestBuy and bought the exact same laptop.

My C720 is going strong, I've got a 32gb USB 3.0 micro flash drive running Ubuntu for all the apps I can't run in Chrome.

I have to say that this laptop fits perfectly for what I want. Quick, fast, reliable, Google OS updates every 6 weeks, don't need a firewall or virus protection! It's that simple. Wish the keyboard would light up, hard to see at times. All laptops at this price-point are the same though

My hubby is not exactly a computer genius but he has learned to like cruising the net since he has been home recovering from a work-related injury. He can sit on the couch, prop up his leg and watch TV while checking out the web. He loves it and I am happy my laptop is free again so I can do my work! This chromebook is prefect for my hubby and will be great to take along while traveling. It will NOT take the place of a laptop if you need to store files and it will not burn CDs or play DVDs.

my neighbor girl will graduate this year, heading on to college, so we got her this and gave it to her early. she loves it and is glad we let her have it now as she needed it for studies and her grades have improved since receiving it. thank you for such good prices that allowed us to fit this into our budget.

I am very happy with this purchase.  I bought it because my 2008 Macbook Pro stopped working.  The Apple store worker told me that it would cost $500 to replace a part.  I realized I didn't really need or use that laptop to it's full potential.  So I decided to purchase this Chromebook to "tide me over" until I made a new laptop purchase. But this has suited me wonderfully so far.  I use this as my entertainment computer. I am able to check emails, websurf, stream movies, etc.  I also love that it is so light and portable. I can take it everywhere. The battery life is long. And at such a low price, I don't feel bad about the possibility of losing or breaking it. In that way it contributes to less stress for me- like one less thing to worry about.

Does what I need it to, check email, browse the web.  I am a heavy Google user, and this is just perfect.  My previous pc laptop was about 8 years old, and I didn't realize just how slow it was, booting up and running programs.  This Acer C720 is very fast, waking from sleep, booting and running with various tabs open.  I actually scored and got one of the mfg refurbished devices from Acer.  I was also able to active the 100GB Google storage, apparently not activated by the previous user, or possibly refreshed during the refurb?  Not sure.  Anyhow, this device arrived super fast, ordered on Monday, received on Tuesday.  Sadly, it appears that some of the refurbs are for sale back up here on Amazon, at a higher price.  I plan to get one for my wife, still an amazing deal at only $199 brand new.  I also use a Chromecast at home, and though I have not had time yet to try it out from the Chromebook, I look forward to using this feature.  Very pleased with this purchase.

99% of my work is spent on Gmail and Google Docs. While I'm doing that I listen to music on Spotify.
This little machine does all this fantastically.
Very cheap, very easy to use.
It does stream video just fine (netflix, youtube, hbogo, nba league pass, tnt live, etc).
Very easy to throw in my backpack and head to a coffee shop.
If it gets lost or stolen, not a big deal.
I still have a MBPro to do some more heavy duty computing, but I'm glad I don't have to carry it everywhere.
Highly recommended.
Easy and simple.  I should have done this a while ago.  You continue to read the reviews and it just makes you nuts.  Just order it, try it, you'll love it.

This item was purchased for the price and the reviews.  Saw many positive reviews for this item and the price was in our price range.  Only been using this laptop for a few weeks and so far me and my brother have no complaints or problems (purchased 2).  Its light and compact and fits our needs.  Would recommend to others.

I chose this chromebook after weeks of research and the price wasn't bad either. I'm doing a home study course on hear and everything works great and playing some games is really good w/high res screen. I would recommend this big little computer to any one either as a starter or as your everyday computer. The battery last just as long as stated in the description which is awsome.

I recently had a knee replacement that kept me at home and away from sitting at a desk. The Acer C700 was essential in allowing me to keep up with e-mail and various other computer work that I couldn't do at a desk. I love the quick boot and shutdown plus battery life is excellent. Now that I'm back at my desk I'm not using the laptop as much but it continues to hold its charge when not being used. I plan to use this when I am able to travel again. I'm also sharing it with my wife around the house. We'll be tossing my older, heavy Windows laptop (it was 10 years old anyway). I might add that I bought the Acer 720 model with 4 GB RAM. I really haven't needed that much RAM. 2 GB would have been fine.

It is a great product for getting basic internet tasks done, including surfing, email, media, etc. I do not have any complaints about it except that it did not work well with my router and I had to buy a separate router just for this device.

I love having a keyboard and the quick access to the web. This Chromebook is easy to use and I like the fact that it comes with antivirus. Only takes minutes reboot. I only use this for web browsing and social media.

I purchased this Chromebook for my very young 73 year old Jewish mother-in-law, who is not very tech savvy, but wanted email and to be able to get onto Facebook in order to keep in touch with friends and family!

My father-in-law recently died, and it was time to get rid of the Dell Inspiron 1100 that we purchased for him when he retired in 2003.  It was infected with a virus, still worked but was beyond its service life, and after three days of wiping the hard drive, reloading and updating XP-pro, downloading all of the drivers from Dell, as soon as I went on Chrome, it immediately got infected again!

Oh well, time to bite the bullet, be a mensch and buy her a new one.

When I received the Chrome, it came charged, (I plugged it in anyway), and as soon as I turned it on, less than 7 seconds from pressing the power button, it was completely on, ready to work.  WOW! what a difference, not having to wait for Windows to go through its stupid long time startup!!!!

This Chromebook is lightning fast, super easy to access any wireless network, and perfect for a Senior (and possibly anyone else) that doesn't need to load CD's or DVD's, or do a lot of computing.

I only had about an hour to play with it, load her gmail, establish a Facebook account for her, and to play with a new toy, but ultimately I was super impressed with this Acer and would highly suggest it.

My only regret so far, is where is the DEL key.  I think they may have eliminated it.  I use that key quite frequently and have other devices that are Apples that also do not have it!

Like I said, I really only played with it for about an hour, and I am not one to read operating manuals, but it seems perfect to do what it is designed to do.  I truly believe this is the product of the future as I thing most computing is going to be done from the cloud anyway.
Received when promised, Works for what I need. Thank you very much, I am looking forward to using my Chromebook.
My son can do everything he needs to on this laptop...its amazing and a great price!  He love to use it!

Does exactly what I would want a netbook to do.  I've heard about a lot of people who buy this and are disappointed having realized after the fact that the computer isn't running Windows (or Mac OS).

This cheap little "disposable" computer will do what 99% of computer users use a computer to do 90% of the time (thats a mouthful).  That is: "browse" the web, manage our inbox and spam, and use some form of social networking to let people know that I accidentally picked out two different pairs of socks (what a numbskull).  The best part about the whole thing is that it is linux based; though few will understand the value in that!

If grandma or grandpa need a computer to break into the social network scene, this is it.  If little Timmy needs a computer to do his homework, this is it.  If I want to run my business by utilizing various web based softwares including Google Apps for Business, this is an excellent option for when I'm on the road (tested, true).

When you're buying a MacBook as a status symbol, or a Dell out of ignorance, STOP; and consider a Chromebook (you won't regret it).

The only complaint is if you need to download a program that doesn't have an app associated with it I am out of luck. Other than that it is great. Love the track pad, the keyboard, and how quick it responds.

Chrome book is unlike anything I have ever used before. I still can not get my printer connected to it nor can I find a way to talk to someone about it. I have trouble logging in to some accounts using Chrome Book w/Google Chrome and have to log in to those accounts with my old computer. I like the speed, but I can not figure out how to effectively operate this type of computer. It shouldn't be this difficult to figure it out. Help center doesn't help me at all since I have no clue what they are talking about. I also can not get the usb drive to work. I get very frustrated using this machine. It's great for email's but that's it! I would not recommend this to anyone who does not understand anything past Windows Vista. In fact, I do not know if this is even windows at all. If it is, it doesn't tell you if it's windows 7 or 8. I don't think it's either. I am puzzled.............

We've had some intermittent issues with the touchpad not working. It doesn't seem to matter if it is plugged into the wall outlet (electrical interference) or not. The WiFi antenna isn't as strong as my ThinkPad from the same location. Otherwise, it works great and serves it's purpose well.

This computer is perfect for everyday use. Long battery life, very smooth OS, light, and thin. I wanted something to replace my old netbook. I haven't run into anything where I wished I was using a Mac or PC. For the price this can't be beat.

This was intentionally for my 11 yr old son for school, but with our computer giving us problems my wife and I have loved this little chromebook and thinking about getting another for our personal use and business she has, we still haven't gotten a printer, but probably will in the near future, highly recommended!!!

We needed a faster computer for Facebook, online videos, etc. and couldn't afford a full fledged laptop, so after reading some reviews of the Chromebook, I realized that it would do everything we wanted to do online and at a very low cost. You just have to buy into the concept that it uses the online Google software and applications for spreadsheets, word processing, etc.; there is no actual hard drive, just a small 2 gig storage drive that works similar to a built-in usb flash drive, and they give you some extra space on Google Drive free for a couple of years. You can also save files to USB flash drives using the usb ports, but you have to download to the built-in drive first and then cut and paste to the flash drive. There is no DVD player or burner. You can't install on-board software; but we use it mainly for web browsing, You Tube videos, Facebook, etc., so we are very happy with our Acer Chromebook, especially for the low price we paid; and would definitely recommend it to a friend. It apparently has a very fast processor and can stream high definition videos even with multiple windows open. It has a large high definition screen - the picture quality is excellent and it is very thin and lightweight, and the sound quality is amazingly good from the small built-in speakers.  It also has a built-in web cam which is surprisingly good quality. You can't use Skype, but you can use Google Hangouts which is similar to Skype.  The only problem we have had is that it often has trouble finding our home wi-fi network and I have to reset my router every now and then and restart the Chromebook to clear up the problem; but I think the problem is being caused by my antique router which I need to replace. As an experiment, I took the Chromebook to several bookstores, coffee shops, McDonald's etc. to test it and it jumped right onto the wi-fi networks every time - it is only at home that I have the connection problems, so I think the Chromebook is fine as long as you have a good strong wireless router. All in all - a very good value and a good product for wireless web browsing.

Okay, it is a chromebook. aren't all chromebooks pretty much the same? The difference, today after a week of stuff breaking, my daughter dumped a drink in this thing, I unplugged it, shook it off, and it works! Thank Gee Golly Sugary Chocolate Marbles for great miracles! Also, I like it. Thanks for a good product. This review has been edited to meet Amazon guidlines.

Wow. Bought a few of these (one for me and one for the wife). For less than $400, these two Chromebooks do just about everything we need them to. Only have one Windows desktop PC in the house now for storage and photo editing. For portable use, there is very little reason to NOT get a Chromebook since they are perfect for laptop-type usage. Even my daughter has our older C710 in her room hooked via HDMI to a 32" TV and wireless Logitech keyboard/mouse so she can watch her shows and browse/research. The mouse and keyboard was plug and play. Literally took 10 seconds. Unreal compared to Windows. So, we're almost exclusively a Chromebook family now. We have a few HP wireless printers and these Chromebooks print via Google Cloud Print to them flawlessly. Nice!

Father-in-law replaced his aging desktop PC with Windows XP to the larger Toshiba Chromebook that's $279 but has a larger screen. The simplicity and speed blows him away. And, no more hours spent doing technical support, waiting on mounds of updates to process all on a Windows install that's not really needed. I would surmise almost everything most home computer users need can be done in a browser and simple file system. That's a Chromebook...

It's pretty amazing that I can get a Nexus 5 and two fast and long-lasting Chromebooks for almost exactly the same price as an iPhone 5S with 32GB of RAM. So, that's what I've done :-)

I love this little computer. I originally got this chromebook after my macbook pro died, and it has since taken care of 95% of my computing needs. The keyboard feels great and the thing is silly light. The screen and trackpad both work very well but show some signs of a $200 small laptop. Nothing to worry about in my opinion.

 I bought it along with a larger solid state drive and then installed ubuntu on it with crouton. The whole process was pretty approachable and greatly expanded what one can do with the computer. I would recommend this computer to just about anyone who isn't doing serious photo/video/audio editing or gaming. I've also had trouble running a virtual machine on it, so people who rely on one should be wary.

Most people, myself included don't need the heavy duty supercomputers that pass as a laptop nowadays for home usage. So why pay more than $200 for one.

My 5-year-old Window-based netbook computer was too slow to run latest web browser. So, I was looking for replacement. But I didn't want to spent too much money for a full-blown notebook, as my main purpose was web surfing and email checking. So, my choice would be either tablet, or chromebook. I tried the 7 inch and 8 inch tablet and I was not happy with the small screen real estate as I didn't want to hurt my vision with small fonts. So, I gave it a try on chromebook.

I was surprised that such an inexpensive device could do so much. The whole setup took about 2 to 3 minutes only. After having it for couple of days, it became my favorite machine just because it was so simple, light and super fast start-up with the solid-state drive. Better yet, I never need to worry about virsus or malware. And the battery life was great...8 to 9 hours run on my tests. Some people complained about the keyboard. Frankly, I didn't feel anything wrong with the keyboard.

However, the display was a little bit dim for my taste. So, I usually brought up the brightness. This was done easily with the brightness adjustment keys on the keyboard. Not a big deal.

I bought the Acer Chromebook from local *C*O*S*T*C*O store because it had a very generous 90-day return policy. Before the end of the 90-day trial period, I bought one more for my daughter for doing homework at after-school center. It's cheap enough so I won't feel too bad if it is damaged.

Up to now, I have owned the Acer Chromebook for more than half year and it's used on daily basis. I am very happy with it, especially with its low price and good features. I would definitely recommend Chromebook to my friends.

I find it amazing that such an inexpensive device can do so much. After having it a week, it became my favorite machine just because it is so simple and light. After using it, you come to question why we need such big computing power, huge hard discs and RAM just to run a traditional OS when it comes to supporting the use cases for about 90% of what you use a PC to do. Whats even better, the Chromebook is pretty much ready to go out of the box, with an already pretty rich supply of online an offline apps don't cost you anything extra
this computer took all of 2 minutes to set up and go..it's extremely light weight and has a great picture.

I wanted a small backup laptop for web surfing, that I would keep in my living room at all times. Based on the low cost and high reviews this model got I decided to check it out.

First the bad: The keyboard is not great...frankly it just feels cheap. Its not terrible, but its not a pleasure to use. The display is disappointing too. Colors seemed washed out and the display seems kinda dim.

Now the good things: Its light, runs cool, really does get around 8 hours of battery life, fast browsing. super fast startup with the SSD. Also you don't have to worry about viruses or malware with the chrome os.

Im happy I purchased this computer,. I'm a firm believer that you get what you pay for. Acer scarified build quality for better internal components. For $200 I'd consider this a great bargain, you get a very capable computer for online functions.
I had the samsung chromebook that i broke by accident but i bought this one and omg im in love it way better and its 50 bucks cheaper buy buy buy

Wife surfs the 'net for various educational articles, and reads her email.  Definitely not a power user.  The clean interface of the Chromebook plus the VERY quick boot time, and automatic updates made her much more comfortable with working online (compared to her old Windows laptop).

Decent construction/durability.  Clear screen.  Quick response.  WiFi.  USB ports for additional storage devices, if needed.
Definitely a good purchase for us!

I love this computer! I have been working in technology for over 20 years and traditional computers are great for corporate work. For my personal use, I am far less needy. Even with my technology background, in my home I only need the internet for my email, banking, browsing, and creating the occasional document. A few years ago, I drank the Google Kool Aid and most of my world is tied up with them. This makes this the perfect computer for me. Upon unboxing it, I was up and running in about a minute. Everything I do with my traditional Windows computer is done on this small, light, powerful machine.

I was forever updating and cleaning my Windows machine. I work with troubled computers all day long. I did not want to come home to deal with my own. This little beast has cured me of that pain. I boot it up and it just works. No waiting, no updating, no pop-ups. It is truly headache free.

There are three small inconveniences for me. First, I have a NAS. If you don't know what that is, you won't care. It has a web interface, but it is far easier to manage the files by connecting to it via the Windows file system. This has been easily addressed by keeping my traditional Windows laptop booted up and underneath the bed in my guest bedroom. I can easily control it from the Chromebook via Google Remote Desktop. That allows me to do file cleanups on my NAS when necessary. I am hopeful that someday either Google or a third party will find a way for me to connect to the NAS without making too many changes to my Chromebook. For now, I am just fine.

The other two issues have to do with my networked multi-function laser printer. I got an awesome deal on an older model Brother laser printer last year and I have no need or desire to replace it right now. If I were so inclined, I would invest in a newer model that is Google Cloud Print ready. Until then, my Windows machine is up and running for my NAS anyway, I don't mind that I also have to keep it running for Cloud Print. That is the easy part. Then there is scanning. I do a lot of scanning. The only way I was able to make that work is to use ScanWorks CloudScan. It works wonderfully, but again, you need to have the Windows computer running.

I am all in with Chrome OS and will soon get a Chromebox to replace my bloated, sluggish Windows desktop.  I have found that there is literally nothing that I personally want or need to do on a computer that cannot now be down in the cloud. I have used Windows programs for years for amateur photo, film and sound editing but now there are terrific online alternatives (for the most part free) for all those things--for example, Pixlr Editor, WeVideo and AudioSauna, respectively.  There are online programs for business needs, file conversion and of course Google's office suite, with its new integration with third-party add-ons, has all the functionality that 95% of users could need.

If you want to find any online alternative to your local software just Google what you want to do followed by "online"  and chances are you'll find various options. But the best part is that the future is even brighter with the functionality of the OS constantly growing.  Rather than having a machine that slows down and demands more troubleshooting with time,  you have one that is getting better with each background update.

There are some people who will need one of the traditional OSes for a while longer--certain professionals and gamers--but for the vast majority of users who are willing to try alternatives to their legacy programs,  the benefits of Chrome OS--speed, security, lack of frustrating technical problems--is well worth the switch.

This laptop is simplicity and elegance for $200.  I was deciding between this and another Windows netbook and decided to go the Chromebook route and was not at all disappointed.

I recently bought the Asus T100 Windows convertible, which is a good machine when it works, but you have to deal with the clunkiness of Windows 8, a tediously slow charge time, wonky WiFi and a glossy screen.  The trackpad is noisy and ineffectual.  Plus, it cost me $350.  I still use it for Windows apps, but my new go-to is the C720.

The C720 just works.  You open it up, it boots in a few seconds, you're good to go.  It's light and sturdy and it does most of the things I need it to do.  The fan is barely audible and the battery life is excellent (and it charges quickly).  The keyboard isn't rock solid, but I can type quickly on it and the trackpad is extremely usable.  I'm starting to get the hang of Google Apps and I'm able to do a lot of work on my Google Drive (which is synced to my desktop).  Not all my work, but enough.

That said, sometimes the computer hiccups with processor-intensive tasks, but not annoyingly so.  The screen is not very good - it has an anti-reflective coating, but it's dim and muddy and the viewing angles are lousy.  The speakers are loud-ish at times, but I hate that they're under the computer where they're easily muffled.  The bezel is so wide, they might as well have put the speakers there.  I still use external speakers or headphones so it's not a deal breaker.  Most annoyingly, the SD card slot is shallow so you can't just keep an SD card in there when you're on the go; it juts out an inch.

In the grand scheme of things, for $200, I will endure a poorly designed SD slot and a mediocre screen.  Battery life and usability make this machine a no-brainer.  It's not for everyone but if you need a supplemental portable or want to give your grandparents a simple way to get connected, this is it.

Perhaps the best moment was when I was showing it to a friend, bragging about its portability and solid state innards.  He said while admiring it, "Oh, yeah.  I just got one, too.  A Mac Book Air."  For what he paid, I could have bought five Chromebooks.

I want to give 5 stars, but for now I cannot.  I purchased the C720 on 2/8/14 and within the first 48 hours I experienced a few "crashes."  I chalked them up as crashes and within the first week focused on finding a bad Chrome extension.  I eventually disabled all extensions but the issue still persisted.  About once a day I would experience a "crash."

The next step was to contact a Chrome Ninja who did some troubleshooting with me and eventually had me do a powerwash.  After trying this and sending some system data they indicated my Chromebook had been put in developer mode and that they could not help me.  This was interesting because a) it was a new Chromebook and b) while I know what developer mode is I certainly did not perform the steps at any time to enter into developer mode.  After explaining this to the Chrome Ninja he reviewed the information I sent again and said the Chromebook was no longer in developer mode but had been put in dev mode at some point in the past.  Given that, he said the only way for him to continue to assist was for me to do a full recovery of the machine.  No big deal, I made my USB recovery disk and completed the task and started over.

After performing the recovery, the machine was still randomly "crashing" 1-2 times per day.  After the Chrome Ninja reviewed the latest system info he replied back and said I have a power issue and that I'd need to contact Acer for support/repair.  What I ignorantly wasn't realizing is that the Chromebook wasn't necessarily crashing, it was completely shutting down.  I should have realized that given that I had to press the power button each time it happened for the Chromebook to boot back up, but I just wasn't putting it together I guess since this is my first Chromebook.

Now that I realized what was happening (thank you Chrome Ninja), I contacted Acer for repair since I had unfortunately purchased the Chromebook from Best Buy and I was past my 14 day return window.  At first, Acer wanted me to pay for shipping to their facility in Texas.  While I was annoyed they would even think I would pay for shipping (I told them the Chromebook was brand new and less than 30 days old) it was admittedly not that hard to get them to pay for the shipping.  I simply asked the Acer support representative and it took him about 5 minutes to confirm a free shipping label would be approved.  After a brief hold, he came back and said he was emailing me a shipping label.

So, that's pretty much where I stand.  I have shipped my brand new Chromebook that I've used maybe a dozen times off to Acer for repair.  While I consider myself an understanding person, I'm quite disappointed that I'm now without my device for a period of time.  I can only hope that they actually repair it correctly and that the issue does not occur again.  Given the random nature of the issue, I'm skeptical at best.  I am hopeful though given the fact that there are so many positive reviews for this device I have to be an anomaly.

I will update my review and rating once I get the device back from Acer.  If anyone else experiences a new machine that just randomly shuts down, don't wait until the return period is over... just swap it out for a new one immediately!

UPDATE: 4/15/2014
-----------------
My Chromebook has been in repair with Acer twice now.  The first time, regarding the power issue above, they simply "Reloaded OS" and sent it back.  I had told them, more than once, that I had already done that and it didn't help.  After receiving the Chromebook back in late March, I began to experience the same issue of the Chromebook just randomly powering off on the very day that I received it back from repair.  So, I immediately called Acer support and they immediately, without trouble, sent me a shipping label (again) to send it back for repair (again).  After just 1 day of having the Chromebook back in my possession, I turned around and shipped it off again.

I received the Chromebook back today, 4/15, with a note reading, "Unable to replicate symptoms of the unit shutting down.  Unit remained powered on while streaming videos from youtube for more than 24 hours.  No trouble found."  Fair enough, but at this point I'm just waiting for the issue to happen again, at which time I will send it in... again.  Luckily, Google has been very helpful and they are helping me figure out what the issue is.  I just have to wait for it to happen again and they're going to analyze the data I send them from a feedback report.

I'm trying to remain patient as I know my issue is difficult to replicate and is very random, but I would love to be able to talk to a more technical person at Acer to explain my issue as I believe things are getting "lost in translation..."  The other issue is I'm thinking it's battery related, and I would be the Acer tech left the Chromebook plugged in, and I've only experienced the issue while on battery power.

Given the above... I've updated my rating to 2 stars.

I've had this Chromebook for 3 months now, so this review is long overdue. When the first ever Chromebook was announced in 2010, I thought it was a stupid idea. A laptop built around only accessing the web? Why would anyone buy that when they can get a similarly priced Windows laptop? Fast forward several years, and Chromebooks have really hit their stride. The Chrome Web Store has really evolved with many apps also working offline (Nice try, Microsoft) and the pricing has gotten down to where I felt it originally should have been.

In my opinion, the Acer C720 is the best value currently on the market. I do 95% of my work online, so a Chromebook just makes sense. Plus, since Google owns my soul, errr, I use many Google products, it works out well. I needed something that wasn't top of the line, but could get through a small to medium work load without bogging down under the pressure, and had great battery life. -Thin profile, feels solid.
-Great keyboard for typing. Well spaced, raised keys.
-Good, mostly accurate touchpad. Love the multi-touch functions to scroll, open a link in a new tab. Some complain about the touchpad, but I can tell you I've dealt with far worse.
-USB 3.0 port, SD card support, HDMI out.
-VERY quiet, barely gets warm even after hours of continuous use.
-SSD makes boot up, opening files a breeze.
-Fast charging.
-Battery life lives up to the claims. I typically keep brightness around 1/3, and have gotten 6 hours on a full charge with over 20% of battery life to spare. However, like any other laptop, if you watch a lot of video, expect around half of what Acer claims.

Cons:

-Speakers are laughable, so make sure you have good headphones handy.
-Despite having a matte finish, the screen isn't so great in sunlight. Wish it had a higher resolution, but for $199, I can't really complain!
-Headphone jack requires a good amount of force to snap headphones in, but I assume this is to ensure they don't easily come unplugged.

Every product has some limiting facet, as microeconomics dictates, and the C720 Chromebook is no exception. There is always some sort of compromise between consumer needs and price. However, this chromebook does exceptionally well at maximizing both factors.
I've been using this device for about 2 months, give or take, and here are some of the real world benefits:
- Portability and battery life - you've probably heard this already if you've scrolled through the comments, but I can't get over how great both of these are
- Can do the vast majority of my work on the Chromebook - Honestly, I came into this thinking it wouldn't be useful, as internet connection is supremely important, and none of the traditional Windows programs are available - Photoshop for one, but what I realized gradually is that I really don't use those programs all that much. I like to think that I'm a "power user" and I assembled a beast of a PC a couple of years ago, but now I find myself only occasionally - perhaps once or twice a week - using my fully decked out Batmobile type desktop. This $200 machine suffices in most cases - for taking notes in class, for researching for papers, for listening to Spotify, for keeping a calendar.

Here are some of the downsides. I try to keep in mind the price point, but some issues are worse than others.
- 11.6 inches is kind of small. You've heard about the screen quality, and some gripe about pixelation and poor viewing angles, but I find the screen for the most part alright. It's just really small, to me at least, coming from a 27 inch desktop monitor, and sometimes I find myself straining to read small text on the screen.
- Whenever I download/open a document for school that happens to be in .doc or .docx format (which is always), the document opens in this thing called QuickOffice beta, which frankly sucks. Sure, it only takes, like, 5 clicks to convert it to .gdoc, but sometimes I can't find the convert button thing and I spend around half an hour messing with it so that I can edit said document, only to give up in frustration and go to good old copy-and-paste. Minor annoyance, yes, but still, an annoyance.

Conclusion: Buy this right now don't think just go button smash this is a better deal than FDR's

It does pretty much everything you want for everyday use, including fast browsing, playing web-page video or YouTube content, music etc.  The one exception might be writing documents, as the intention is that you use Google apps and Google Drive.  My existing '.odt' OpenOffice (LibreOffice) documents cannot be opened this way.

The C720 is lightweight and low power so it doesn't get hot and makes for comfortable laptop browsing.  The 8-hr claim for battery life is a bit optimistic if you happen to launch a few web-page videos, but several hours is realistic on a single charge.

I bought it with the intention of using Crouton (chroot) to also run a Linux system in parallel.  So far it works great after installing Ubuntu "Saucy" with the Cinnamon desktop.  With this setup you can use ChromeOS for everyday browsing and playing media, and switch instantly to Ubuntu for development work, or to use LIbreOffice for document editing.

At $199 this is a new price point for a capable PC.  The dual-core Celeron is way more performant than some quad core Android devices (see my Minix Neo X7 review).

My only complaint is that the SD card socket is not one where the card pushes all the way in.  The card sticks out about 1cm, which could lead to damage if it were knocked.  With only 16GB of on-board flash it would've been nice to have a flush fitting SD socket.

i have now had the acer c720 for 15 months. i still like it. however, it has a continued issue in which it just randomly shuts off. at first it didn't seem like such a big deal. it happened once a week or so. but now, it happens more frequently -- sometimes more than once a day. its annoying. i realize the cost was only $200, but i think it should stay powered on even if it cost less than that. acer hasn't been of any assistance. i have read the comments on line about others having this same issue and the comments from acer (as recent as oct 2014 anyway) about 'looking into' the issue. that doesnt help me or anyone else whose acer c720 chromebook randomly shuts off.

i have been using the acer c720 for six weeks now.

the good:
i like it. it works well and, honestly, i cant find anything in terms of productivity that it doesnt do. i use google apps, docs and drive so i do not miss using a downloadable office suite. im in property management and i find that google docs and drive fit my needs very well. i absolutely love how it boots up and is ready to use in approx 4 seconds. i do not miss the annoying and endless start up/shut down and updating of my previous windows 7 laptop.

it works smoothly when streaming online shows and movies.

it prints very easily from a wireless printer that supports chromebooks. actually that is a big reason i purchased the chromebook and the epson xp-410 printer.

the battery is great. i usually plug it in at 10 pm and unplug it at 5 am when i get up and it lasts the duration in between. not bad for a $199 laptop.

the not-so-good:
in the six weeks i have owned and used the acer c720 chromebook, it has, for no apparent reason, just shut off. it has happened 5 times while streaming online shows and while using google music service. i cant seems to isolate any factors that are causing the issue, but its a little frustrating especially if im watching a cool movie ...and wham..it shuts down. no notice, its just a black screen and i have to boot it back up.

the bottom line:
other than the unexpected shutting down, i really like the chromebook. i have not decided if i should send the chromebook back because thats such a hassle and its the only computer i now own. because it boots up so quickly it isn't as bad as it could be. nonetheless, if you are considering a chromebook, just be aware that it might have the same sudden shut-off issue mine has. otherwise i highly recommend it.

I have friends and associates who recommended this chromebook to me, and as of yet--I think that it is a wonderful device! I conducted research before acquiring this, and although the low cost motivated me--I don't typically throw money around for kicks. This was a $200 well spent in my book because the Acer c720 is a useful tool. It would also be a huge step up from nothing for users can't afford a full fledged laptop, this to me, is revolutionary.

Overview:
It's not necessarily a laptop replacement, but it's better than a laptop in a few ways. The main strength of the Chrome OS is that it is very difficult to hack, and it is usually intuitive and fast to use. This could replace a laptop for someone who only checks their email and does not need a computer for anything apart than web browsing. It's light, inexpensive and operates as a computer for accessing one's google drive and online resources. Everything that it does is FAST, extremely fast for a computer with 2GB.

Reasons why I bought it:
I have a mac book pro, but after it experienced connectivity issues with my campus network I realized that I only used photoshop and other memory intensive programs at home. I now carry this chrome book with me because it is light, inexpensive and will allow me to upload files for class, type, check my email and visit facebook. It's a mobile computer which I use to submit assignments and can even do in browser programming for class. It's a chromebook dedicated for getting work done, if I need power I'll go home or elsewhere--with this I can't play games (a definite plus for productivity's sake) and feel motivated to work. I sometimes keep it open at home in order to check my email while I'm working on my computer. I also wanted a smallish computer that didn't run windows or android--this fit the bill.

This works for me because if necessary-- there are plenty macs and pcs on campus if I need other programs. Also it's fine for anything that I might need to do in a coffee shop.

Size: Small and light. I know average sized men who use it therefore the small size is not necessarily an impediment for average use, but the small size might also make it suitable for a child. When it's in my backpack I don't even notice that it's there.

positives:
+ 7 second boot up
+ watching videos online is great
+ Light
+ 200 dollars is a stellar price for its size and functionality
+ App store has note taking apps for class
+ decent battery life (8 hours)
+ FAST

negatives:
- keyboard and track pad are average (use a usb mouse)
The keyboard does not feel wonderful on my hands although it is certainly an attractive chiclet style board.
- /+ offline functionality is not superb--average. Carrying a usb drive for backup might be useful for some people.
- the slideshow part of google drive is unreliable, don't depend on it
- Feels unsubstantial-- some people might drop it if they're not careful--it is very light, don't leave it near the edges of tables if you have a cat.

Improvements:
I would like a less "grainy" keyboard, a more comfortable track pad, skype and a full-ish microsoft office would also be great (but I knew this before I bought the computer). Perhaps having microsoft office would defeat the purpose of a chromebook? If it is offered in the future I'll try it though.

Also, if something were to happen to my main laptop or it were in the shop (never happened) I could still have a screen larger and more comfortable than my ipod touch. For the price--this is a wonderful machine and I plan to use it until it no longer works.

Recommended for:
teachers, students, grad students, fans of chrome os, web browsing people, travelers

My main gadget is a Nexus 7 tablet, but I have been wanting a keyboard and didn't want to get the kind that snaps into the Nexus. I read and watched enough reviews on the HP 11 to come to the conclusion that although the screen is wonderful, the performance is mediocre.  I then read enough reviews and feedback on the C720 2gb to realize that 4gb in a Chromebook may not be entirely necessary at this point in time.  Thus I finally took the leap last week and ordered the Acer C720 2gb.  I could not be happier!  Some have complained about the lackluster screen but I actually find it quite nice, at least for my purposes of pinning to Pinterest, editing photos, and reading articles online. I have owned several 7" tablets, a Nexus 10" tablet, and countless Windows laptops and computers. Since purchasing my C720 several months ago, it is the thing I reach for when I want to process my email, search the web, or work on any of the increasing number of web-based applications I use. In addition, I maintain several servers using the fine 2X Remote Desktop Client on my chromebook. This (I am using it right now) thing is as light and small as my Nexus 10 in its keyboard case, but so much better for everything that requires even a little typing. The only thing I still do on the tablet is watch Netflix and read e-magazines on Zinio. It is pretty much the same thing with my current laptops (and HP 12" touchscreen model (weighs twice as much as the C270) and a 15" i7 that I use as a backup server and for programming. I spend far more time using the chromebook than either of these other portables. So, although technically the chromebook is a supplementary device, it is the one I use most. In all fairness, I should add that my business uses Google Apps for Business, so the chromebook is a great fit in that regard, but Chrome is such a good browser that I think it would work just as well if we used Office 365 instead. I can't believe that this machine was only $200.

Features: Time to get into the system to start using it is as fast as anyone could ask for, and less than the 15 seconds that I have read in various reviews, whether starting it cold or waking it from sleep. In that respect it feels more like my phone or tablet than my computers. The keyboard is solid with good action. I can type as fast as with any other keyboard I have. It would be nice to have a higher resolution screen, but it is good enough, and the brightness is absolutely fine. Although I really have not found it necessary, I leave a tiny 64 GB flash drive plugged in all the time, in case I suddenly need some off-line storage. Oh, that reminds me of my one gripe. The SD slot is very shallow, so if you insert an SD card, most of the card sticks out. That means it is good for copying stuff onto or off a temporarily inserted card, but you really can't leave it in there or it will surely get broken. Anyway, no biggie. I am delighted with this purchase and with the chromebook concept. It works out much better than I had imagined it would!

I'm in IT, so I like to explore different options for my clients.  With the end of support for XP I have a lot of companies who are looking at their options for their aging desktop replacements.  Linux is often mentioned as a replacement for MS products, but the market is fractured and no one distro seems to have risen to the top, so Apple and Google seem to be the only viable options for most mainstream users.  With new Windows based computers averaging over $700 per unit plus new software it's not an insignificant decision if you have to replace, say, 10 of your computers.

I'm finding that more and more people use their computers primarily online anyway, so the "limitation" that Microsoft rails against in the "Scroogled" ads isn't particularly valid for many users; of course you can turn on "Offline" on your Google Drive and work on documents and email when your not connected.  With 100GB of Google Drive space for free for two years storage capacity isn't a problem for most people.  Photos can be placed on Google+ without eating into this 100GB limitation so that helps.

The computer is very fast doing most things, depending on your wireless connection.  It boots almost instantly, opens local apps like the file explorer and video player instantly, and is light and seemingly sturdy; at least it feels sturdy in spite of the plastic case.  The battery life is quite good at about 8 hours of use and it charges remarkably fast.  The screen is OK, nothing amazing, but quite readable.  With the HDMI out you can easily plug it into a large monitor or TV.  It quickly recognizes the second display and you can easily use that additional display as a mirror or as an extended display.  This is not a gaming computer, but for HD video playback it is excellent when viewed on a large display.  Movie viewing on the internal display is quite acceptable as well, although the internal speakers are not very loud and the 11" screen needs to be held pretty close to your eyes, but not much closer than a small desktop monitor.  Headphones overcome the sound problem if you want to use them.  It's own internal display has good viewing angles from side to side, but is quite sensitive to the horizontal tilt.  However the hinge is stiff enough that the display will stay wherever you place it, so I don't find this a huge drawback, but it could be better.  The keyboard is acceptable given it's size and I don't really miss the lack of the function keys, or you can plug in an external keyboard and mouse.  The internal storage is fairly limited but a 16GB USB flash drive like the SanDisk Cruzer Fit fixes this for very little money.

So much for the physical part; how is it to use for work?  Well, pretty good, actually.  The cloud is incredibly convenient for those on the move, assuming you can find a wireless connection, which is more and more common, but most will use the Chromebook in their houses and/or offices.  The range and sophistication of apps is increasing at an incredible rate.  Many desktop functions like QuickBooks, AutoCAD, and office suites are now apps.  That's the good news, the bad news is that many of these apps are still not as sophisticated and feature rich as their desktop counterparts.  QuickBooks, for instance, doesn't let you customize your invoices nearly as much as the desktop version.  The biggest use for computers in the business world is, of course, office suites and Google Docs does a pretty good job, but still lacks many of the features of  desktop office suites.  For instance Excel or  OpenOffice Calc will let you format cells so the text can be angled, but Docs lacks that feature.  That said, Microsoft's own Office Online also lacks this feature along with other limitations.  However, the ability to work collaboratively from anywhere is great and if you work a Google Sheet or whatever, you can later use OpenOffice, LibreOffice or other software to tweak it later.

So, is the Chromebook or a Chromebox at full fledged replacement for your aging XP?  No, not quite if you require a feature rich software package(s), but it's pretty close.  I have clients with perfectly good XP machines and they plan on using those machines until the computer fails, but they also realize that as of the 8th of April they will have to unplug those machine from their network and the Internet after moving much of their data to Drive and also backing up locally.  However their investment in the computer, in MS Office 2003, and in other software will continue to be useful as an adjunct to their Chromebooks.

For under $250 this is an amazing little computer that will do most of what many people need.  Cloud computing is still in its infancy and as the power of apps increases so will the functionality of this type of computer.  One of the best parts is that you don't need a guy like me to fix your computer anymore; no more viruses, no more software updates, no more backing up your computer; it's all done by the pros, mostly at Google, so it's transparent to the end user.  Some folks worry about the security of their data, but I think that the whole business model of Google depends on them protecting your data so they invest millions into backing up the data and keeping it secure.  How much did you spend on the same functions over the last 5 years?  Less, I'll wager.

Bottom line; if you're tempted, I say go for it, I doubt you'll be disappointed and will probably be amazed.  This is not the only Chrome device out there; I also recommend that you look at the Toshiba Chromebook with its larger screen or the ASUS Chromebox which should be out in March.

Remember the price of this laptop I can't complain at all about the screen Hdmi out - I've hooked this up to my 55" samsung tv via hdmi. The picture was amazing. Just make sure you don't choose mirror displays. that will send the 1366x768 image to the tv. Choose the other setting and it will send a full 1080p signal to your screen. I tested playing movies from either usb port, the sd card, and the actual hard drive on the computer and all worked perfectly. Webcam- just average. In good lighting its a decent image. I really find this incredible, my past laptops were 3 hours at most wifi- works great. I needed an ethernet port which this did not have. I purchased a usb to ethernet adapter from amazon. Sabrent USB 2.0 to Network 10/100Mbps Ethernet Adapter sd/usb ports - all work and quickly, dont' have any usb 3.0 devices to see how much quicker the usb 3 is. keyboard- i like the small keyboard. can reach any button easily while typing. doesn't feel cheap. the full screen button and the buttons around it are a little "clicky". KEYBOARD
I have one complaint about it: the KEYBOARD.
It's only OK. Which means, it is not bad, but it is far from being good.
It does not have definite pressure points; you can't feel whether you've pushed the keys down or not.
So the keyboard is definitely not good.

MOUSE
One more thing you might come across (but this is related to Chrome OS, not this device):
If you like fast MOUSE cursor movements, i.e. you are used to that a small mouse movement causes big cursor movement on the screen there is a high chance that your usual mouse will not fit.
You have to buy a mouse with at least 1600 DPI sensitivity. I don't recommend Logitech mice since most of them have 1000 DPI and Logitech even doesn't state the sensitivity of their mice.
I've managed to buy a cheap no-name Chinese wireless mouse for around $15 which is a 1600 DPI wireless mouse and it works like a charm; it is sensitive and fast enough, and very responsive like a wired one; there is not any lag stemming from the wireless operation.

So you have to be sure that the sensitivity of the mouse is at least 1600 DPI. If it is higher that is not a problem -- in the Chrome settings you can decelerate the speed. It's just can't be set to be fast enough with a 1000 DPI mouse.

The product was certainly a bargain at the price; it just wasn't what I was looking for. With a limited capability it really was not something I could use on a daily basis. I wish had I bought something different.

Update 5/15/2014:
My original review is still posted below.  I just wanted to update my review, as things have changed for the better and I want to be fair.  I have changed the rating from 3 stars to 5 stars, as this is one of the best technology purchases I have made in quite some time.

I did end up returning the Chromebook I purchased in February, as I couldn't resolve the wifi connection issue(see original review below).  After a few weeks without it, I began to miss it.  I spent an hour or two reading the forums again, and found what I thought might be a solution to the wifi connection issue.  So I ordered another Chromebook from Amazon.  I signed into my wireless router and found that the firmware hadn't been updated for over three years.  Did the router update and checked settings(switched Chromebook connection to 5 Ghz band - my dual band router has 2.4 and 5 Ghz), and the Chromebook hasn't dropped my wifi connection once.  I gave up on the music and apps, figure I don't really need them on this device.  I didn't try the SD card slot either.  Again, not something I really need.  I use this fantastic device for everything internet except for MMO gaming(that's what my laptop is for).  Highly recommend for anyone who just needs a quick device for things like e-mail, YouTube, online banking/bill paying, social media, etc.  I'm not usually a fan of touchpads, but this is the best touchpad I've ever used - first time I don't want to use a mouse.  You can't beat this device, especially at this price.  I've had it for about a month now, and have absolutely no complaints.  Love it!

Original Review:

Pros:
 - Nice web browsing at great speed
 - VERY quick startup
 - Amazing battery life and charging (better than I expected)
 - SD card slot (also a con, see below)
 - Good price

Cons:
 - Doesn't use Google Play Store apps (Chrome Store - big difference)
 - No user manual included
 - SD card doesn't insert all the way into machine
 - SD card not always recognized

Now for a little explanation.  The web browsing is nice at a fast speed, even seems faster than my Intel i7 laptop.  I was thrilled that it has an SD card slot, but even that seems to work only when it wants to.  Transferring files takes A LOT of time.  There is also a problem with maintaining wifi connection.  This seems to happen when the battery gets down to about 50%.  I have restarted my router and the issue is still there.  If this issue isn't resolved, I will be returning it.  A big disappointment for me was that it doesn't use Play Store apps, as I was hoping to play some of my favorite games.  The Chrome Store doesn't offer many games that interest me that are also available offline.  Another big disappointment is that the Google Play Music app (pre-installed) is a nightmare when trying to add my music to my library.  Apparently it requires downloading another app (Music Manager), but there are four different versions of this app to download, and I don't know which one I need for my Chromebook.  That's another issue: no real support site(s) that are helpful enough to guide a Chromebook novice such as myself through tasks that should be pretty basic.  I understand that the Chrome OS is updated frequently and this makes a regular "User Guide" impractical,  but something explaining the basics (beyond "plug it in and turn it on") should be included.

As an Amazon Prime member, I bought a Kindle Fire, but the web browsing crapped out on me within six months of purchase, so I don't want to buy another Kindle.  I guess this will work fine for web browsing, checking e-mail, YouTube, and watching Amazon Prime content (tested and works well), but I was hoping for something with which I could also use to play games and listen to my music.  I guess this is not that device.

This Chromebook is for my husband to check email, use craigslist and general web surfing. It has fit the bill perfectly.  The screen is small (no surprise) for games, but for everything else, it is a snap. It is totally quiet. After some set up issues (mainly our router needed to be moved), wifi works beautifully.  It is also super fast.

There are just a couple of things I don't like; one is the mouse pad which doesn't have a separate button so I often accidentally zoom in on google maps (since I have one finger on the "button" and one on the other hand "pointing"). The other thing is I almost always have the audio "headphone" jack plugged into my home stereo, and I am startled by a loud buzz when the book goes to sleep or turns on, or at other times (it happens fairly frequently) and is really unsettling. And I guess a third thing is I do have to limit the number of tabs (pages) open, or I get the "he's dead Jim" message. On the whole though, I'm very happy with it. I use it to read, often when it isn't plugged in, and the battery life seems fine. The screen isn't nearly as good as my 15" laptop, but it's so light and easy to travel with (around the house or out-and-about), I am really glad to have it. The keyboard is fine, only the mouse pad, lacking keys which aren't also part of the pointer surface, is the only thing I'm having to struggle with (and the loud buzz).

I bought my C720 about 6 weeks ago (local purchase), and haven't regretted the purchase in any way.  It does the job expected, in a very competent fashion.

I bought it after an in-store trial of 3-4 different Chromebooks.  This one was clearly faster, snappy compared to molasses (the other models) at loading a complex web site.  I still feel like I never wait for it to do something.  Now, I'm not opening more than 2 windows at a time, nor do I expect this to be a high end gaming device or a monster calculation machine.  I bought it because I got tired of 5 minute start times on my other machines.  I've got two Win 7 laptops that take forever to be ready for use.  The Chromebook is absolutely ready in 5-7 seconds, every time.

The battery lasts a very long time.  In my typical short daily uses (5 minutes here, 20 minutes there), it seems to last about a week.

Chrome has opened every web site successfully.  No problems.  I had no problems using Logmein to remotely access a work computer (but with their recent company issues I have switched to VPN on Win 7.  I haven't tried VPN on the Chromebook).

I was surprised there wasn't a direct WiFi link to my printer.  The free Cloud Printing from Google works fine...perhaps a few seconds more delay reaching the printer than my local WiFi would give.

Mostly I'd say the take home lesson is that you turn it on (quickly!) and it just works.  Fun and quick.  The only way you could go wrong is to buy it expecting it to run Win 8 or Windows applications.  Or to to handle 5 programs at the same time.

Oh yes, the build quality is better than I expected from Acer.

My desktop died almost a year ago.  It was almost 9 years old and obsolete.  I had upgraded it a few times, and it was a real workhorse while it lasted.  The BSOD (blue screen of death) had become a daily occurrence, so I finally let it stay dead.

I replaced it with a tablet which I thought would be sufficient since I'm now retired.  But there were limitations - small screen (OK for watching videos & playing games) and no SD card slot.  I hated the virtual keyboard, so I purchased a Bluetooth keyboard, and that helped a lot.  But I really got tired of having to use my sister's laptop to upload photos from my camera plus having constant eyestrain, so I ordered this Chromebook.

I've owned the Samsung Series 3 Chromebook and the difference between these two machines is astronomical in terms of performance. When comparing speed, snappiness, and quickness in loading pages, the C720 is the hare to the Samsung's tortoise. Most websites load just as quickly as they do on my MacBook Pro Retina 13", and once the website is completely loaded, scrolling up and down quickly doesn't hang it up at all. The Samsung's ARM processor is sluggish and there really isn't a comparison. Unacceptably for a modern machine that is supposed to give you the "best of Chrome", the HP Chromebook 11 has the same processor as the Samsung from 2012 and the performance is not much better.

Trust me - nothing is more frustrating than waiting for websites to load, and a close second pet peeve is poor performance, lagginess, and abrupt jerkiness when navigating around a page. You will get none of that on the C720. In this day and age, I need the internet to work immediately and reliably. The use of the older ARM processor is a huge oversight by HP and something they shouldn't have skimped on.

The Samsung and the HP definitely win in the looks dept., but the C720 isn't an ugly computer by any means. People moan about its design, but it's quite easy on the eyes when you see it in person. Pictures don't do it justice. The metallic gray is pleasing and the shiny bezel around the display is reminiscent of Apple's design choice, which I prefer to the matte black bezel of the Chromebook 11. The C720 is also very light and feels quite sturdy in the hand despite being made of lower cost materials. The keyboard is good enough to use, even though the keys do feel slightly "mushy", but they haven't caused me any significant errors or slowdowns so far.

You really can't complain of much when spending $199 on a computer. If you're looking for something fast, light, and can last all day, throw your chips on the Acer C720. You will not be disappointed.

I work in technology and have several high-end custom laptops running Linux and Windows and have very little patient for computers that don't perform very well.  I have been wanting a Chromebook for some time but wasn't sure what to expect. I care more about performance than looks so I went with the Acer since it was getting good performance reviews.  I was also looking for a another small and light computer that I could take with me when I travel for work that I could use for my personal use - I like to keep personal and work usage completely separate.

I have been using this laptop for several weeks now and I am very impressed.  This is now my favorite computer!  I did upgrade the SSD drive to a 64Gb drive which seemed to improve the performance and I have been pleased every since.  As Google says, it is instant on and off so you never wait.  The battery life seems to last forever.  It far exceeds any other laptop I have every had, especially at this extremely low weight.  I love that TPM is build into the platform for heavy encryption of the storage and I like having separate profiles between users.

It is a shift to have your data and applications come from the cloud but it works and completely integrates with my phone, a Samsung Note 3.  Once I got familiar on how to use my Chromebook and Google tools, I decided to move all of my personal content to my Google Drive - all of my pictures, documents, music, etc.  I encrypt sensitive information with Boxcryptor on my Google Drive.  This works well on my Chromebook and my phone.  I am now using my C720 for doing just about everything I use a computer for - creating and editing documents, editing and posting pictures, doing video calls and messaging with Google Hangouts. watching movies, listening to music and more.

By the way, the wireless radio on this laptop is amazing.  I have not seen another laptop beat it in speed tests on my wireless network - this includes custom gaming laptops with special wireless cards, a Macbook pro, iPads, phones, etc.  Only my Samsung Note 3 with support of 802.11ac comes close.  I couldn't believe it at first but test after test showed the same result.  Simply amazing especially at this price point!  I am not sure how Acer did this.

Wi-Fi access in Google sponsored locations is automatic as well.  I noticed that I got instance access in some locations without hitting the captive portal page and having to go through a registration process to get Internet access.  That is pretty cool.  When I travel, I like this laptop to my mobile hotspot on my phone and I am connected whenever I want to be.

There are times when I am using unsecured public Wi-Fi that I like to get my access through a VPN tunnel so I set up my Chromebook to use a L2TP VPN tunnel.  You can set it to automatically connect to the VPN server once Wi-Fi is connected and this works very reliably.

I also use this laptop with an external mouse, keyboard and monitor in docking mode.  I was even more surprised to see this laptop drive the display on my laptop while also driving my external display that is a 1080p monitor through HDMI.  You can extend the display or mirror your laptop display.  Either way works very well and I have never had even one issue, which is rare.  I have seen Macbooks and Windows computers choke on driving external displays more often than they should.

Watching video on this laptop has been a very good experience as well.  I watch Netflix, YouTube & Google movies and my own video files with no issue on my laptop or with an external display.  The video is very smooth.  By the way, any Google movie you buy can also be watched through YouTube.

This laptop will also reach multiple file systems on USB drives.  I have tried Windows and Linux partition formations without issue.

In summary, this is a solid device from Acer.  This laptop will spoil you and delivers far more value that most laptops several times more expensive.  It is easy to use by design but it is very functional for a wide range of users.  I am recommending this laptop to everyone looking for laptop.  There are some new ways of doing things in the Google Chromebook model but I think that is an easy transition to make and will greatly simplify your life once you do!  I also suggest looking at some of the Chromebook books on tips and tricks.  That really helped me in my transition as well.

First off, let's dispense with this "But, it's ugly" gripe. It's not. At all. I find the C720 thin and sleek, and I like the graphite gray color that gives off a titanium vibe.
