As for the "Jeez, you can (unlike the HP 11)  see the slotted vents and screws . . . and EVERYTHING on the bottom" Yeah, you can. I know, because I checked. And that's the last time I looked down there. Seriously, how much time do you spend looking at the underside of a laptop? Why is this even an issue?

Honestly, for me the "refined industrial chic" aesthetic of this little Acer is a plus.

As for performance, it's, well, amazing. I find both the screen and speakers more than adequate. The screen, once you find the right angle on your lap or desk (which requires all of about 2 seconds) has rich colors, solid contrast and color saturation. I watched a couple of Netflix videos on it yesterday, also several YouTube vids, and they all looked . . . fine. No, not an Apple retina display. But it didn't cost me $1,200 either.  And, with an IMac G5 desktop and iPad, I am, and have always been, a Mac guy. And I still find this Acer immensely impressive and fun.

The speakers, though expectedly thin on bass, are clear and resonant, though I do most of my listening via earbuds through which the Acer delivers superb, rich, and nuanced audio.

But mainly, the C720 is SO fast. Pages load up almost as fast as you click on the link: BamBamBam. Even the laudatory reviews of the HP Chromebook 11 concede that its processor is paleolithic compared to that of the Haswell-driven Acer.

Now, when it comes to computers, I am a certifiable cyber cretin. But within 10 minutes of unboxing the C720, I was zipping around with ease and confidence. Sampling videos, creating music playlists on Spotify, loading new apps from the store such as Planetarium, Pandora, and Old Time Radio, among others. There are still some tasks I need to figure out how to do, but I am now in my third day of use and am hugely enjoying my C720 experience.

I find the Acer C720 Chromebook is the best combination of price, quality, speed, and battery life among the several Chromebooks on the market. It serves a introduction to computing for new users and as a good traveling computer for PC users. Acer and YouTube have many tutorials on the features and use of Chromebooks. Check these out before you buy.

Tablets and Chromebooks are similar in a lot of ways. They are primarily for online use, they have very short boot up times, they don't drain much power in standby mode, and the price range is about the same. My Acer C720 boots in less than 10 seconds and goes several days in standby without a recharge. and cost $200. My Nexus 10 cost $400. Both tablets and Chromebooks require much less upkeep than a PC, for things like backup and virus protection. And the complexity is much reduced from that of a PC. There are fewer options, so there is less confusion in learning how to accomplish the tasks you want to do on a computing device. And, every hacker is not trying to download stuff on your device that you don't want. So when you evaluate a Chromebook, compare it more to a tablet rather than a PC.

Where Chromebooks and tablets differ is in productivity. Tablets have a touchscreen and apps which are convenient for consuming information, but the browsers are substandard compared to a PC, and there is no real keyboard for data entry. In that respect, Chromebooks are much more like a PC. For new users contemplating buying a PC, a Chromebook is a much shorter path to learning how to use a PC, than a tablet. For less than half the price of a PC a Chromebook is a cheap and easy way to get into computing, and it may be all that a lot of people will ever need.

The Chromebook can be set up to do the same things you can do on a PC with the Google Chrome browser. However, it's not limited to Google applications, only applications that work within the Chrome browser. Any web application that works in the PC Chrome browser works on a Chromebook. For example, Microsoft SkyDrive, Netflix, Spotify, Pandora, RSS readers, YouTube, Twitter, Facebook, gmail, Outlook mail, etc, all work in the Chrome browser so they also work on a Chromebook just like they work on a PC. This is not true of tablets. Tablet apps are configured differently from PC applications.

If you're using the Chrome browser now on your PC you know that it has many extensions like Add This sharing, Readability, Hangouts, free Google phone calling, etc. These are all available on the Chromebook. As a PC user, my Chromebook fits my particular needs much better than my Nexus 10 tablet. About the only thing I use my Nexus 10 for now are things like Hangouts, and other casual activities that don't require input.

Battery life: You can easily get 8 hours from this machine, and if you are careful with your browser tabs and screen brightness you can easily get 10-11 hours. And yes, it charges fully in 1 1/2 - 2 hours as promised.

Inflight Wifi passes:  12 of these free with purchase. Wow!

Cons:

This technology is right on the edge for business use, so some things are still works in process.

VPN: My company's VPN doesn't work with the Chromebook. Not a total surprise but would be nice to use this in public places with a secure connection.

Wifi: In the course of one travel day I connected fine to 2 networks but was denied access to 2 others. Not surprising that a machine that's essentially a browser can't support all possible configurations, but slows you down since this is meant to be an always connected machine.

So if you keep in mind this is a fairly new technology, and if what you want to achieve with it will be mostly online work, you won't be disappointed.

If you've been averse to Chromebooks before, you're like me.  There was always something that held me back.  Build quality, lack of computing power, bad battery life, etc.  This one caught my eye, with its specs anyway.  The design of the computer is understated, but the color scheme is nice, as well as the build quality for a budget computer.  Expansion slots are rather generous for this price point as well, featuring USB 2.0 and 3.0 ports, an SD card slot, and an HDMI out so I can expand my desktop and watch movies or videos on my TV if I want.  The only downside is that the shiny black bezel around the screen is rather reflective.  I'm not really sure why they went that route when the rest of the materials are pretty on point.

The performance and battery life are where this computer shines the most though.  With only 2GB of RAM, you might think that it will be sluggish.  You'd be totally wrong.  With the newest Intel Celeron Processor with the Haswell Architecture, this thing not only performs well above its class in speed, it simply outdoes any of the previous Chromebooks that are anywhere near this price range.  Startup is merely seconds.  That processor also helps keep battery life very good.  I've been using this computer going on 3 weeks now and I've noticed days where I used it for 7+ hours and I still had decent battery life remaining.  A lot of this depends on what you're using your computer for; whether you're working on text in WorkFlowy, have 8 windows open in Chrome, or have your screen brightness up pretty high watching videos.  I typically keep mine at around 2/3 brightness, as I don't work in very bright places, nor do I need it to be bright.

The keyboard is very nice, even though the spacing in the chiclet keys take some getting used to if you're coming from a more traditional PC keyboard.  The Function keys at top are replaced by just keys that do functions.  Makes it simple and way easier to use than some more feature-heavy Windows laptops.  The speakers, which are underneath the laptop, are actually pretty decent considering how small they are.  I prefer to just use headphones anyway, so that's not really a deal breaker for me.  The touchpad is really nice too, considering the price.  Multi-finger gestures work flawlessly and the feel of the pad is very comfortable.  The "click" of the pad, if you press down, is pretty noisy, but you really don't need to use it at all.

I've been getting lots of questions from friends and co-workers about this little machine and I can't help but highly recommend it, just as long as you know what you're delving into.  There is a learning curve if you've never used ChromeOS before, which I hadn't, but there are handy how-to's and guides built into the OS to help you on your way.  As ChromeOS gets updates and the community of WebApps expands, these machines are going to the be at the forefront of a new revolution of computing.

I actually prefer the Chrome OS.  It's zero maintenance.  No more backup for other people.  It should be fairly easy to sync firefox bookmarks and files across all machines.  But you need to setup.  If you are using the Google services, you are already setup before buying the C720.  If you lost the whole thing, the only thing other people can see is your google user name. Chrome OS has very limited apps.  It doesn't support wmv, though probably support most of codecs used in avi.  But the FLEX app works because it is pure html.  You can stream any movies from another machine as server.  If the codec is not supported in Chromeos, it will transcode as it streams.  But you need a decent machine to be fast enough.  Chromeos supports L2TP and a more secure startup mode of openvpn, that most canned vpn servers doesn't support that yet.

You can install and switch to Crouton (Ubuntu Linux) and back with a hot key.  But ... the same Chromeos kernel is used that is incompatible with the Ubuntu and other Linux kernels.  So Crouton can't be the answer to everything unless it can hot swap the kernel too.  Also, to start Crouton you have to get a terminal in Chrome, type the startup command, and leave the tab on.  I tried to save a few dollars by staying with my old vpn provider while having a cup of coffee but the Chromeos openvpn won't work in Crouton.

ChrUbuntu in Intel machines is more like a full blown Ubuntu.  It takes well over an hour to install.  Crouton takes somewhat less.  It occupy less than 5GB.  With 2GB left for Chromeos, I have 3GB user space left for Ubuntu.  Openvpn works.  Encryption works.  For codecs you need to install Ubuntu restricted stuff via software centre.  Full HD WMV works.  Trackpad works as in Chromeos plus you can use finger only to drag without the left mouse button - the Ubuntu/Unity way.

In a way, dual boot ChrUbuntu is more convenient.  When you power on the chrome book, you will see the warning screen in developer mode, ctrl-D will lead you into the Default Chromeos, and ctrl-L will lead you into the Legacy OS Ubuntu.  Even if you need to switch OS, both boot up very fast in the C720.

There are some caveats if you comes from Windows or Linux.  There are no mouse buttons on the C720 trackpad.  But the whole trackpad is actually a left mouse button.  Instead of the right mouse button, you can use double finger tap, which is superior and you can't miss.  There's no edge scrolling but I prefer two finger scrolling.  There are no more F function keys.  It is not just with different names.  Full screen is usually F11 but on Chromeos it is F4 if you count the position.  There is one USB 3 and one USB 2 socket because (?) USB 2 device won't work on the USB 3.  And you have to have another computer plus printer connected to the internet so you can print from your Chromebook using cloud print, unless your printer is cloud print ready (not even a wifi printer).

The speed of C720 is impressive.  It takes a lot less time to boot Ubuntu, but I don't know how much "smaller" the distribution is.  For movies in a USB 3 drive, you can use the > and < key to fast forward and back at will.  I don't know how to say this but it's like fast forwarding a VCR, but smoothly and much faster if you don't let go of the key.  You can scroll through the movie in a minute but you can pinpoint to the exact sec with ease.  Just two keys.  It's the same in Chromeos by default and in Ubuntu too.  But by default the Ubuntu player skips 1 minute and back something like 30 sec.  It should be capable of 10 sec forward and 5 sec back, while fast forwarding (and backward) the whole movie in a minute.

I switched to the Acer C720 Chromebook (2GB RAM) after spending most of my life on Windows PCs and laptops. At first, the switch was weird, as it would be for anyone in any situation where one uses an unfamiliar device. But once I figured out how to utilize and customize the Chrome OS to my liking, I've become a very happy Chromebook user.

After I set everything up to my liking, I started noticing a lot of nay-saying about the Chromebook I've come to love and use as my primary computer. A lot of this negative talk has come from Microsoft and, I suppose, power users. Or people who just don't like Google in general.

But I digress on the latter because that's such a heated topic and that's not what I want to write in my review about. What I do want to do, though, is dispel this misconception that the Chromebook is a total brick without wi-fi.

Here's what I can do offline:

- Listen to music
- Read epub and mobi ebooks
- Read pdf files
- Write txt, docx, and gdoc files
- Get to my Google Drive
- Play games (though I'll be honest, I don't play games on my Chromebook, but I know it is something I could do if I wanted; it's just that any game you want to play has to be on the Chrome store and it needs to be made for both online and offline use)
- Read email
- Create mindmaps
- Create notes on Google Keep
- Create tasks on Wunderlist

Now, one may still think that's still not a lot, but let's keep this in perspective: this is how I utilize my Chromebook every day, excluding whatever browsing I might do on the Internet. And these are the only tasks that I want to have if I'm offline. When I'm online, I do a lot of other stuff, granted--but for those days I might not have wi-fi, I can rest assured knowing I can at least do what I need to do on my Chromebook without any issues or panic.

So clearly, the Chromebook isn't a brick offline. All the essentials are there. And honestly, I find it much nicer because there's less distraction. I can focus on my tasks throughout the day instead of fiddling with my desktop and groaning about using a laptop that I feel like I will never utilize completely. In that way, Chromebook shines. It's not for everyone, but it is for someone like me.

EDIT: I also want to add that I watch videos online, on YouTube and other websites, and it works wonderfully. I have no complaints. In fact, I've found that videos load more quickly on this Chromebook than it did on the HP laptop I used to have. On the HP laptop, if I was watching a movie online, it'd take an hour or two to load completely. On the Chrome OS, the same video might take, what--5 or so minutes to load. Ever so often, it might take longer, but it's happened rarely.

Now even spreadsheets can be created, accessed and updated when offline and syncing is automatic next time you are connected.  More on the laptop: lightning fast, solid, very light and portable, amazing battery life, plays online videos seamlessly, runs all my apps and online software without hesitation, turns on from sleep instantly, powers on from fully off (rare) very quick.  I have not yet found a downside to this laptop or ChromeOS, even though I was a little skeptical.  Thank you Acer for this award winning laptop and Google for this slick, revolutionary operating system.  I would recommend this laptop to my parents, business users who have flexibility to use new, more flexible tools, students (big yes) and anyone who is tired of worrying about viruses, applying updates or fussing with your computer.  You may not be happy with this laptop if you are looking for a large screen (this one is made to be very portable), want to play the latest games (not for the serious gamer) or are tied to legacy programs like old fashion accounting or old fashion productivity tools that are installed only locally and not cloud based (everything here is designed to be shared online through your Google account or other credentials so you can access it from anywhere and any computer, though much of it can be also done offline, then synced next time you get online).  Happy Laptop Hunting.

I've had my Toshiba laptop for about six years now. In effect, its performance and speed have degenerated, despite keeping it as healthy as possible. Seeing as how I do most of my computer work online nowadays anyway, getting a Chromebook was the most cost effective alternative to getting another laptop or desktop.

Everything you need to use the internet as effective as possible is in the Chromebook through the usage of applications. Some standard apps that come with the unit are Google Chrome, Docs, Play, Drive, GMail, and pretty much everything else in the app store.

Two gigs of SDRAM, and 16 gigs of solid state hard drive space, and 100 gigs of space on the Google Drive is pretty good for a computer of this scope. Unit boots up in seconds...literally! Computer has built in virus protection, and it updates itself, so no worries on that end.

Please take note however, that this is not a Windows based laptop...it's literally just the Google Chrome web browser in laptop form, loaded with all kinds of applications. So if you need something that'll do more work than just browse the web, play music, and edit documents, I highly recommend getting an actual laptop.

If you find yourself online most of the time, doing nothing much beyond that, you can't go wrong with the Chromebook.

I love how fast it boots up, but as I try to duplicate the programs on my old Windows machine I a slightly disappointed.  No Google Earth, but it is a Google os machine.  The spreadsheet app won't recognize Open Office spreadsheets.  Still, I am bent on moving to the cloud and hate the way Windows machines get slower every year.  I think I will learn to live with this machine,  Great battery life and boots in seconds.

I got this because my Nexus 7 battery is going down hill fast and I wanted a bigger screen to look at. Plus, having a keyboard makes all typing WAY better than on any touch screen. Plus, I can do some work that I really couldn't do on my tablet. This thing fits my needs to a tee. Despite this, it isn't a tablet and tablet are better for some things IMHO. They are smaller, more portable and faster at some media consumption activities. I knew this and am quite happy with my Chromebook. In terms of performance, it is lightening fast - just as much as my full blown laptop and desktop. In fact, it pretty much is a full-blown laptop. Outside of the Citrix Receiver I need for work that I can't get for it, I can do anything on it. For the price, there isn't anything that compares too.
This is great for those who only need a web browser. There is no need for antivirus software and don't have to worry about getting loaded with malware.

I purchased this as a smaller portable laptop for school and remote access. I'm pretty new to the chrome OS but so far I've been very pleased with it. It's not a windows/mac machine but it's also not supposed to be. As long as you keep that in mind you'll probably love it.

I was very pleased with this laptop, I got it for my preteen son and for what he needs it for, it is a perfect computer at a reasonable price. I set the parental guidelines of course. these days having access to the internet is crusial for young children and there education. anyway great computer and very pleased

Not a lot GB storage, only 16GB. But, a 64GB Flash Drive does the trick.
No complaints, absolutely happy with the laptop. All my buddies from college are buying it, due to the apps like Google Drive and not to mention, long battery life!!!!!!!

I purchased this Chromebook for my mom to replace her aging ThinkPad Windows notebook computer.

Some background: A few years ago my dad who is in his 80's switched from a Windows laptop to the iPad and has absolutely loved it. Previously I was always having to make house calls to fix his Windows laptop since there were so many random ways that he could change the settings, drag and drop things to the wrong place, have issues with the internet, etc. The switch to the iPad gave him a very consistent environment that doesn't provide an easy way to accidentally change settings or do anything that will prevent him from getting on the internet, checking his e-mail, etc. To top it all off he really likes the interface as he was never really a keyboard and mouse person anyways.

Fast forward to today... My mom, who's in her 70's, was always having similar issues with her laptop. Problems connecting to the internet, issues with losing icons on the desktop, figuring out bookmarks, accessing her mail, etc. The catalyst was when she complained that the computer no longer was lasting very long without being plugged into power. She doesn't like the iPad design since she prefers and keyboard and also likes to sit the computer on a table with the screen visible without having to hold it. I already had her setup with a Google account since she uses Gmail so the Chromebook was a natural choice for me to consider for her.

When the Chromebook arrived I set it up with her Google account and then gave it to her accompanied by a brief lesson on how to use it. Needless to say this thing is levels and levels beyond her old Windows computer. It boots AMAZINGLY fast. From a full power-off state it boots up and is ready to use in about 6 seconds!

The integration with Google is of course very tight. Once she is logged into the computer she is also logged into Google so her e-mail is just available right away rather than her having to go to the Gmail website and enter her username and password again.

The hardware design is also great. This thing is very lightweight and slim. It is like a luxury item compared to her old computer even though the Chromebook cost just a fraction of her old one!

So far she has been using it without any problems. I can judge how good a product is for the average user based on how many "tech support" calls I get from my parents. In the case of the Chromebook the support calls have dropped significantly!

If you are looking for the ideal computer for an older relative or for somebody who just isn't into all the technical aspects of traditional computers then this is a great low-cost solution. The overall design and form is perfect for being mobile and the operating system itself is very streamlined and simple, yet powerful enough to get all the usual internet needs (browsing the web, e-mail, etc.) taken care of.

Got this for my son-in-law.  I don't know much about what this was, but he is into electronics & I knew her didn't have one.  To me the only bad part is it doesn't run Windows.  That is my fault for not doing more checking.  I did give him a choice of exchanging it for a regular laptop or keeping this & he chose to keep this, so at least he was satisfied with it.
Nice cheap laptop for web browsing. Does not offer much past Google services but for the money well worth it.

I had the older Samsung ARM Chromebook,  but it would stutter and lag when trying to watch some streaming movies on Google Play,  so I sent it back and got this model.

I was lucky enough to get one of the 4gb models, and this thing is perfect for watching movies, consuming media, writing emails, or anything else I want to do.

Just to test it out,  I had several tabs open simultaneously playing movies on Netflix, Google Play,  YouTube (HD), streaming content on the Weather Channel website, Pandora, AND graphic-heavy sites the Verge and ESPN going all at the same time,  and there was absolutely no lag or stuttering at all!

I think the keyboard and trackpad are just fine,  and I really like the gestures, 2-finger swipe, and keyboard shortcuts that a Chromebook features.

I also utilize web-based programs like pixlr that is a web-based photo editing software when I need functions like that, so I really don't lack for any functionality on the Chromebook.  Any heavy lifting is done by my desktop computer anyway,  so this thing does everything I need it to do.

Really a great product.

I personally purchased the 4gb ram version, but it's basically the same thing...

I honestly love this thing, I use it constantly, but this is due tot he fact that I use chrome os AND debian linux. Many people that have given this a poor rating is because they believe it needs internet access to do anything. They obviously bought this type of computer for the wrong reason, and not enough knowledge. If you want to use it as an only online computer in chrome os, go ahead... But that is only using half of the potential, if not less, that this machine has to offer.

Personally I use this computer for programming, and as a media device to randomly plug into tv's and such. I also use this any time I am not at home, seeing as it is so portable and has an easy 10 hours of battery life, its great.

Another reason people dislike this product is because it can't play games. Well it can... Personally I don't game on this computer, I have another computer dedicated to that, and I use the chromebook to be productive, but if I really wanted to, I could install steam on any decent version of linux (debian, arch, fedora, centos, ubuntu, etc.) and play games. I have seen people play Skyrim on this chromebook (albeit on the lowest graphics settings).

Overall, it is a great computer, but you should really try and unleash the full potential of it yourself, or else you won't be having the best time you could with your new chromebook.

EDIT: An easy way to make your chromebook run chrome os and another version of linux is to google search "crouton" and go to the "dnschneid/crouton  GitHub" entry, and follow the instructions. It basically installs the chosen distro of linux inside chrome os, and you run it inside chrome os, allowing you to seamlessly switch between both os's at any time with a simple key combo. Personally I use Debian Jessie with LXDE, if you don't know what I just said, just follow the instructions, which will give you Ubuntu with XFCE.

Also, to do this you need to have your chromebook in developer mode. You can do this by:

  -Press and hold the Esc+F3 (Refresh) keys, then press the Power button. This enters recovery mode.
  -Now, press Ctrl+D (no prompt). It will ask you to confirm, then the system will revert its state and enable developer mode.
  -Press Ctrl+D (or wait 30 seconds for the beep and boot) at the white boot splash screen to enter Chrome OS.
  (copied from arch wiki)

So far it has been a great decision. The small size of the chromebook make it extremely portable. Much like a tablet, I find that I can take this thing anyplace that I would take my 10 inch tablet. This chromebook  handles as many windows as I normally would have open without much noticeable change in speed. No real difference from my macbook there.

There have been so many reviews of this thing, I really shouldn't waste time typing so much. If you like browsing the net using Chrome and need a laptop to perform the basic tasks, then this is the device for you.

I bought one of those (4GB) for my son who is at University to replace / complement an old laptop, and he loves it. Okay, I spent weeks, no months laboring over whether to replace my laptop (monitor no longer works) with another windows based laptop or go Chromebook.  I am already heavily entrenched into the Google ecosystem and consequently the Chromebook was a big draw.  For those not quite entrenched in Google, I can understand why a Chromebook may not be as appealing.

Let me be clear:  I already have a work windows based laptop that I can do various things if necessary.  What I mainly needed was something to more easily type long emails, etc on.  We mainly use it for the internet and doing more robust web browsing when the android tablet just won't quite cut it.  The Chromebook fits the bill to the "T"!

One review I saw about windows based laptops vs Chromebooks that i agree with: Chromebooks do not need as robust hardware because they don't have the heavy and complicated windows software that needs a fast processor to operate.  2 gig RAM is more than enough.  And the Haswell based processor is plenty zippy and keeps the laptop running for days for me with periodic use.

The selling point for me?  Once I realized I can access my old laptop with my Chromebook using Google's "Chrome Remote Desktop", I was in business.  This way I can access my windows laptop and my keystrokes on my Chromebook control my old windows based laptop and my old laptop sends the screen to my Chromebook's monitor.  It then looks like on my Chromebook that I'm working on my old laptop.

All for $199, half of a new windows-based laptop?  How can you go wrong?
It's great! I bought this for my wife and she loves it! She has even gotten used to doing word processing and spreadsheets using Google docs. She loves the speed and ease of use.
This Acer chrome book is an excellent value if you don't need full computer. Great speed and convenience for web activities.
all I wanted was to surf the web and check my e-mail and this does it perfectly. Recently I started to use it to make phone calls also.

They do lag a bit..Was very disappointed that my kids couldn't play minecraft on it especially after I spent 30 bucks on a minecraft computer game..Kids think it's ok..Does have some good features to it..Wouldn't ever purchase another one..I think it would be good for those who aren't really into much but social media or surfing the internet..

Last Christmas, I got the kids a Kindle Fire.  This year, I got them this Chromebook.  It's a great alternative to a tablet as it has a keyboard to enable typing and document creation.  No set-up is necessary, I just turned it on and boom I am on the web in seconds!  The launcher at the bottom is a nice feature to add your favorite apps for a quick launch.  It's just one click to launch the webcam.  I really like cloud computing as it allows me the flexibility of creating a document at work and then accessing and revising it home  without needing to send it via email and worry about multiple copies and versions.

The only drawback to this Chromebook are printing and projecting the Chromebook onto my TV.  Unless you have a Cloud Print compatible printer, you would need to connect your classic printer to cloud print using your PC/laptop (Google these terms for setup instructions).  Once these are set up, using your Chromebook, you can virtually queue your documents to this cloud print queue.  If your PC/laptop is on and connected to your printer, it will print out your documents.  Since I have a laptop that is not permanently connected to my printer, I would need to fire up my laptop and connect it to the printer to print these documents.  So,  there is little advantage of using the Chromebook.  I may as well just use my laptop and print from it!

Additionally, projecting the Chromebook to my TV using a HDMI cable is not intuitive.  Even after many tries, the projected screen on the TV is not fully extended to fit the size of my TV.  I am buying Chromecast to see whether the projection would be easier.

It's overall a good machine especially if you mainly use it for quick web browsing (it boots up much faster than a PC/laptop) or document creation.  It would be great if I can just plug the Chromebook to my printer and directly print!
easy to use boots up quick, perfect for google search and email, I really like the internet radio and available music to store on the cloud, I would recommend it
Good product great price. Very happy with its performance and speed. I would recommend this product for people who surf the internet
I guess I wasn't aware of exactly what I was purchasing.  I bought it for my husband and he really doesn't like it.  I'm going to send it back and buy another one.

I bought this to replace my girlfriends aging 17" HP laptop. It was heavy and so hot that you had to use a lap cooler (which made it even more heavy to lug around). When she told me she wanted a Chromebook I was skeptical and kept re-iterating that it wasn't a "real laptop".

I got the 2GB model and have had no problems. I sometimes find myself using Google Remote Desktop to access my powerful desktop from the comfort of my couch, and it works with almost no lag.

-I was surprised by how heavy this thing felt. It's not much heavier, but you can really feel it. It was a little disappointing when I first picked it up. Still, it's not exactly a sack of bricks. It's really light, just not as light.

-It feels sturdier. The keys on the Samsung constantly fall off, but these feel like they're holding on well (so far). I'll certainly update if I have problems.

-The keys are a little hard to press in the beginning. It takes a few days of getting used to, but they are definitely harder to press than my macbook pro and just about any other modern keyboard I've used. That's not necessarily a bad thing, just a matter of taste.

-The screen is beautiful on both machines.

All in all, I'm happy I got this machine over the Series 3, mainly because of the issue with the keys falling off of the latter. I would prefer that machine in just about every way if not for the keys. This is great though, and I can't think of a reason to dock any stars at this moment.

Over the past year I've had an iPad, an HD+ Nook, and a Samsung Tab 3.  What I liked about tablets, compared with a full-fledged laptop, was the instant-on availability, and all-day battery.  This Chromebook has both, plus it has a decent keyboard that I was missing on the tablets.  I use the Chromebook for web surfing, and since I don't play games I don't miss all the apps; there's a website for everything I need.  I have the 2GB RAM version, and I haven't had any noticeable degradation in performance.  I frequently have 5-10 tabs open at a time.  As for the touch pad, it took a getting use to, but after several weeks I really liked it.  The only problem is trying to select large blocks of text can be tricky.  The screen isn't as good as most laptops, but for a couple hundred dollars it isn't bad.  One thing that's really nice is there's no function keys, and they're replaced by very useful buttons like contrast, volume, refresh etc..  Overall I'm extremely happy with this Chromebook.

My fiancee had mentioned to me at different times she wanted a netbook type of computer, she wanted something small enough that wouldn't take up too much kitchen table space and yet large enough for comfortable viewing.

With so many different netbooks on the market, it was a hard choice. Knowing she likes using Google Chrome, Gmail and other Google products, I decided to focus on a Google oriented computer. Chromebook and I'm glad I did. She loves it.

The Chromebook is perfect in size,  you feel like you're using a laptop without the chunkiness. The bootup is extremely fast, turn it on and you're ready to go in seconds. The graphics and sound quality are fine for watching movies or listening to music.

One feature she liked, you can set the touch pad to scroll with two fingers, making for easy web browsing. For applications, Google has numerous additional applications that can be used on the Chromebook.

I've been reading about Chromebooks all year; the concept was pretty intriguing, despite the fact that I have a bunch of other/similar devices:  an entry-level Sony Vaio from 2011, an X51 Alienware desktop PC for gaming, a 2011 Kindle Fire, and a Moto X smartphone.  So why add a Chromebook?

I wanted a multi-use device that could...

Stream music from my Amazon Cloud
Stream instant video from Amazon (great selection of kids stuff) and Netflix
Run full versions of websites
Have a full keyboard, for writing emails or various other things

The Chromebook does all this stuff for basically the same price as a tablet, but it is much closer to a full function PC than a tablet is.  I like it as a video device far more than a tablet.  I like it for using the web far more than a tablet or smartphone.  For items not related to gaming, it has basically replaced my laptop in its entirety.

About Chrome OS and this device:  I'm currently streaming music from Amazon with 9 Chrome tabs open and have no issues at all.  I have a hard time understanding what people need 4GB RAM for with this device; how is it useful to open 15+ Chrome tabs?  I haven't run into any performance issues at all.  The boot time is absurd.  7 seconds may be underestimating.  It also shuts off instantly when you hit shutdown.

Thus far I've had no real issues with the Chrome store or apps; Google Docs is fine so far for working with MS Word items, and in fact Google Drive is now installed on all my devices because I've started doing my writing on this device.  Remote Desktop lets you connect to any of your Windows PCs for using Windows programs through those computers if you really need to, though I imagine I'd have to be using this more for work to need that for anything.

I've used this to watch a decent amount of content on Netflix and Amazon Instant.  The screen is... ok.  It isn't all that bright and won't "wow" you but as a portable mini-TV it does the job.  My son loves watching his kids shows on this, which lets us reclaim the real TV for our purposes.  Speaker quality is likewise functional but won't blow you away.  Headphones are the way to go when possible.  As it relates to both of these, I'm perfectly happy with the quality for the price.

I didn't have any issues with the keyboard, I'm normally a 90 WPM typer and am probably a bit slower on this, more due to the size than anything.  I actually like the trackpad to be honest.  Not sure why folks don't.  It isn't the worlds greatest but is way better than the one on my Dell PC from work and perhaps marginally worse than the one on my Vaio.  My basic Logitech wireless mouse worked fine with the Chromebook, but I stopped using it pretty quickly as I got used to the trackpad.  The dual-finger scrolling and chrome forward/backward helps a lot.

Battery life is pretty nuts.  I've gotten about 7 hours of pure video streaming.  At the high end, just off the charger, you get some arbitrarily high readings (like 9+ hours) but I think the claimed 8 hours is probably accurate.

The fact that you can "hack" this thing into installing Ubuntu is awesome.  I haven't done it yet, but the concept is very cool.  Native gaming in Chrome OS is miserable outside a few highlights; I'd say the main one is the Chrome version of Bastion, which suggests companies COULD make some great games if they wanted to.  But with Ubuntu, you can theoretically play Linux-compatible games you may have; I know I have a bunch from Humble Bundle (such as FTL) that should run great on this laptop, even if it wasn't meant to do so.  I bet it can run older games very well also, such as Half Life 2 or the original Portal.  My next project is to play around and see if I can pull off Steam and if the 16GB SSD can handle something like that.  If so, I'd give this thing... six stars?  Can't really give it more than I already am.

Anyway... know what you're getting into here.  This isn't a full Windows laptop.  You can install Linux and access a lot of full-featured laptop programs that way, but even still, your hard drive space is limited and this may be beyond the basic users capabilities.  If you do video compiling, music or photo editing, gaming, etc. as your main laptop activities, this would need to be a 2nd computer for you.  If you find yourself using alternate devices like a smartphone or tablet in your house for watching movies, listening to music, or browsing the web, you might get great mileage out of this device. I know I have.

Highly, highly recommended device.  I love this thing.

EDIT: Just over 90 days of use later, and I can tell you that I've completely fallen in love with this device. It is the fastest Chrome device in my house, far faster than the dual-core Sony Vaio it replaced and even faster than my core i7 Haswell gaming desktop. I've installed Ubuntu 13.04 and 13.10, both XFCE and Unity, through both USB 3.0 and SD card, and played Minecraft and Steam games on this thing. The batter life is still epic. What else is there to say?  This is, hands down, the single best value buy in all of computing right now.

I purchased this unit and replaced the internal 16GB M.2 SSD with a 128GB model.  This laptop works quite nicely for those of us who like to get our hands dirty.  It comes with Google Chrome but there are google-able instructions on how to adjust it to boot a non-chrome OS.  Ubuntu linux should work pretty much out of the box.

I purchased the unit to get BSD running on it.  I'm hacking DragonFlyBSD into shape and solved the boot loader and keyboard issues and am working on the mouse pad.  X runs fine in VESA mode (so great for 2D), sans the mouse pad which I am still working on.  FreeBSD, OpenBSD, NetBSD, and so forth will not current boot due to numerous fixable issues but I assume that since I got them fixed in DragonFly, that the other BSD's will be able to get them fixed too.

For developers I suggest loading a couple of 16G usb sticks.  Load one with the Chrome recovery image (google-able to get it), one with your favorite OS, and consider purchasing an internal M.2 form-factor SSD to upgrade the 16G internals.  The case is *trivial* to take apart... just a lot of screws and simple snap-tight after that (be sure to break the warranty seal can unscrew the screw under it).  With the recovery image in-hand you can feel free to blow away the internal SSD... if you mess up and get stuck you can always reload it from the recovery image.

The only downside when running non-chrome OSs is that the laptop boots up with a BIOS warning screen that you have to hit ctrl-L to get past.  There's no way to get rid of it short of mod'ing the HW which I do not suggest.  However, I am not going to dock it a star for that one issue.  Also note that there are only 2 USB ports and *no* hard ethernet... you have to use the built-in wireless adapter (it's an Atheros AR9460).

This laptop has a pretty nice display for its small size.  With DragonFly it pulls 7.1 watts idle with the lid closed and ~8W with it open (and DragonFly isn't power-savings-optimized).  That's with the wifi turned on... so not bad at all.  The laptop has a Celeron(R) 2955U @ 1.40GHz (haswell) class cpu in it... considerably faster than the atom-based netbooks of old!  For comparison, this cpu is about 5x slower on a per-core basis than a 3.4GHz desktop I7, and has 2 cores (so about 15x slower than a 4-core/8-thread 3.4GHz I7).  Which is not bad at all considering that the whole laptop only pulls 8 watts from the wall.

The unit has 2G of ram.  The OS is able to use ~1.7GB of it.  Keep in mind that with a bigger SSD inside you can set up a SSD swap partition on it, and at 300MB/sec+ and no random seek overhead, the 2G of ram is not a big deal.

-Matt

For $200, this thing is fast. Easily downloads 720P from YouTube. HBO Go, Hulu and Amazon Prime videos play quickly and smoothly. Startup is super quick and the screen is very nice and non reflective. It is quiet as there are no internal moving parts. I am very happy about how fast this Chromebook loads web pages. I recommend this product.
bought for an 11 year old for schoolwork and fun.  they are still getting used to it but it's great no complaints so far.
I am not very technologically savvy, so why has it taken me so long to get a chromebook...  I absolutely love this, and wish I bought this a long time ago.
This is a good notebook...You do have to get use to Chrome, but it is fast and you can browse easily....There are several apps and you can customize it to your needs.

Bought this for my mom who isn't at all computer savvy.  It is incredibly fast and easy to use.  She loves downloading new apps and toting her little Chrome-baby all over the place!  It does everything she needs and nothing she doesn't, which is great.  I recommend it to anyone who needs a new computer but wants something streamlined and efficient.

Pros:

- battery life almost 8 hours

- secure (great for older and younger people or for people who don't know a lot about computers -- in a way this is the best feature)

Con:

Like any other Chromebook is not for everyone or for any purpose, for that it's better to have another PC with Windows or Mac OS in your household, this is a great second device. I highly recommend it for such a purpose.

(I got the 4GB model, I don't know if having only 2GB would negatively influence the performance, the 4GB works great, I don't think that the 2GB would be underpowered).
Unbelievable !! Love it. works super fast. It's like turning a page of a book. Been recommending to everyone. I am truly happy with it.

I was already a Google fan with their apps on my moto x phone. 7 sec bootup and syncing up with my google account just makes my life easier. I got it on Cyber Monday with a great price. I recommend to get a external drive and google chromecast. I barely use my other laptop.

Spilled Lemonade on my old Lenovo PC and needed a replacement. I did a lot of research and ultimately decided this machine was the best value out there for folks like me who prefer a laptop over a tablet for basic web browsing.

I find it hard to believe there are people who have bought this item and are complaining about the lack of functionality. $200 and not one lick of research? Come on people.

This thing gets 5 stars because it does what it intended to do, and it does it very well. I am already enjoying not having to deal with anti-spyware update notifications with every log on.

My only complaint is the keyboard, it's just not very good. I am circumventing via a wireless keyboard I bought that works without issue. In summation, this is a great product and one I highly recommend.

I purchased the Acer C720 for my Wife for Christmas it does all we expected and more quick booting and loading of apps a great piece of equipment for surfing the internet. While its not a monster computer seven tabs open and no problem with speed a truly great light little internet tool. When I saw the advertised battery life I was doubtful it would really perform that long between charges but I was wrong and the recharge time was amazing from 20% to full charge in a little over 1 Hour great equipment.

perhaps more chrome than chromebook... but kind of buggy... frequently freezes-up... It's not my connection, have several (windows) laptops with no issues, but more of an explorer user on those.

3/9/14... Update.... kinda of in POS territory after a couple months. Real slow resolving url / web surfing. Down to 1 star. If I had to do it over again... would spend another hundred... and get a "real" laptop.

I got this for my 7 year old son for Christmas. Its been a lot of fun for him. You can enable a supervised account with your google account and supervise everything they do (at this time its a hidden setting in chrome, search for it). I set it up so he can only go to the sites I want him to go to like kahn academy, wikipedia, lego, math games, etc. He is having a lot of fun and a lot of learning and like I said, I can log into my google account and control where he can go online. Its decently made, its not going to be on par with the build of a real laptop but for 199 bucks Im not sure you should expect that. Its a nice, cheap 'laptop' for doing a lot of things online.

I upgrade from the sARMsung chromebook and this is a huge upgrade.  Battery life doubled, performance easily doubled.. I hooked up via HDMI to my 39" tv and works smooth as silk.  I rarely go beyond a half dozen tabs at any time but the responsiveness is noticeably better.

Build
The quality is much sturdier than the sARMsung.. feels much more solid.  Keyboard keys are bit smaller than i'm used to but not a big issue.  Display is bright and crisp.  Video is rich and works without a hitch both onboard monitor or on tv.

I'm only a week and change in, i'm sold and already pimping chromebooks with a renewed fervor to friends again.
It does not do everything I need it to.  I will be returning it so if you could please send me a return label I would apprecaite it.

Our household has a Kindle Fire, a Kindle Touch, a First Generation iPad, an iPad 2, Android phones, iPhones, and a desktop.

 I originally asked my husband for a Kindle Fire HD for Christmas. Then, a friend mentioned getting an Acer Chromebook and how much she loved it. I told my husband to change my Christmas request, if possible. Santa delivered and I couldn't be happier.

 I have used my Chromebook to Facebook, play Candy Crush, email, pay bills, watch Netflix, upload a sale to Craigslist, ebay, shop online, watch youtube videos, and surf the net.

 My six year old has used my new Chromebook a few times with no issues. She can find "her" websites (American Girl, PBS Kids, Nick Jr, Disney) without a single problem. My daughter has never used a laptop. She immediately taught herself to use the track pad.

 The battery life of the Chromebook is awesome and it charges faster than any device that I have. The track pad is simple to use. Two finger touch/press and your have your "right click" function to save, cut, copy, paste, spell check and more.

 I have no problem with the Chrome OS. I never used it until I received this Chromebook and it isn't hard to get used to using.

If you're unfamiliar with chrome OS, Don't buy this machine. It works very well for what it is, a fast internet browser. Everything in chrome OS is wifi based. The "apps" are just links to websites you can already go to. If you want music you have a number of streaming sites plus google play music. Google docs for word documents, you even sign on to the chromebook with your google account. The price is great for this machine but outside of wifi you're scroogled (as microsoft said in their new attack adds) as your chromebook is essentially a paper weight. For the more tech savy, you can also run Ubuntu ([...]

I have had other laptops before but this one is the best by far. It just takes seconds to turn on like advertised. It was a great buy and i would recommend it  to anyone. The only thing that the app store does not have is Skype. I hope it will be added.

I like this mini laptop a lot, very light and convenient to hold. BUT, on occasion, I'm getting the dreaded "web page cannot be displayed". It will load OK after I repeat the command. I've rebooted my router and even did a pwer wash, but to no avail. Guess have to live with it.

This is my first chromebook. I love the keyboard - the keys are not slick, but slightly textured. The power button is too close to the backspace key and is in the far upper right; however a single tap on the power key only flickers the screen. The screen is looks great and the battery life is great.

I have the 2GB version but wanted the at-the-time unavailable 4GB.  I have found the 2GB to be enough memory, per crosh & top. Video and embedded Adobe products use a lot of memory, so keeping those tabs closed when not in use helps.  Chrome OS will discard memory for "low priority" tabs when memory runs out; meaning you would need to reload those pages when you click on a discarded tab.  So, you really always have memory.

Rendering is slower than any other real laptop or desktop I own. So have your expectations set properly for performance.  I chose this new Acer over the Samsung for its faster processor; and I'm glad I did.

Although I am a heavy user of Android and Google services, I waited a long time before buying a Chromebook. The concept intrigued me since they were originally released, but I wasn't sure that a Chromebook would be enough to fit my needs.  After a lot of research that included reading many reviews, I finally jumped in and got one.  I could not be more pleased! This particular model is a great value, and for web browsing and email reading, it is perfect. The battery life is really good (over 6 hours depending on usage), and it is really light!

This is not a regular Windows computer, so you should be sure that you understand that before buying it so that you aren't disappointed. But for general Internet, email, Youtube, Facebook, etc, this is a great device. And with the Google offline apps, it can be used for word processing, taking notes, and other functions.

My only complaint is that the keyboard has those flat keys that look like chicklets, which makes it more difficult to type because you can barely feel where one key ends and the next begins. Plus, the keys don't feel very durable. However, most of the use I plan on giving it involves web browsing with limited typing, so it shouldn't be a problem. But if you are a blogger or plan on typing a book on this, make sure you try the keyboard at a store before you buy...

Chrome OS has a lot of drawbacks. You cannot use it to sync an iPhone. Forget about installing iTunes. Editing video would be a nightmare. This computer cannot function as a primary computer.

What it can do, it can do very well. It is ideal for checking email, purchasing items on Amazon, streaming music, checking accounts, and watching YouTube. Spotify, Google Music, and Pandora all work well on this computer.

As a teacher, I needed a machine to carry in my messenger bag, check attendance, and input grades. This computer is great for simple tasks. I am in love with it. I have a fully loaded Mac Mini at home and I use it for all of the heavy-duty computer tasks. As a secondary computer, this computer rocks. The battery life is insanely awesome (8 hours on a single charge!!). The screen is passable. The audio quality is okay. The storage is limited but if you have an internet connection, the world is at your fingertips. If it is on a website, this computer can handle it. For $200, I highly recommend it as a secondary computer.

i did not realize the operating system would not work for the service provider i wanted to use it with.
i do not like the fact that it's made to use with google cloud, and that service is free for only 2 years, then you have to pay.
i did not realize the operating system was something i was totally unfamiliar with and did not have the programs and features i was used to using.

overall it just did not fit my intended purposes and i chose to return it, and got acer with windows instead, which i am perfectly happy with.

Absolutely love this computer.  it's small and lightweight.  this computer is all about gaming/socializing and was perfect for my eleven year old.  It was her favorite Christmas gift.  Now I want one too!

The TN display had very poor viewing angles and was dimly lit.  When I tried turning up the brightness, the contrast was lost and everything was washed out in white.

As far as the viewing angles, as long as I was viewing it from a very narrow angle it looked fine, but I found myself constantly adjusting the screen tilt to get a clear image that was otherwise fuzzy and not clear.  I returned mine and will likely be targeting more expensive devices with higher resolution IPS displays in the future.  This device just hurts my eyes for reading.

It's a shame, because I really did want to like this since it performs spectacular and is a great value for the money.

I love Google -- I use their apps for everything -- and I definitely use my home computer primarily for email and online shopping, so I figured a Chromebook would be perfect; however, after having only a MacBook for the last few years, I'm having a very hard time adjusting to the lag and overall inaccuracy of the trackpad on the Chromebook. This alone would be no big deal considering how little I paid for this guy, but on top of that, there is this awful, faint, high-pitched sound that intermittently comes and goes while I'm using the Chromebook. Many people may not be able to hear it, but if you have sensitive ears (i.e., you've experienced going into someone else's home or office and you need to leave because either a TV, computer or lamp is making a sound that's driving you insane and nobody else can hear it), you might want to steer clear. I Googled, and according to a couple of threads on Reddit,  I'm not the only one who has this problem with the C720. Aside from these two complaints, it's definitely a great product for the price, but I probably wouldn't have bought it if I'd known about these drawbacks in advance.

I brought this as a birthday gift for my daughter 9 year old.  What was surprising is that my wife who has a Sony Viao laptop also prefers to use the Chromebook when she can.  My daughter hit the ground running with the Chromebook os and did not require any training.  This serves all her needs and i do not have to worry about virus, patches or a corrupt os, boots in 7 seconds and an 8 hour battery life is icing on the cake.

My wife has expressed that she is willing to take a Chromebook for her birthday gift to replace her Sony Viao.  Although this may not be a full blown computer, this serves 100% need of 80% of the users.  for the remaining 20% of the users like me who have specialized need for software for professional reasons, you always have the macs and window pcs and the associated pain that comes with it.

We bought this for our 9 year old grandson - he can do anything on this that he wishes .
We will most likely buy one for our 5 year old next year. Just right for their small hands

I will not say a Chromebook will replace what a PC or Mac can do. But for a lot of consumers it will probably be enough. The Hazwell chip is so much better then what the Samsung Chromebook has that you should not even consider the Samsung. I have now had both a Samsung and the Acer C720 and the Acer is improved so much over the Samsung. I like the feel of the Acer keyboard and the Touchpad is a decent size because it does not have a lot of multi touch features. Chromebook's really remind me of a Netbook with a OS built for a small form and minimal hardware specs. When you match hardware with a minimalist operating system like Chrome OS you get good battery life, responsive user interface and a good user experience. Its way better then buying a cheap Windows 8 machine which is a terrible match with cheap hardware and a more bloated OS. I first considered a small MacBook Air the 11.6" model but for $999 its really a expensive piece of hardware for what I intended to use it for. So finding the Acer with a much improved Hazwell CPU which provides good 8hr plus battery is better choice for me. The only down side to a Chromebook is that you are stuck in a Google ecosystem and more specific a Chrome OS ecosystem. So if you are using apps like iTunes, Microsoft Office, some tax software, or like other browsers like Firefox, Opera or IE. Your gonna find a Chromebook restrictive. No it does not run Skype either. I am perfectly fine with this, but I do think this limits a Chromebook's appeal and usefulness by not being able to run some apps that work on almost every other platform. I am sure a lot of people will buy a Chromebook or get one for a gift and be either impressed or disappointed in it. I can embrace it because its basically a web access device for me. But I am sure others will find it constrictive.
Great little laptop, Beats my former netbook hands down, Battery life is also better, You can go all day,  New processor is very quick and responsive.

I was looking for portable, handy laptop that I could carry anywhere. So, I was looking for light, long lasting laptop. At first, I marked Macbook, and almost purchased when I saw price drop in last Oct.
At first, this Chromebook was not attracted because of its OS which does not have useful app's for engineer. However when I found out that I could run Ubuntu, I googled detailed info like performance and usability. And I decided.
It's been almost three weeks since I purchased this one, and I almost satisfied with my c720 with Ubuntu 13.10 OS installed.

Pro.
1. light enough to carry everywhere, even in my messenger bag.
2. long battery life. (I noticed that I can use more than 6 hours, which is enough for my day to day journey.)
3. performance. (It feel like almost as fast as my office laptop which have 2TB 7200rpm hard disk with dual core ivy bridge CPU, even though it is actually slower. I guess that 16G of SSD and latest intel CPU may counts.)

Con.

Love how fast it starts up! Easy to use. GREAT GREAT GREAT and the price is right! Battery is charged for 8.5 hours! Light and easy to carry around with you.

P.O.S., honestly. It's not as great as advertised; thought I could buy a simple laptop for my father but it's just too AHHHH! Don't get it, just teach someone older to use a regular laptop. Merry freakin' Christmas!

Edit 2/13/14: After reading all the comments on my review, which I wasn't notified for, I decided to update my review.

-This laptop from the start asks you to create a user identification for Google.
-The screen is small compared to the laptop my father already uses.
-The complexity to this device is within its simplicity.
-The boot-up time is not as quick as it states.

-If trying to have something simple an older person can use (parent, grandparent), this is not the item for them as it is still just as confusing as a regular laptop [which, by the way, is a laptop that has Internet, browsers, desktop icons, viruses, downloadable content, etc].

-Stick with a Nexus, or some kind of tablet that auto updates everything. Download their favorite applications for the user of this tablet then let them be happy with it.

If my updated review still leaves any of you that commented, or any future buyers, in confusion then I don't know what to tell you.

I played with this machine for last few days and truly impressed by the performance.  It offers best value for given price.  Strongly recommended for students and others who want to use for light work.
Excellent laptop for everyday use and internet browsing. Really like the quick start and shutdown and long battery life. Light and easy to carry. Highly recommend it.

it is also very well suited for those that do everything on web sites and use cloud/web services.

The Chrome OS takes some getting used to and the keyboard is pretty weak, but this is a small price to pay for what you are getting at this price.  I also personally love the trackpad, but your mileage may vary.  If you need to a portable, durable, long-lasting internet workhorse, this is your product.

I picked one of these up a couple of weeks ago.  Amazon was sold out at the time so I got mine from Best Buy, but it was the same price.  It has exceeded my expectations.  Chrome OS feels "light" (in a good way), so combined with the solid state drive, everything happens lightning fast.  I should note that this machine is used strictly for email, web browsing, and streaming audio/video, but that is all I need it for.  There is a document editor that looks like it would do whatever I need, and there are plenty apps and games available for Chrome OS.  As these machines continue to become popular, look for a lot more cool applications to become available.  Perhaps the most noticeable part of this Chromebook's experience is that it powers on/wakes up instantly.  It only takes a few seconds to open the thing up and be looking at my home page.  Has an SD reader so if you think you need more space than the SSD provides, you can always pop a card in for more storage.

Pros: Surprisingly quick, light/portable, EXTREMELY long battery life (around 8 or 9 hours), very inexpensive, always stays automatically updated, and Google stays on the ball with updates.

Cons: Lower quality screen in comparison with higher-end laptops (can be understood with price).

I see that some people list the fact that this computer is only fully functional when connected to the internet as a "con."  However, this is a Chromebook, they are made for internet-based use, so I did not feel that was a fair assessment.

Bottom Line: My other computer is a Core i5 Ultrabook and the Acer C720 is an impressive machine to me.  If you are looking for a fun new toy that can breeze through the internet/email/YouTube and can go forever on a single charge, pick one of these up!

We had a five year old HP laptop running Windows 7 in need of replacement. It took forever to boot up,  was constantly updating Windows and was a little sluggish.

We originally were drawn to the Samsung Chromebook given its popularity on Amazon and its good reviews. But then the Acer C720 was released with the Has well CPU and the $199 price so we decided on it.

The Acer C720 boots up in seconds and it does match its 8 hour battery life claim. The Chrome browser is full function and no different than running itself on Windows. The same goes for Gmail, YouTube and nearly every web based application.

For offline use, there are a full set off Office apps that work offline. Same goes for Gmail offline.

We play a lot of movies on it offline and find mp4's play fine. We have played them off the internal memory, sdcards, external hard drives with no problem. We can easily move files from one device to another via the Files application.

Only issue we have seen is it won't recognize a cable attached Nexus 7 tablet, although it recognizes an Amazon Kindle Fire tablet. The Chromebook Groups say this is due to the Nexus supporting a new file transfer protocol and updates needed for Chrome OS.

Our conclusion is the Acer C720 Chromebook has successful replaced our old Windows laptop with great battery life, instant on, all at a great price.

I bought this as a replacement computer for my wife, because most of what she does is online and she would not have to worry about backing up or moving files, as they are kept on Google Drive.

This appealed to her, but the problem is that none of the apps from Google Play can be installed. We live out of country and any time she tries to install an app it says "This app is not available in your country." I'm having a hard time understanding why something that is installed via Internet, which we have, should be unavailable outside the USA.

Given the limitation, the term "Chromebook" should be named "Chrome Browser". Browsing is the only thing you can do if you live abroad.

For a user who likes to do standard internet tasks from banking and shopping, to surfing and reading this is a great option.  The 720 is light, has good battery life, is simple, fast, has a great screen and is well constructed.  Don't expect a BMW for the price of a KIA, but this is one cool ride.  Getting rid on my big HP and my Toshiba is collecting dust.  Will be sending one to a friend as a late Christmas gift.

this device is a small powerhouse. i am totally satisfied with it's performance. won't go back to regular PC. very simple interface . it also is wonderful for streaming  from the internet.works really well without all the bells and whistles of a regular PC. will purchase again if there is another upgrade especially if it is in HD. thanks Amazon for your wonderful service!

I got my first Chromebook about six months ago, it was Samsung series 3 with an ARM processor. Initially it meant to serve me as a second laptop for occasional light work online, but very soon I realized that I was using it most of the time. My powerful Windows laptop and Mac mini were just sitting there collecting dust, getting my attention only once a week at best. I replaced my Samsung with Acer C720 2 GB RAM version two weeks ago.
Here's a quick breakdown.
- C720 has a slightly better screen than Samsung. Same washed out colors, but contrast and viewing angles are better, and so is brightness level. If you are spoiled by the screens of modern tablets, you might think that 1366x768 resolution would look unattractive. That's not quite right. I should remind you that MacBook Air 11 screen has the same resolution and the same size. It's just enough to do what it's designed to do.
- The keyboard layout of C720 may not be as good as Samsung's, but I like Acer's feel and key movement better. Unless you have very large hands, it might provide one of the best typing experiences in the price range below $300, and it's definitely better than most Windows laptops for that price. I write quite a lot and C720's keyboard didn't cause any significant discomfort so far. Touchpad is reasonably good, but nothing to be overexcited about. I only wish it was a bit larger.
- C720 is WAY faster than Samsung. Don't be deceived by the name of the processor - this Celeron unit from the Haswell family has more processing power than Chrome OS requires. And 2 GB of RAM should be absolutely enough for anyone, who normally doesn't keep over a dozen tabs running heavy websites simultaneously. The fan would kick in from time to time, but it's very quiet and is never annoying. Boot time is typically impressive for Chrome OS devices and takes around 7 seconds.
- Battery life is one of the sweetest spots of this laptop. To get promised 8.5 hours you don't have to keep the screen brightness at 50% all the time (as you would do with the Samsung to get 6.5 hours). I don't carry the charger with me and never managed to make it run out of juice. In fact, sometimes I would even give some boost to my phone's battery from C720 without worrying that it may die unexpectedly. Also, the battery charges pretty quickly.
- Speakers of C720 are louder than Samsung's, but they don't sound much better - they shoot down at the table (or your lap) and don't really promise anything. But plug in headphones or external speakers and you'll get some decent sound quality for a low budget device.
- The Web Camera on C720 is also superior to the one in Samsung. Promised difference in resolution might not be that visible, but it keeps higher framerate, works better in low light and seems like it captures a wider viewing angle. It is definitely an upgrade. Microphone gets the job done, but it's not very useful in somewhat noisy environment.
- C720 is a little bit heavier than Samsung, but by no means it is heavy or bulky. It is still a portable laptop that could be easily moved or carried with one hand. Its build quality is better than most Windows laptops below $350. Obviously, there's nothing special about the quality of materials, but everything feels solid, the lid mechanism is sturdy enough, and overall it's not bad at all. It certainly lacks some style, but it looks and feels more expensive than it costs.
I love Chromebooks for the ease of use. The first set up takes about five minutes. They are perfect for kids, for elderly people unfamiliar with computers, for students, for writers, bloggers or even programmers. It's amazing how much stuff can be done in a browser. Online shopping, social networking, managing emails, listening to music, watching movies, reading books, video chatting - everything that most casual users actually do on their computers and even more. Offline capabilities are not forgotten - you can watch movies from the local or external storage, listen to music, work with Google Docs and many other Chrome apps or even games that can run offline. One of the greatest things about Chrome OS - there is virtually no maintenance. You have to try really hard to make it work wrong. I have many computers (too many in fact) and maintenance can be quite cumbersome. Are all operating system (OS) updates installed, is the antivirus running, are there system errors, and so on. That is why I like the Chromebook. I do not need to deal with a thing. My daughter can play all her online games without causing me any additional computer maintenance.

If you only need to do web based activities (browsing, email, watching online videos, writing papers, etc.), the Chrome OS is perfect for that. Just the Chrome web browser and no additional software. The operating system itself is a customized Linux distribution, which is well-known for being secure and not always requiring powerful hardware. If there is a problem with the OS, do a factory reset and you will be up and running in no time.

The size of this laptop is a bit small at 11.6 inches, but good enough for light work. It is a perfect size for my daughter. At $200, this is a great deal.

I bought this for my wife so she could do basic browsing and video chat with the kids.  The kids have Kindles which won't work with Gchat/vid/Gplus.  However, the Kindles do work with Skype which is nice because Skype is ubiquitous.

My brand new Chromebook, however, doesn't work with Skype.  I have to use the Google platform to chat.  I like the Google platform but it's unreasonable to try to force everyone else to use it.

So now I have two devices that can't talk to each other as if the technology just isn't capable.  The reality is that these companies are being petty and making their customers suffer.

On side-note, the Chrome web store is different than Google Play.  So don't expect that apps from your Android will work on your Chromebook.  They likely won't.

My advice is to skip the Chromebook and wait for Google to catch up to user needs.  There are better alternatives.

Once setup and connected this device is awesome.  You can read plenty of other reviews that will attest to that and why.  I have to dock a star because the initial setup is impossible if all that is available to connect to is a MAC filtered wireless network as we have in our home.  The wireless MAC number for this device is not listed on the box or the device itself and the setup screen does not allow any exit to determine what the MAC number is (the Continue button is inactive even if 'No network' is selected).  So - the MAC number of the device cannot be determined so it cannot be put in the wireless access point MAC filter table to allow it to connect.  Chat with Acer tech support was useless - they offered suggestions that will not work to determine the MAC address until at least one connection has been made or using keystroke combinations including Function keys that do not exist on the device.

In the end we went to our local library where there is wireless access but no MAC filtering.  Connection was instantaneous and at that point the network icon (lower right of screen) became visible and usable to determine the MAC address.  So then we could go  back home, feed that into the MAC filter table and we were golden at home, too.  An alternative that might have worked was a  direct wired ethernet connection - the Acer does not have this but using something like a Plugable USB ethernet adapter would probably work to get past the initial setup screen.

I'm a technology addict and I've been following the development of ChromeOS for a while. When it first came out, I totally understood the concept but wanted to wait for it to mature a while and the prices to come down. My trigger price point was $200 so when the 2GB version of C720 came out, I had to have one.

I find it amazing that such an inexpensive device can do so much. After having it a week, it became my favorite machine just because it is so simple and light. After using it, you come to question why we need such big computing power, huge hard discs and RAM just to run a traditional OS when it comes to supporting the use cases for about 90% of what you use a PC to do. Whats even better, the Chromebook is pretty much ready to go out of the box, with an already pretty rich supply of online an offline apps don't cost you anything extra.

Just like tablets came on the market and turned the PC industry upside down because they did 80% of a PC did, and did it with a better user experience, lower price with much less hardware spec. In the same way, I think the Chromebook will have a permanent place in personal tech as the one matching basic needs at the cheapest price - a second PC for around the home, or the "throwaway" unit for travel where you don't have to worry about damaging or losing it because its both cheap and highly secure.
